Labour's Lindsay Hoyle was re-elected as chairman of ways and means, while Tory Eleanor Laing was chosen as a deputy to John Bercow. The Commons Speaker was re-elected without a formal vote. The deputies must be balanced with one Conservative and two opposition MPs. Details of the number of votes each candidate received will be published later.

A study by US biologists found that the vibrant blue color in tarantulas is created by tiny structures in their hairs, which have evolved independently at least eight times across different species. This coloration is not likely driven by sexual selection, as tarantulas have poor color vision and do not display their blue parts during courtship. The consistent shade of blue suggests important visual signaling functions, possibly for concealment or warning purposes. The color evolved from multiple origins with various mechanisms producing the same hue, indicating its significance beyond attracting mates.

The campaign group Privacy International raised complaints about data collection by GCHQ, MI5, and MI6, leading to a ruling that some of the activities did not meet the standards of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). Supervision was improved last year. The review of spy agencies' activities revealed collection of communications data and personal information. Article 8 of the ECHR safeguards the right to privacy. Much of the data collection was authorized under an outdated law, prompting calls for transparency in legislation. New guidelines were established in 2015 for lawful data collection practices. The tribunal found past data handling to be unlawful, but the Home Office affirmed the importance of such powers in protecting the UK. Efforts toward transparency and stronger safeguards for bulk data collection were promised by the government.

Five soldiers were wounded in a rocket attack on Turkish tanks in Syria, while two fighters from the Free Syrian Army were killed. This incident marks the first fatalities since Turkey's operation in Syria began two weeks ago. The rocket attack, attributed to IS elements, occurred near the village of al-Waqf. Turkish-backed Syrian rebels have regained villages from IS, including the key town of Jarabulus. Turkey has targeted both IS and Kurdish fighters, drawing criticism from Washington due to the importance of Kurdish forces in combating IS.

The University of Texas at Austin removed statues of General Robert E. Lee and other Confederate figures, citing them as symbols of modern white supremacy and neo-Nazism following the violent events in Charlottesville. The university stated that such monuments do not align with its values and are not representative of American history. Similar actions to remove Confederate statues have been taken by other schools and governments in response to the racial legacy associated with these symbols. The debate over these monuments has sparked controversy, with some viewing them as part of US history and southern culture, while others see them as offensive reminders of slavery and racial oppression. President Trump expressed support for the statues, calling them "beautiful," but opponents argue they represent hatred and bigotry.

A £250,000 fund called Digital Xtra is supported by Skills Development Scotland, Highlands and Islands Enterprise, ScotlandIS and Education Scotland. It aims to support extracurricular computing clubs for children aged 16 and under. Submissions for funding will be evaluated by a panel comprising representatives from technology businesses, the Scottish government, and education.

Summary:
20-year-old French striker Moussa Dembele has excelled at Celtic since his move from Fulham, scoring 32 goals and attracting interest from top European clubs. Manager Brendan Rodgers praises Dembele's development and ambition, acknowledging he will eventually move on. Celtic are on course to win the Premiership title and remain unbeaten in the league. Rodgers remains focused on continued success and improvement through the season.

Terry Smith, 33, died in hospital in November 2013 after being held under the Mental Health Act in Surrey. The Independent Police Complaints Commission referred the case to the Crown Prosecution Service, indicating possible charges of gross negligence manslaughter and misconduct in public office for two sergeants and a health worker. The investigation focused on the methods used to detain Smith and why he was restrained at Staines police station. Smith was arrested after a call for assistance, fell ill, and passed away the next day at St Peter's hospital. IPCC Commissioner Jennifer Izekor expressed sympathy for those affected and emphasized the need for further criminal investigation.

Premier Inn is set to open three new hotels in Edinburgh, creating 150 jobs and 10 apprenticeships. The locations include two hotels on New Market Street and another in York Place. The addition of these hotels will bring the total number of Premier Inn properties in the city to 14, offering over 1,500 rooms. Additionally, a hi-tech "hub by Premier Inn" will be introduced, featuring innovative room control via Apple Watch. The hotel chain is excited about this new concept and plans to expand further in Scotland.

Retired Sheriff Peter Gillam explained that the varying rates of women being jailed across different courts in Scotland reflect the independence of the judiciary. Each judge has their own approach and views, leading to differences in sentencing. The existence of an Appeal Court serves to ensure some degree of uniformity, but judges ultimately rely on their local knowledge and information to make decisions. Gillam emphasized the importance of allowing judges to exercise their discretion and handle cases in a way they believe to be correct.

A 25-year-old batsman died from a brain haemorrhage two days after being hit on the neck during a match in Sydney in 2014. A hearing was held to determine if his death could have been prevented, with players accused of being dishonest in their testimonies. Key players, including Brad Haddin, Doug Bollinger, and David Warner, provided evidence at the inquest. Questions arose about whether the batsman was targeted with short-pitch bowling or unsettling comments. Concerns were raised about sledging and short balls bowled at the batsman. The counsel for the family criticized players for lack of recollection. The coroner's findings are set to be delivered on 4 November. Suggestions for compulsory helmets for batsmen were made, but it was noted that it would not have saved the batsman's life.

In South Sudan, 19 abducted children were freed by the government after mediation. The Murle community was responsible for the abduction, known for stealing livestock and children. Over 200 people from the Nuer community in Ethiopia's Gambella province were killed in the cross-border raid. Ethiopian forces surrounded the villages but the children were released peacefully through negotiations. Efforts are ongoing to free all abducted children. The incident sparked protests in Ethiopia, with calls for better protection for children. Ethiopia's Prime Minister condemned the raid as carried out by "primitive and destructive forces."

Andreas Lubitz was the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525, which crashed on March 24, 2015, resulting in the death of all 150 people onboard. Investigations revealed that Lubitz intentionally crashed the plane by taking control while the pilot was locked out of the cockpit. Internet searches on his tablet included information on suicide methods and cockpit door security. It was also discovered that Lubitz had a history of depression, which was not disclosed to Germanwings when he was hired in 2013. The recovery of the flight data recorder provided crucial technical information about the flight. Lubitz initiated the jet's descent leading to the crash, and the investigation highlighted the importance of the recovered black boxes in understanding the tragic event.

Priyanka Yoshikawa, a 22-year-old with Indian heritage, recently won the Miss Japan title, aiming to challenge stereotypes and redefine Japanese identity. She credits fellow mixed-race beauty queen Ariana Miyamoto for paving the way and hopes to inspire change in societal perceptions. Despite facing criticism for her background, Yoshikawa is determined to promote diversity and acceptance. She envisions a world where talent transcends barriers of nationality, ethnicity, and gender. Yoshikawa's victory sparked discussion on nationality and purity in today's globalized society, reflecting a shifting perspective towards beauty standards and cultural identity.

The Moscow city court ruled that the Church of Scientology cannot be considered a religious organization as the term "Scientology" is a registered US trademark. The court set a six-month deadline for the Church to close, based on arguments presented by Russia's justice ministry. The organization plans to appeal the decision. The Church of Scientology, founded by L Ron Hubbard in 1954, is based in Los Angeles, California, and has faced controversy globally, with critics accusing it of being a cult and scamming its members, while supporters argue that it offers spiritual support.

Alex Kersey-Brown, a Bristol-born rugby player who grew up in Penmaenmawr, represented Wales at the schoolboy level before turning professional with Huddersfield in 1967. He played for London Welsh and Oldham as well, earning two caps for Wales in 1968-69. Unfortunately, he passed away after battling cancer, with condolences extended by Wales Rugby League.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has mandated all MPs to support the bill triggering Article 50 for Brexit, prompting resignations from some within his shadow cabinet such as Shadow Welsh Secretary Jo Stevens. Despite representing pro-Remain constituencies, some Labour MPs plan to rebel against the party line. The bill, introduced following a Supreme Court ruling, is set to be debated in Parliament, with Labour pushing for amendments including a vote on the final Brexit deal and assurances from the government. Opposition parties like the Liberal Democrats and SNP are also taking stances on the issue.

Daniel Sturridge, a 26-year-old forward for Liverpool, suffered a strain after coming on as a substitute in a recent match at St James' Park. This injury adds to his history of recurring ailments, including knee, foot, thigh, calf, and hip problems, limiting his playing time last season. Sturridge has made six appearances this season, scoring four goals. Despite a recent hip operation, he managed to play a few matches before his latest setback. The Reds' manager, Jurgen Klopp, has emphasized the need for Sturridge to differentiate between serious pain and minor discomfort. Liverpool faces a busy schedule ahead, with seven games leading up to the League Cup semi-final against Stoke on 5 January.

President Joko Widodo proposed harsh punishments including chemical castration and death penalty for paedophiles in Indonesia following a tragic incident. The laws faced opposition in parliament from two parties, with human rights groups arguing against violence as a solution. The Indonesian Doctors Association objected on ethical grounds. The new laws also allow electronic tagging and a minimum 10-year sentence for child sex crimes. Despite criticisms, the government believes in the effectiveness of these measures to combat sexual crimes against children in the country.

A 17-year-old from the Netherlands and Belgium fell 40m into a dry riverbed during a "puenting" bungee jump in Spain, resulting in a fatal accident. Bungee jumping is popular in Spain, with companies offering jumps in scenic locations. This incident follows the recent death of a British tourist in a bungee jump near Granada. Local authorities expressed concerns about the safety of such activities, noting previous fatalities linked to bungee jumping in the country. It is advised to ensure the safety of a jump before participating.

Archaeologists from the NTS discovered a walled enclosure beneath the lawn in the Fountain Court of a castle in South Ayrshire. Believed to have served as a kitchen garden from 1733 to 1782, a new walled garden was later constructed out of view from the house to enhance the castle's landscape. The discovery sheds light on the estate's hidden history, with the original garden being part of Sir John Kennedy of Culzean's renovations in 1733. The walls of the garden were demolished in 1782 during improvements by Robert Adam. Ongoing drainage works in the Fountain Court aim at making it suitable for hosting large public events.

A landmark achievement was reached nine months ahead of schedule in March, with over 15 million people receiving antiretroviral drugs globally. Global efforts have averted 30 million new HIV infections and nearly eight million AIDS-related deaths since 2000. New infections have decreased from 2.6 million annually to 1.8 million, while AIDS-related deaths have gone down from 1.6 million to 1.2 million per year. Investment in HIV has risen from £3.1bn ($4.8bn) in 2000 to over £13bn ($20bn) in 2014. While progress has been made, issues remain such as lack of awareness of HIV status and lower treatment access for children compared to adults. Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for 66% of all new HIV infections, with an estimated 25.8 million people living with HIV in the region. Efforts are now shifting towards ending the AIDS epidemic by 2030 under the Sustainable Development Goals.

James, a 23-year-old from Colwyn Bay with diastrophic dysplasia, a form of dwarfism, has overcome multiple challenges through surgeries and leg straightening treatment. He will be carrying the Olympic torch in Rhos-on-Sea as part of the Wales relay, nominated by a friend he met at the 2008 Beijing Paralympics. Despite his condition, James is an active member of the Dwarf Sports Association, winning awards and holding badminton championships. His friend Russell Swannack praised James for his efforts in promoting disability sport, calling him an inspiration and a truly incredible person. James maintains a positive outlook, believing he was made the way he is for a reason and living his life without letting obstacles bring him down.

Mr Fox, a well-known radio presenter, is currently facing allegations of indecent and sexual assault spanning from 1988 to 2014. He denies the accusations, stating that his behavior was consensual and part of workplace "horseplay". He emphasized that the radio culture and workplace dynamics have evolved over the years, but his morals and behaviors remain unchanged. Several accusers have detailed incidents of inappropriate behavior, including squeezing breasts and simulating sex acts, which Mr Fox denies. The trial is ongoing as both sides present their arguments.

During the first quarter, Scottish retail sales saw a slight increase in value and volume compared to the UK as a whole. The Scottish Retail Sales Index indicated a 0.1% rise in value and 0.7% increase in volume. Retail experts highlighted a fragile consumer confidence affecting the industry and called for policies to boost investment and growth. Food sales primarily drove the sales volume growth, while online retail became increasingly important. Recent figures indicated a mixed performance in March, with household goods performing well but fashion and footwear experiencing a decline due to factors such as the early Easter.

Former Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu recently underwent successful heart surgery, which was decided during his annual medical check-up. His brother confirmed his good condition and thanked supporters for their prayers. Kanu had previous heart surgery in 1996, followed by a successful career in football and philanthropy, establishing hospitals in Africa to address heart conditions. Recognized as one of Nigeria's most distinguished individuals, Kanu retired from international football in 2010 after a successful career that included a FIFA under-17 World Cup title and Olympic gold medal.

A march in York started at 14:15 BST and proceeded to York Minster with representatives from charities, pressure groups, and refugees speaking to the crowd. The organizer highlighted the community spirit of York, while David Cameron announced the UK's plan to accept up to 20,000 people from Syria, prioritizing vulnerable children. City of York Council is collaborating with partners to determine how to provide support pending government guidance on the resettlement process.

Skippers and vessel owners in Northern Ireland are participating in an economic survey of the UK fishing fleet to gather data on running costs. Led by Seafish, this 11th annual survey aims to inform decision makers at national and European levels. Stakeholders are encouraged to share their insights to create an accurate industry snapshot and influence policy effectively. The results will be published next year.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a competent skier, tragically fell 160ft while skiing off piste in Flaine, near Chamonix, during a family holiday. The accident occurred when his sister lost her ski on a jump, causing Carwyn to ski ahead and become separated from his family. Police believe he skied in the wrong direction, leading to the fatal fall. The family, known for their farm business in Talybont-on-Usk, Brecon Beacons, expressed devastation and gratitude for the support received. The community, in shock over the loss of the 7-year-old, is ready to assist the grieving family upon their return.

The summary of the provided information is as follows:

- Various player signings have been confirmed for the coming months, with details available on specific pages.
- Notable transfers include Oscar moving from Chelsea to Shanghai SIPG for about £60m in January and Lukas Jutkiewicz's transfer from Burnley to Birmingham for £1m in early January.
- Numerous players are listed as unattached and set to join different clubs in January.
- Manager movements and current boss updates can be found on the relevant page.
- The page encompasses signings from Premier League, Championship, and Scottish Premiership clubs, as well as selected deals from overseas and the Scottish Championship.

Vincent Ryan, a 25-year-old well-known dissident republican, was shot multiple times and killed while sitting in a car at McKee Road, Finglas, Ireland. His brother, Alan Ryan, was also killed in 2012. Irish police have initiated a murder investigation but are not connecting this incident to a recent gangland feud in the city. A burnt-out vehicle was discovered near the crime scene.

Pippa McManus, a 15-year-old anorexia patient, tragically died by suicide after inadequate care and support following her discharge from The Priory hospital. The Stockport Coroner's Court found that a lack of communication with her family, insufficient care planning, and disjointed agency cooperation were contributing factors to her death. Her parents highlighted the need for quicker and more effective treatment for individuals battling mental illness. The court noted the severity of her condition and the history of self-harm, as well as the absence of necessary mental health support. The family's concerns were reportedly dismissed, revealing systemic failures in the mental health system that failed to ensure Pippa's safety post-discharge.

Camilla is the 11th chancellor of the university, succeeding Lord Wilson of Tillyorn. She recently attended a ceremony at the university, where she presented honorary degrees and will continue to participate in a reception.

The report to the local authority highlights significant declines in secondary pupil numbers over the past 20 years in Dumfries, while primary schools have capacity for 1,400 more children. All four secondary schools are being rebuilt or refurbished, with a new learning hub for over 300 students also being constructed. Caps on intake for Dumfries Academy and Dumfries High School are planned, based on factors to be reviewed annually. The overall secondary school capacity is deemed sufficient for the town's needs. Primary schools will have intake levels set at or above their 20-year averages, except for those relocating. Some primary schools are under a review for low utilization.

Mauricio Pochettino revealed that Tottenham's Dele Alli will be sidelined for a few weeks due to a knee injury sustained in training. Alli will miss the upcoming matches against Arsenal, England's games against Scotland and Spain. Pochettino expressed disappointment at losing the key player but acknowledged that injuries are part of football.

A 25-year-old player, Jón Daði Bodvarsson, has signed a three-year contract with Reading FC, joining them from Wolves. His arrival follows news of Yann Kermorgant's injury. The versatile forward can play in multiple positions and is seen as a valuable addition to the squad by manager Jaap Stam. For more football transfer updates, visit the dedicated page.

Max Verstappen, who was unable to legally drive on his own in Belgium or the Netherlands, passed his driving test at 18. Despite competing in 14 grands prix, he felt pressure during the test but succeeded on his first attempt. Now being able to drive independently, he expressed relief and eagerness to avoid mistakes. Additionally, turning 18 allows him to drink champagne on the podium if he ever achieves that feat.

European leaders gathered in Gdansk for a midnight ceremony commemorating the start of World War II, coinciding with Russia's Victory Parade boycott. Events in Paris, London, Berlin, and Washington also marked the occasion. Poland's President reflected on the war's origins and its aftermath, highlighting the triumph over Nazi Germany and the end of communism. The Gdansk event saw global dignitaries in attendance, including Ukraine's President Poroshenko. Tensions between Russia and the West were evident, with ongoing disputes over Crimea and Ukraine. Despite the Western boycott of Moscow's parade, Russia prepared for its largest military display. Additional ceremonies in Germany, the UK, France, and the US honored the day when Nazi Germany surrendered, marking the end of the war in Europe.

Summary: AFC Bournemouth midfielder Harry Arter and his partner Rachel welcomed their daughter Raine, receiving support and congratulations from the football community on social media. The couple had previously experienced the loss of their daughter Renee in 2015. The term "rainbow baby" was used to describe Raine as a symbol of hope after a previous tragedy. Messages of support came from various clubs and fans, with a touching moment captured between Arter and Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola.

Bradford City defeated Northampton Town 1-0 in a match where James Hanson scored the only goal with a header. The game featured missed opportunities and contentious decisions, including Northampton's disallowed goal and Bradford's penalty appeals. The match also paid tribute to a former Northern Ireland international who passed away recently.

Sean McHugh, 19, was fatally stabbed by a group of teenagers in Anfield on 30 September 2013. Reese O'Shaughnessy, 19, was sentenced to a minimum of 18 years for his role in the murder, along with Andrew Hewitt, 15, Keyfer Dykstra, Corey Hewitt, and Joseph McGill, all 14. The attack was described as "truly wicked" by the judge, who noted that each offender played different roles in the killing. The incident was sparked by a minor dispute between rival gangs, leading to Mr. McHugh's tragic death.

Serial burglar Darren February, 34, denies breaking into Simon Cowell's home in west London while he slept in December 2015. Evidence at Isleworth Crown Court includes February's DNA on a glove and steps at the scene. The forensic expert suggested February may have worn the gloves to steal items before discarding them. However, the expert could not definitively prove February wore the gloves. Other DNA was also found on the items. Prosecutors argue that February's DNA being present at the scene would be unlikely unless he was involved. Witnesses and CCTV footage are being used in the trial to identify February.

Aberdeen defeated Inverness CT 1-0, with Gary Warren inadvertently scoring an own goal off Ash Taylor's shot. Despite missed opportunities from both sides, Aberdeen's win extends their lead over third-placed Rangers. Aberdeen's strong defensive performance saw them maintain a clean sheet streak and move closer to a record points tally. Inverness CT struggled to find their rhythm and remain at risk of relegation. Aberdeen's manager praised the team's consistency, while Inverness CT's manager acknowledged the need for improvement in upcoming matches.

Two victims, Anny Ekofo and her nephew Bervil Ekofo from the Congo, were found wounded at a property in Elmshurst Crescent, East Finchley. Both were pronounced dead. Anny was described as a caring figure, while Bervil was remembered as kind and trouble-free. Family members expressed shock at the tragic event, with Bervil's mother grieving the loss of her "life" and "best friend." The Metropolitan Police's homicide and major crime command unit is investigating the incident, which stirred the neighborhood with a large police and paramedic presence.

Typhoon Phanfone has caused one fatality, with an US airman on Okinawa being washed away by high waves. Thousands of households lost power and Japan's two largest airlines suspended numerous flights. The storm also halted the search for missing individuals following a recent volcanic eruption. Although Phanfone was downgraded from a super typhoon status, it was still considered dangerous by the Japan Meteorological Agency. The storm is expected to weaken as it moves further into the Pacific Ocean. Tokyo experienced heavy rainfall, leading to school closures and flight disruptions, with consequences also seen in various industries and events, including suspension of production in car plants and delay of the Japanese Formula One Grand Prix.

The text discusses a case of sexual abuse within the Jehovah's Witnesses congregation, highlighting the organization's handling of such incidents internally due to their belief in requiring two witnesses to a crime as stated in the Bible. Despite victims coming forward, the elders often ruled that there was insufficient evidence to take action against the abuser. In one case, it took over two decades to bring the abuser to justice, while the Jehovah's Witnesses organization did not impose any punishment. The victims are now pursuing a civil claim against the organization in hopes of prompting policy changes. The text also mentions the organization's reluctance to cooperate with legal authorities and its practice of shunning members who associate with non-members. Additionally, it compares the Jehovah's Witnesses' approach to handling abuse cases with the Roman Catholic Church's previous method of dealing with allegations internally before reforming their child safeguarding policies.

A man was rescued from BG Group's North Everest platform and taken to Aberdeen Royal Infirmary by an offshore rescue helicopter. The Aberdeen Coastguard coordinated the operation after being alerted at 11:30 on a Sunday. The man's current condition is unknown.

The Million Pound Game between Salford Red Devils and Hull KR ended in a dramatic 19-18 win for Salford, saving them from relegation. The game drew criticism for its high stakes and impact on players' mental health. After the emotional victory, Salford's Craig Kopczak expressed empathy for the defeated Hull KR players and their families. Despite the win, Kopczak emphasized the challenges and stress of the game. Now, with Salford secure in Super League, Kopczak is focused on leading Wales in the Rugby League World Cup qualifiers. Wales faces tough matches against Serbia and Italy, with key players unavailable. Kopczak is optimistic about Wales' prospects, aiming to build on their past success.

Summary: Joe Allen scored his first international goal for Wales in their 4-0 win over Moldova during the 2018 World Cup qualifier. The 26-year-old midfielder moved from Liverpool to Stoke City seeking more playing time, impressed by the quality of players at his new club. Allen is looking forward to playing with new signing Wilfried Bony and believes Stoke's ambition matches his own. He is flexible in his playing roles and is eager to contribute to both club and country success.

The drive between the Republican Convention in Cleveland and the Democratic Convention in Philadelphia revealed insights into a growing number of Americans switching party allegiances. A lifelong Republican in Cleveland expressed concerns about Trump's leadership, considering voting for Hillary Clinton. In a run-down town near Cleveland, former Democratic steelworkers disillusioned by lost jobs and opportunities are now supporting Trump for change. In Pennsylvania, a former Democrat and Bernie Sanders supporter is leaning towards the Republican Party due to distrust of Hillary Clinton. On the other hand, a long-time Republican in Lancaster County has canceled her party membership due to concerns about Trump. The unpredictable nature of the upcoming election is evident as voters consider changing their voting habits.

Mr. Kenneth was accused of banging on his girlfriend's door during a row in Dundee, but he denied the allegation. His girlfriend testified in court that she wasn't afraid or alarmed during the incident. The sheriff found Mr. Kenneth not guilty of the charge. Additionally, he was fined £300 for driving without insurance after the incident.

The INTO language skills centre in Newcastle's Haymarket area was evacuated, with a controlled explosion carried out on Newcastle Town Moor. An 18-year-old man was arrested in London. Newcastle University confirmed the campus is open and safe, with no reported injuries or danger to the public. Roads in the area reopened before 01:00 BST. Northumbria Police are investigating, reassuring residents that the controlled explosion was planned. The university serves over 22,000 students and has 1,200 academic staff, with the INTO Centre accommodating over 700 international students across four floors.

Reuben Stretton, 20, has been arrested and charged with the murder of 20-year-old Isaac Williams, who was found injured and later died in hospital. Another man, Devan Garner, 19, has also been charged with the murder, while Charlotte Ford, 22, has been charged with perverting the course of justice. Isaac Williams was described as a quiet and polite young man by friends and family, and tributes have been paid to him by his former coach and the Railwaymen's Boxing Club.

Asda, a supermarket owned by Walmart, reported a decline in like-for-like sales of 5.7% and pre-tax profits dropping nearly 19% to £791.7m due to tough competition in the grocery sector from the big four UK supermarkets and German discounters Aldi and Lidl. Despite efforts by new boss Sean Clarke to implement strategic changes and reduce prices, Asda struggled to regain market share against its competitors. Analysts believe a major turnaround is necessary for Asda to withstand the intense competition in the UK grocery market, as the company has been challenged to differentiate itself effectively and improve its offering.

In Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, a mass prison breakout occurred with drug traffickers and gang members escaping. The system is overwhelmed due to an influx of arrestees from anti-drug cartel efforts. This region has seen numerous escapees since 2010. The key battle is between the Zetas and Gulf cartels for control. Despite efforts, President Calderon's drug war has resulted in high casualties.

"The play, written by Jack Thorne and set 19 years after the final Harry Potter book, has officially opened at the Palace Theatre in London's West End. Audiences are encouraged to keep the secrets of the play, presented in two parts spanning five hours, which follows the original characters as adults. It has received rave reviews for its thrilling stagecraft, original storytelling, and strong performances. Critics praise it as a game-changing production, with one describing it as a 'triumph' and 'superb family entertainment'. Despite some quibbles about the length, the play has been hailed as a magical and spellbinding theatrical endeavor that lives up to expectations."

Yanis Varoufakis criticized the Greek bailout program as a macroeconomic disaster, stating it has already failed. The German parliament approved negotiations for an €86bn bailout in exchange for austerity measures. Greek Prime Minister Tsipras, who has doubts about the bailout, reshuffled his cabinet following dissenting votes. Greece must implement further reforms to secure the bailout, with Jeroen Dijsselbloem warning of challenging negotiations. The European Council approved a €7bn bridging loan for Greece, allowing repayment to the ECB and IMF. Greek banks are set to reopen with a withdrawal limit of €420 per week.

After Germany surrendered in Europe, Japan continued to fight against America and its allies in the Pacific Ocean during World War Two. In an effort to end the war, the Americans dropped atomic bombs on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945. The devastation caused by these bombings resulted in tens of thousands of deaths and widespread destruction. Japan finally surrendered on August 15, 1945, marking the end of the war. The use of atomic bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki sparked debates about the ethical implications of nuclear weapons and their continued existence in the world. Today, some countries possess nuclear weapons, while others advocate for their complete elimination.

During an Education Select Committee session at the University of Oxford, Vice Chancellor Alistair Fitt expressed concerns about the impact of Brexit on the UK's university sector. Universities strongly oppose Brexit due to its negative consequences on research, international partnerships, and access to EU funding. The potential loss of EU students and staff, uncertainty over research collaborations, and financial implications are worrying for higher education institutions. Oxford University has appointed a head of Brexit strategy, emphasizing the seriousness of the situation. There is also discussion about the possibility of higher tuition fees for EU students post-Brexit, but concerns remain about affordability and competition from other countries.

A tragic road accident near Milton Keynes resulted in the deaths of six men and two women in a minibus collision with two lorries. Among the victims were employees of Wipro and minibus owner Cyriac Joseph. Three Wipro employees died, and one was critically injured. The men on the minibus were contracted to work in Nottingham. A memorial service for Mr. Joseph was held in Nottingham. Two men have been charged with causing death by dangerous driving, with one also facing charges for driving over the drink-drive limit. The minibus was carrying passengers from India visiting the UK. The two lorry companies involved expressed sympathies, and investigations are ongoing.

The UK awaits the results of the long-delayed Chilcot enquiry into the events surrounding the 2003 Iraq invasion. There is uncertainty over potentially extending bombing campaigns to Syria against the Islamic State militants. The US and Western allies have been cautious about involvement in Syria, contrasting with their previous actions in Iraq. The role of Ahmed Chalabi in influencing the Iraq invasion is highlighted, as well as the subsequent chaos in Iraq and the rise of Islamic State. The challenges of rebuilding both Iraq and Syria amidst fragmentation are daunting, with millions of refugees and implications for the West.

Jamaica's quartet set a new world record in the 4x100m relay, with Usain Bolt anchoring the team to gold at the London 2012 Olympics. Yohan Blake's exceptional third leg set the stage for Bolt's dramatic finish. Canada initially won bronze but was disqualified, promoting Trinidad and Tobago. Bolt now has six Olympic golds before turning 26. He described the atmosphere as electric and highlighted their desire for improvement. Bolt paid tribute to Mo Farah with a "Mobot" celebration.

The South and Mid Wales Chambers of Commerce president highlighted the importance of steps taken by Wales in response to Brexit, including a business confidence plan and a £5m jobs and growth fund announced by First Minister Carwyn Jones. An extraordinary meeting of the Council for Economic Renewal, involving business leaders and politicians, focused on addressing the impact of the UK's withdrawal from the EU. The Welsh Government aims to reassure businesses and investors, emphasizing continued support, growth, and attracting investments. Key issues such as EU funding, the labour skills gap, and future immigration policies were raised, with plans for enhancing business support, promoting export, apprenticeships, and tourism campaigns. Opposition leader Andrew RT Davies called for a balanced approach, urging diverse voices to be included in discussions about Wales' response to Brexit.

A poll by YouGov found that 56% of Britons would quit the Eurovision competition, with 76% of Leave supporters and 65% of Remain supporters in favor of dropping out. The UK has won Eurovision five times, with the last victory in 1997. Since then, the UK has had three last-place finishes and no top 10 placements in the past seven years. This year, the UK will be represented by Lucie Jones singing "Never Give Up On You", but only 22% of Britons plan to watch the show. Reasons for watching include amusing commentary by Graham Norton (26%), making fun of the show (19%), and liking the music (9%).

The US Department of Defense announced the closure of RAF Mildenhall and two other RAF bases in the UK as part of a cost-saving initiative, resulting in job losses and relocation of personnel. The move is expected to save $500 million annually. The US military will consolidate its presence in Europe, with RAF Lakenheath becoming the sole European base for certain aircraft. Plans for a working group and government support have been put in place to address the impact on the affected communities. The closures are part of a broader strategy to optimize resources and focus on strategic priorities, including shifting attention towards the Asia-Pacific region.

Els Borst, an influential figure in Dutch politics who helped legalize euthanasia in 2001, was found dead under unclear circumstances at her home near Utrecht. Police are investigating whether her death was accidental or a crime, and have ruled out natural causes. Borst, a former minister and medical academic, was described as a pioneer in the field of euthanasia and medical research. Her sudden death has shocked her political colleagues.

Antony Ricketts, 20, was convicted in his absence in Carmarthen for putting non-recyclable waste out in blue bags in Barnsfield Terrace. He was ordered to pay costs of £186.31, a victim surcharge of £20, and was issued a warning by council officers. Ricketts was linked to black bags and contaminated blue recycling bags on multiple occasions. Councillor Jim Jones emphasized that leaving rubbish on the streets for days will not be tolerated and that fines will be imposed on those who do not comply with waste disposal regulations. In line with this, two other individuals from Llanelli were fined previously for similar offenses. Residents are urged to act responsibly to keep streets free from litter.

The International Paralympic Committee (IPC) has initiated proceedings against the National Paralympic Committee of Russia following allegations of a widespread doping program. The IPC will make a decision on any potential ban in August. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has decided against a blanket ban on Russian athletes, leaving individual sports federations to determine their eligibility. IPC President, Sir Philip Craven, criticized the IOC's decision and emphasized the seriousness of the situation, expressing doubt that Russia can uphold anti-doping standards. A report by Canadian law professor Richard McLaren implicated Russia in a state-sponsored doping program and led to the IPC's actions. Russia has the opportunity to appeal any IPC decision within 21 days before the Rio Paralympics in September.

Redcar's RNLI lifeboat rescued three stranded teenagers at East Scar rocks in Saltburn on Saturday. This incident is part of a series of incidents in the area, with a total of 18 people rescued this year. Redcar and Cleveland Council plans to add more warning signs on the beach to alert visitors to the dangers.

Mr Bannon, the former head of Breitbart News, will participate in national security discussions alongside top officials following President Trump's executive order. The National Security Council advises the president on security and foreign affairs, led by retired Lt. Gen. Mike Flynn. The order aims to address evolving security threats by restructuring decision-making processes. Bannon, known for his anti-establishment views, described the mainstream media as the "opposition party." Critics view Breitbart News, where Bannon once worked, as promoting xenophobia and misogyny. Additionally, President Trump ordered a restructuring of the Homeland Security Council in separate measures.

Trisha Boyko "adopted" Jean Jeanie, an eight-year-old Dexter cow, after falling in love with her in a field. Struggling to meet costs, she raised ??3,500 online with the help of donors. Cornish accountant Martin Sands saw the news story and decided to sponsor Jeanie for ??65 a month. Despite not having a particular interest in animals, he was moved by Jeanie's story and decided to support her for at least 12 months. Jeanie, also known as Mooridge Jeanie, now has a loving home and supportive sponsors, including Ms Boyko and Mr Sands.

The government-nominated team consists of Chief negotiator Irfan Siddiqui, journalist Rahimullah Yusufzai, former ambassador Rustam Shah Mohmand, and ex-ISI official Major Mohammad Amir. The Taliban-nominated team includes influential cleric Maulana Sami ul-Haq, Sharia advocate Maulana Abdul Aziz, and former senator Ibrahim Khan. The government team is known for its expertise in Afghan affairs, while the Taliban team comprises individuals with strong religious and political affiliations.

The CIES Football Observatory has compiled a list of players with the most league appearances by year of birth. Tottenham's Dele Alli leads for players born in 1996 or later with 98 games. Premier League players dominate the list compared to other European leagues. Alli narrowly edges out Barcelona's Alen Halolovic and Villarreal's Matias Nahuel. Bournemouth's Simon Francis has the most games among players born in 1985 or later. Romelu Lukaku leads for players born after 1993 with 210 games. Chelsea's Eden Hazard tops the list for players born after 1991. Chelsea manager Guus Hiddink calls for a reduction in fixtures due to player workload, but former Chelsea doctor Ralph Rogers believes it is unrealistic given the market demands for football.

A 23-year-old footballer, who previously played for Sheffield Wednesday and Bradford, made 23 appearances for a National League team last season. Lacey has also been with Altrincham and is now poised to make his Football League debut, expressing his excitement and determination to make the most of this opportunity. For more football transfer news, refer to the dedicated page on the website.

A 24-year-old woman stopped breathing and died during a procedure at a clinic in Bangkok, resulting in a doctor, Sompob Sansiri, being charged with causing her death. The clinic was unlicensed to operate at night, and the Thai Ministry of Health suspended its operation for 60 days while investigating the incident. The Foreign Office stands ready to provide consular assistance, and attempts were made to revive the woman when she stopped breathing under anesthesia during minor corrective surgery on her back.

Rebels launched a rocket attack on an army post in Hakkari province, Turkey, with military jets pursuing them and targeting their escape routes. The interior minister reported that 115 rebels have been killed in a large-scale military offensive over the past two weeks to prevent them from fleeing into northern Iraq. The offensive involves about 2,000 troops and has resulted in casualties on both sides, with six soldiers, two village guards, and 11 Kurdish rebels killed near the village of Gecimili. The PKK, classified as a terrorist organization, has been engaged in clashes with the Turkish armed forces in south-east Turkey, with recent skirmishes leaving several dead.

Stewart Adams, the chief executive of Loganair, announced his departure after joining the company from Tiger Airways in 2013. He will step down in April for personal reasons, and Loganair has begun the search for his successor. Under Adams' leadership, the airline has operated 31 routes across the Highlands and Islands as well as other parts of the UK while flying under Flybe livery. Chairman David Harrison praised Adams for his hard work and strong leadership during his tenure.

Summary:
Renowned figures such as Stephen Hawking, Elon Musk, Bill Gates, and Steve Wozniak have expressed concerns about the potential dangers of artificial intelligence (AI) and warned about the possibility of a future where machines surpass human intelligence. The Centre for the Future of Intelligence in Cambridge aims to address the implications of AI through interdisciplinary research involving philosophers, psychologists, lawyers, and computer scientists. While some, like Professor Hawking, emphasize the transformative power of AI, others, such as Professor Maggie Boden, raise concerns about the current impact of automation on society, particularly in the care of the elderly. The Centre plans to focus on practical research topics, including ethical considerations for autonomous vehicles, societal implications of automation, and the need to balance technological advancements with human welfare.

A 24-year-old player with six seasons at a north London team and experience in the second tier with Bedford Blues has signed with the Exiles. His contract length remains undisclosed, but the director of rugby praised him as a valuable addition due to his Championship experience for the upcoming competitive season.

PC David Rathband was blinded by Raoul Moat in Newcastle in 2010 and later took his own life in 2012. His family believes Northumbria Police failed him and are taking legal action against the force. Rathband survived being shot by Moat but lost his sight. Moat had also shot others before committing suicide. Rathband founded a foundation to help injured emergency workers but ultimately struggled with his blindness and died by suicide. His twin brother highlights the ongoing risks faced by police officers and the family's continued fight for justice.

A fatal attack occurred on Saturday night at a house on Phibsboro Road around 22:30 local time. The victim, a man, was taken to the Mater Hospital and was pronounced dead. A woman in her 40s was arrested in connection with the incident.

Google has initiated legal actions against the London-based firm BT in California, alleging patent violations and has filed a separate case in the UK. BT previously sued Google in 2011, and the dispute remains unresolved. Google has labeled BT's patent claims as meritless and accused the company of arming patent trolls. In response, Google has filed counterclaims against BT for patent infringement. The two companies are scheduled for a mediation hearing in July in Delaware regarding the 2011 case.

Juventus secured a 3-0 victory over Cagliari, with goals from Mario Mandzukic, Paulo Dybala, and Gonzalo Higuain. Buffon made his 620th league appearance, saving a penalty from Diego Farias with VAR assistance. The win puts Juventus closer to their seventh consecutive Serie A title. Key moments included Dybala's missed shot and Higuain's goal assisted by Alex Sandro. Stephan Lichtsteiner received a yellow card during the match, and several substitutions were made by both teams.

Leicester Tigers took a commanding 21-0 lead against Northampton Saints, with tries from Smith, McCaffrey, and Williams. Despite a fightback from Saints with tries from Harrison, North, and Gibson, Tigers managed to claim a last-minute victory with a kick from Burns. The return of Tuilagi, who had been out since 2014 due to injury, contributed to their win. Leicester's director of rugby praised his team's resilience, while Northampton's director of rugby expressed disappointment at their slow start. The match ended in a 30-27 victory for Leicester Tigers.

A serious car crash in Birmingham involved a black Vauxhall Astra and a red Ford Fiesta, resulting in a two-year-old boy and a pregnant woman sustaining injuries. The driver of the Astra fled the scene, and the woman sadly suffered a miscarriage as a result of the collision. Another child, a four-year-old boy, had minor injuries. Police are seeking witnesses to the crash and urging the driver to come forward.

British tennis player Watson won her second WTA tour title in Hobart, climbing to a career-high 38th in the world rankings. She heads to the Australian Open after not dropping a set all week, facing Tsvetana Pironkova in the first round. Watson, who battled illness and coaching changes, credited coach Diego Veronelli for her success. She defeated Brengle in the final after overcoming service struggles and tough conditions, expressing confidence in her performance and mental strength.

More than 7,000 children and adolescents in Scotland had their mental health referrals rejected last year, prompting concerns from the Scottish Association for Mental Health (SAMH). The charity emphasized the need for prompt action to address this issue, as many young people are currently waiting for help and support. There are also concerns about the missed waiting time target for specialist mental health treatment, with the latest statistics showing that a significant number of patients are not being seen within the required timeframe. The Scottish government has committed to reviewing rejected referrals and improving the mental health system, but there are calls for swift and thorough action to provide timely support to those in need.

Kromtech, the company responsible for MacKeeper, has confirmed a data breach exposing customers' names, internet addresses, and login credentials. However, payment details were apparently unaffected. The breach was brought to their attention by a security expert and steps were taken to address the issue immediately. Security researcher Chris Vickery discovered the exposed data, totaling 21 gigabytes, using Shodan. Initially, Kromtech stated that 13 million customer details were compromised but later clarified that the number included both active and non-active users. MacKeeper, a software promoted for Mac computer optimization, has faced criticism for potentially slowing down and causing system issues. Kromtech denies these claims, stating that the program cannot harm the system.

Hooper, 34, retired from playing rugby after a career that included stints at Saracens, Yorkshire Carnegie, and Bath, where he made 138 Premiership appearances. He will now transition to a coaching role as a part of Todd Blackadder's backroom team. Rock, 31, who was previously the academy director at Yorkshire Carnegie, will also be joining the coaching staff.

John Edward Bates, a 67-year-old man formerly from Spalding, Lincolnshire, now living in London, is facing 22 charges, including two counts of indecency with a child allegedly committed between March 1972 and October 1989. Bates denies all charges. The prosecution claims that four male complainants accused Bates of sexual abuse during his time as a scout leader in South Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire. The prosecutor stated that Bates invited one boy to his home, showed him pornographic films, and sexually abused him. Another boy was taken to London by Bates and later abused. Two boys from the Spalding group also made similar complaints. Bates, who served in the RAF and as a Lincolnshire Police officer, denies the allegations. The trial is ongoing and is expected to last for two weeks.

British Formula 1 team Manor Marussia has secured investment from Stephen Fitzpatrick of Ovo, with former Sainsbury's boss Justin King joining as interim chairman. The team is confident in its competitiveness and has announced driver Will Stevens, with another to be confirmed soon. The new car must pass crash tests before the season opener in Melbourne. Graeme Lowdon remains as president and sporting director, expressing optimism for the upcoming season under new leadership.

Three players - Oxford, Mutch, and Grabban - have joined a Championship side on loan until the end of the season. Oxford, 18, made his debut for West Ham at 16 and signed a new long-term deal with his parent club in December. Mutch, 25, has played eight times for Crystal Palace this season, while Grabban, 29, has made six appearances. All three players are potential additions for their new team's upcoming match against Ipswich. For more football transfer news, visit the dedicated page or the Premier League tracker.

Former Wham! star Andrew Ridgeley criticized Channel 5's documentary, The Last Days of George Michael, for being "insensitive, contemptuous, and reprehensible." The broadcaster defended the show, stating it was a "measured account" of Michael's life and death. Ridgeley, a friend of Michael, believed the programme should have been aired after the singer's funeral as a mark of respect. Despite backlash from fans and Ridgeley, Channel 5 maintained that the documentary was based on contributions from those who knew him. Michael passed away on Christmas Day due to heart and liver disease. Fans criticized the programme on Twitter, calling it "pathetic" and "disrespectful."

Dover District Councillor Bob Frost made comments about black people during an online conversation about the recent riots, apologizing and deleting the posts afterwards. Deputy Council Leader Sue Chandler condemned the language and suspended Frost from the Conservative Group pending investigation. Frost's remarks were perceived as racist and offensive, with the chair of equality charity Afiya Trust expressing disappointment in his position of power. Frost acknowledged his mistake, expressing deep regret for causing offense.

A recent study published in the Lancet suggests that the diabetes drug exenatide may halt the progression of Parkinson's disease by helping brain cells work more efficiently or survive. While the trial showed promising results in stabilizing patients, researchers emphasize the need for further testing to confirm long-term benefits. Although current medications manage symptoms, they do not prevent brain cell death in Parkinson's. The University College London team is cautiously optimistic about the potential of exenatide as a breakthrough treatment but stresses the importance of further research before recommending it for widespread use.

Shadow Europe minister Pat Glass made inappropriate comments after an interview in Sawley, Derbyshire, where she referred to a constituent as a "horrible racist." She later apologized for her remarks, acknowledging the validity of concerns about immigration. Criticism came from UKIP and Brexit campaigners, with accusations of contempt for ordinary people's concerns. Various politicians from different parties weighed in, with some calling for a full apology and others highlighting the sensitivities around immigration issues. The incident drew parallels to previous controversies involving Labour politicians making divisive comments. Shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper defended Glass's apology while criticizing false promises from Leave campaigners regarding changes to migration policy post-Brexit.

In the Champions League, qualification remains uncertain heading into the final matches as Al Ahly secures their first win by defeating leaders Wydad Casablanca. Zamalek's loss prompts the resignation of their coach and the suspension of their captain. Sundowns' victory over Zamalek sees them top Group B, while Enyimba and Zamalek will battle for the remaining spot in the last four. In Group A, Zesco United's draw with Asec Mimosas and Al Ahly's surprise win over Wydad Casablanca keep the group open, with all four teams still in contention for the semi-finals.
Request for suggestions for investigations or topics of interest from the audience to potentially generate news stories.

Former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has been freed from detention after being cleared of involvement in killing protesters during the country's uprising. Mubarak, a former general and close ally of the United States, has returned home to his family's property in Heliopolis, eastern Cairo. Many Egyptians view the Mubarak era as a period of relative calm and prosperity amidst the political and economic turmoil that followed. While some celebrate his release, there is also criticism and disappointment among those who sacrificed during the 2011 revolution, as they feel justice has not been served. The current political landscape in Egypt under President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi remains contentious, with many activists silenced or detained.

The Great Tapestry of Scotland, the world's largest embroidered tapestry, is currently on display at Stirling Castle's Great Hall until 8 March. The tapestry spans 469ft long and features scenes from Scottish history, including the Battle of Bannockburn and Andy Murray's Wimbledon win. It consists of 160 hand-embroidered panels and uses 300 miles of yarn. Visitors can explore Scotland's history through the tapestry, which is a significant piece of art attracting over 200,000 viewers on its national tour.

A letter from major banking organizations warns of significant consequences from Brexit on jobs in the financial industry and beyond, highlighting the potential impact on global trade and employment. The letter emphasizes the importance of maintaining existing trade ties for economic prosperity and calls for a smooth transition period. Concerns over uncertainty and volatility in global markets since the UK's Brexit vote are also highlighted. Exit negotiations between the UK and the EU have not yet begun, adding to business uncertainty, with substantive talks expected to start after 2017.

The Welsh government agreed on the destination of a nearly £39m stimulus package as part of the budget deal with the Liberal Democrats to benefit the economy. The money, to be spent over two years, is a result of a council tax freeze in England and will fund projects such as apprenticeships, school building upgrades, housing, and road improvements in enterprise zones. Opposition parties have criticized the allocation, with Plaid Cymru deeming it inadequate and Conservatives suggesting it should benefit council tax payers. Labour defended its spending plans, noting that it aims to boost the economy and public services.

The GMB union members voted in favor of a deal regarding pension scheme changes at Diageo, while Unite members rejected it. Industrial action was planned at Diageo sites in Scotland, Northern Ireland, and Cheshire. Following talks, a deal was reached with GMB members supporting it, but Unite members did not. Diageo awaits confirmation from Unite on their stance. The company stated the need for sustainable pensions due to escalating costs. Discussions are ongoing with unions to address the proposal. Diageo operates numerous distilleries and brands in Scotland.

The Great North Air Ambulance Service (GNAAS) launched a blood transfusion scheme in 2015, leading to 60 transfusions performed by medics. A third of these were critical for survival, with overall positive outcomes for many patients. Dr. Rachel Hawes, inspired by her military experiences, spearheaded the initiative to address traumatic bleeding. Blood is delivered to helicopters daily by volunteers, aiding mainly road traffic accident victims. Newcastle's Royal Victoria Infirmary received most cases, followed by James Cook University Hospital and Royal Preston Hospital.

After Brexit, London's financial district, known as "The City," plays a crucial role in euro clearing, handling 75% of all euro transactions globally. Euro clearing is a process that centralizes transactions through a third party to reduce risk and costs. If euro clearing moves from London to the EU, it could cost an additional 77 billion euros and result in the loss of over 80,000 UK jobs. The EU is seeking greater control over clearing in London, potentially pushing business to New York instead. This shift could weaken Europe's financial power globally, prompting warnings about the consequences of disrupting growth and financial stability from Chancellor Philip Hammond.

A deceased woman in her 50s was discovered at a residence on Holmfield Avenue. Three individuals, Mohammed Member, Shafiq Member, and Fatima Patel, all residents of the same avenue, have been remanded in custody. Formal identification of the deceased is pending. More updates on this story can be expected from Leicestershire.

Following the tragic death of five-year-old Tyler Whelan in 2011, a Serious Case Review was conducted on the department involved. Ofsted had previously identified issues but later observed rapid improvements and no children were deemed at risk. The council invested in additional social workers, reducing caseloads and improving the overall service. The case highlighted missed intervention opportunities, leading to enhancements in the system. Despite ongoing concerns about maintaining investments due to budget cuts, improvements in child safety procedures were acknowledged by council members and inspectors.

Summary:
- Wales defeated Argentina 24-20 in a rugby match at the Principality Stadium.
- In a football qualifier, Chris Coleman's team drew 1-1 with Serbia at Cardiff City Stadium.
- Trains between Cardiff and Swansea are now running as usual after earlier disruptions.
- Various streets in Cardiff were closed from 15:30 to 20:30 due to the events.
- Cardiff council advised on busy train services and extra capacity on certain lines post 21:30.
- Certain train stations are designated for specific destinations after the matches.
- Buses in the city center will be diverted to different areas for ease of travel.
- St Mary Street taxi rank was closed temporarily, but the Mill Lane rank remained open.

The BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme featured personal stories of individuals who grew up with addicted parents. Josh Connolly's father was an alcoholic, leading Josh to struggle with anger and shame, eventually developing his own issues with alcohol. Jade Bailey witnessed her father's descent into heroin addiction, feeling abandoned and questioning her father's love for her. Sarah, raised by an alcoholic father, had to walk away when his drinking changed their relationship, leading her to feel stronger but anxious around drunk individuals. These experiences highlight the lasting impact of parental addiction on children.

The Rushden Lakes development, set to open in spring 2017, will include a 12-screen cinema, a bowling alley, a climbing structure, a cycle hire business, and restaurants. Despite objections from local councils concerned about the impact on town centers, the plans were ultimately approved by the East Northamptonshire District Council planners. The project has faced criticism for potentially drawing shoppers away from nearby towns like Kettering, Corby, Northampton, and Bedford. The main shopping complex, approved in 2014, is currently under construction.

The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) has announced that the UK Anti-Doping Agency (Ukad) will oversee drug-testing in Russia as long as the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (Rusada) remains non-compliant with anti-doping regulations. Rusada was declared non-compliant due to doping allegations, leading to Russian athletes being banned from international competitions. The ban will continue until Russia demonstrates significant changes in its anti-doping practices. Ukad will coordinate testing with sport federations in Russia, and an independent body will manage results oversight by Wada.

Sunderland's 10-season stay in the top flight ended with their relegation after a 1-0 defeat to Bournemouth and Hull City's draw with Southampton. Manager David Moyes faces pressure to step down, with chairman Ellis Short apologizing for mistakes and pledging to improve on and off the field. Moyes acknowledged the lack of quality supply to top scorer Jermain Defoe and the team's struggles to score. Various injuries and recruitment issues have contributed to the team's downfall, with media pundits criticizing management decisions.

Former Tory prime minister Sir John Major criticized the UK government's approach towards the EU, warning of substantial costs and a lack of charm in negotiations. He believes Brexit will be a historic mistake and expressed concern about the UK's diminished diplomatic influence and relationship with the US. Sir John called for Parliament to have a significant role in shaping Brexit negotiations and urged for a more diplomatic approach to protect the UK's interests. He cautioned against inflated expectations and criticized the lack of goodwill in talks, emphasizing the need for statesmanship.

In Glasgow's Sighthill area, a police officer engaged with a driver of a red Vauxhall Astra who suddenly reversed the car and fled on foot after stopping on Alford Street. Despite the incident, the officer was unharmed and returned to duty. Police Scotland is actively investigating, and the Scottish Police Federation is informed.

Hafren Power is proposing a £25bn project to build an 11-mile barrage between Wales and England, aiming to generate clean energy and promote economic regeneration. The largest shareholder, Richard Bazley, and another founder, Idwal Stedman, have been declared bankrupt multiple times. Despite this, they believe their past should not undermine the legitimacy of the project. Supporters claim the barrage could provide 5% of Britain's electricity and create jobs, while opponents raise concerns about environmental impact. The project requires UK government support, with detailed proposals still pending.

The Sustainability and Transformation Plan for Buckinghamshire, Berkshire, and Oxfordshire includes a review of community services by Oxfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group, with potential changes to community hospitals. The Green Party raised concerns that community hospitals could be replaced by hubs, expressing worries about lack of information and significant budget cuts. Plans for community hospitals will be detailed after May, with proposed changes subject to consultation. Oxfordshire CCG faces a projected funding gap of £200m by 2020, reflecting broader financial pressures in the NHS.

Since 2005, Simmons & Simmons has offered flexible working, with one partner working from home on Wednesday mornings and having the rest of the day off. The CBI advocates for firms to promote flexible working in job ads to improve diversity in hiring. They suggest removing candidates' names from applications to reduce bias. Companies, like Simmons & Simmons, have seen success with flexible working policies, leading to increased employee engagement and productivity. The CBI emphasizes the benefits of inclusive workplaces, as diverse teams can make better decisions and ultimately drive business growth.

In a proposed scheme, upfront relief for savers worth £21bn would be scrapped to make pension pot withdrawals tax free. An alternative flat rate tax relief option was considered but deemed unpopular. Critics argue that the Chancellor missed an opportunity to tackle pension inequality and help lower-income individuals. Supporters believe maintaining existing reliefs is sensible to avoid new risks and administrative burdens. The decision not to announce changes to pension tax relief has drawn mixed reactions, with some expressing disappointment and others advocating for stability in pensions policy. Former Liberal Democrat pensions minister Steve Webb supports the decision for stability to encourage long-term saving.

British sprinters coached by Rana Reider and Steve Fudge have experienced clashes with their coaches and among themselves due to competitive rivalries. The tension has affected the relay team prospects for the Commonwealth Games and European Championships. Richard Kilty, who won gold at the World Indoor Championships, aims to resolve these differences for relay team success. Despite ongoing friction, Kilty sees the potential to challenge top sprinting nations like Jamaica and the USA by combining the best talents from both groups. James Dasaolu and Adam Gemili, key members, will miss the World Relay Championships due to injury and exams.

John Lumsden Donaldson, a businessman in Spain, experienced a ransomware attack on his auction company, which forced him to shut down operations. His son, a computer programmer, helped resolve the issue by identifying the attack and advising against paying the ransom. The attackers did not access customer data but targeted the company's servers in Spain through a backdoor in Windows Server. Despite efforts to resolve the issue, lingering problems persist due to the use of older Windows software.

Economic nationalists, movement conservatives, and working-class supporters have differing perspectives on the US withdrawal from the Paris agreement. President Trump's daughter and key advisors advocated for staying in the agreement for environmental, diplomatic, and national security reasons. Despite initial skepticism about climate change, Trump's decision is seen as a move to prioritize American economic interests, jobs, and reducing government regulation, while potentially fueling discontent among international critics and domestic liberals.

The inter-departmental ministerial group on human trafficking reported an increase in the number of victims detected last year, with trafficking gangs in China, Vietnam, Nigeria, and eastern Europe posing the biggest threat to the UK. Better coordination between government departments and international authorities is emphasized, while anti-slavery groups criticize government shortcomings in combating the issue. The police conduct regular raids to uncover potential trafficking situations, with cases ranging from labor exploitation to illegal organ removal. Despite improvements in identifying victims, there remains a significant number who do not come forward due to fear of deportation. The report highlights instances of child trafficking for criminal activities and the involvement of organized crime groups in human trafficking in the UK.

The final annual report from the Independent Monitoring Board for HMP Birmingham highlighted low staff morale during the privatisation process, with G4S Care and Justice Services taking over the prison after delays. The IMB welcomed the new owner and anticipated innovations. The process from announcement to handover was considered lengthy, with concerns about the impact on staff and inmates. The report praised prison staff for managing challenges like gang culture. Recommendations include faster processes and learning from Birmingham's experience. The Ministry of Justice emphasized the need for quality and efficiency improvements in public services and public safety.

The UK government is debating a Welfare Benefits Uprating Bill that would cap benefit rises to 1% for three years starting next April to reduce the deficit. The coalition argues it's fair given public sector pay caps and private sector pay rises below inflation, while Labour opposes it as a cut to working people's support. Some Lib Dem MPs may rebel, but the coalition is expected to win. The bill affects various benefits and tax credits, aiming to save £2.8bn. The debate reflects differing views on who should bear the financial burden, with accusations of denial and contempt from both sides.

Vincent Enyeama, Lille's first-choice goalkeeper since 2013, has extended his contract with the club, expressing happiness and gratitude for the opportunity to continue playing with them. Despite receiving offers from other clubs, Enyeama values the family atmosphere at Lille and is committed to bringing success to the supporters. With numerous clean sheets this season, the club officials are pleased to secure Enyeama's services, highlighting his exceptional qualities on and off the field. The 33-year-old's presence is seen as crucial for the club's progression and the development of young goalkeeper Mike Maignan.

Here is a summary of some of the most memorable moments from various MTV Video Music Awards (VMAs) over the years:

- Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swift's acceptance speech, sparking a feud with Beyonce and Taylor's eventual return to the stage.
- Britney Spears performed with a python, later regretting the decision.
- Lady Gaga accepted an award in a raw beef dress to protest the military's policies.
- Beyonce announced her pregnancy in a dramatic fashion after a performance.
- Madonna's groundbreaking 1984 performance set a standard for future VMA acts.
- Britney Spears shed her innocent image with a revealing outfit during her 2000 performance.
- Nicki Minaj and Miley Cyrus had a public feud at the VMAs, leading to a tense on-stage moment.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and airlines like Qantas and Virgin Australia have advised against turning on or charging Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phones during flights due to safety concerns related to battery problems causing the devices to catch fire. Samsung has issued a global recall and is expediting the shipment of replacement phones. There have been reports of incidents involving the phone catching fire, leading to precautionary measures being taken by aviation authorities and airlines. Airlines in the US will make individual decisions regarding the use of the Note 7 on board. Samsung's shares have dropped following these developments.

First Minister Arlene Foster and Sinn Féin are at odds over the terms of an independent inquiry into the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scandal in Northern Ireland. Foster announced that terms were agreed upon with the attorney general, but Sinn Féin's Conor Murphy deemed them insufficient. Sinn Féin is calling for a robust, transparent, time-framed investigation led by a senior judicial figure from outside the jurisdiction with the power to compel witnesses and subpoena documents. They are also demanding Foster's temporary stepping aside pending the investigation. The RHI scheme, initiated in 2012, aimed to promote renewable heat sources but ended up being significantly over budget due to excessive subsidies and oversubscription by businesses.

Wilfried Bony left Swansea for Manchester City in 2015 for £28m, managing 8 goals in 46 appearances. Currently on loan at Stoke, a possible return to Swansea hinges on the future of top scorer Fernando Llorente, who is sought by Chelsea. Swansea may consider Bony as insurance if Llorente departs. With Tammy Abraham on loan and Borja Baston away, Swansea could face a shortage of forwards. Bony, formerly Swansea's record signing, scored 34 goals for them. His return may have been hindered by his high wages at City, but Swansea could gain funds from Gylfi Sigurdsson's possible move to Everton.

Red Bull Racing's team principal, Christian Horner, confirmed that Daniel Ricciardo will be in the car next season with a fixed contract, while the team has all options with Daniil Kvyat. Speculations about Max Verstappen joining the senior team have been quelled. Red Bull's engine supplier for 2016 is uncertain following failed negotiations with Renault and rejection by Mercedes and Ferrari. Red Bull may continue with Renault engines under a different name. There are talks with Honda for a potential supply, but McLaren's veto has blocked this option. Toro Rosso is expected to use 2015 Ferrari engines in the upcoming season. Renault is likely to take control of Lotus and return as a team owner and constructor.

The article discusses the remarkable career of rugby legend Dan Carter, highlighting his unique playing style and enduring influence on the sport. Despite the increasing physical demands of modern rugby, Carter has maintained his success through his strategic approach, exceptional skills, and understated demeanor. Known for his precise technique and calm presence on the field, Carter's impact extends beyond his impressive statistics and accolades. His humility, work ethic, and ability to excel in high-pressure situations have earned him admiration from peers and fans alike.

Extra patrols have been deployed in response to a surge in anti-social behavior linked to the drug Spice in Manchester's city center. This synthetic drug can induce severe effects such as hallucinations and aggression, leading to a strain on public services. The Greater Manchester force is collaborating with various agencies to address the issue, with calls for stronger enforcement and addiction support. Officials express concern over the escalating problem and seek national attention to prevent its spread. Daniel Gerrard highlights the need for stricter drug classification and increased addiction treatment resources.

The 2016 BBC Proms season closed with a unique virtual orchestra involving 1,200 performers, a high-pitched rendition of Rule Britannia by tenor Juan Diego Florez, and an attempt to hijack the tradition of flag-waving for political reasons. The event featured international musicians conducted by Sakari Oramo and included works by various composers. Despite political tensions, the concert aimed to unite through music. The season concluded with traditional British anthems and concerts held in different locations across the UK, showcasing a variety of musicians and performers. Additionally, young talent was highlighted, such as 13-year-old Gwydion Rhys conducting the BBC National Orchestra of Wales.

Summary: Celtic's new signing, 21-year-old midfielder Ntcham, revealed that fellow Frenchman Dembele's positive feedback about the club influenced his decision to sign a four-year contract. Ntcham hopes to follow in Dembele's footsteps and succeed in Scottish football. He prioritizes playing regular first-team football, which led him to choose Celtic over staying in England's top flight. Manager Brendan Rodgers played a key role in convincing Ntcham to join the squad. Ntcham emphasizes his physical and technical attributes as a player and looks forward to adapting to the new challenge.

Engineers from Network Rail and Thames Water are addressing a collapsed sewer causing a hole in Forest Hill, disrupting rail services until Wednesday. Repair work involves sealing the sewer and filling the hole with concrete and ballast. Services are affected between East Croydon and London Bridge, West Croydon/Crystal Palace and New Cross Gate. The complex repair work aims to prevent sewer flooding for local residents. Frustration mounts among passengers, with disruptions also affecting other London routes due to high temperatures. Southern services to Brighton are impacted by a track failure. The ongoing Southern trains' cancellations and delays due to an RMT dispute add to commuter woes. Rail minister Paul Maynard will provide evidence on the issue before the Transport Select Committee on Wednesday.
