Ilkeston in Derbyshire is one of the largest towns in the UK without a rail station, as its previous one closed in 1967 due to Dr Beeching's cuts. A new station off Millership Way is due to open later this year after facing delays caused by the need to trap and relocate protected newts found on site. Additional setbacks included foundation work taking longer than expected and flooding concerns. Despite frustrations from local officials and the transport secretary, work is progressing with plans to dismantle the old bridge and open the station for services to Chesterfield, Sheffield, Leeds, and Nottingham, with 160,000 passengers expected annually.

A deliberate arson attack took place at Bishopbriggs Cultural Centre on November 17, 2015, causing significant damage. The suspect, captured on CCTV, is described as being approximately 5ft 10in tall, wearing a blue tracksuit, a hat with a luminous rear band, and dark shoes. Police are appealing for information to identify the individual responsible for the fire.

The "You Stink" campaign in Lebanon continues its efforts despite postponing a demonstration after clashes between protesters and police. Prime Minister Tammam Salam has warned of a looming collapse due to political dysfunction, specifically highlighting the unresolved garbage crisis as a symptom of broader issues such as corruption and sectarianism. The protests demand government action to address not only the rubbish problem but also the underlying political system. The country's political deadlock stems from divisions between major political blocs and regional influences. With ongoing public pressure, the campaign pushes for change while calling for peaceful demonstrations and reevaluation of demands.

Fox Norton, trained by Colin Tizzard and ridden by Robbie Power, won the Punchestown Champion Chase by a length and three quarters over Un De Sceaux and God's Own. The victory marked Power's seventh Grade One win of the season. Tizzard praised Power's tactics and Fox Norton's consistency, hinting at a possible step up in trip for the horse. Willie Mullins noted that the faster pace didn't suit Un De Sceaux. The win also contributed to Mullins narrowing the gap with Gordon Elliott in the trainers' championship. Power's success and the impressive performance of Fox Norton were highlighted by BBC's horse racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght.

The article discusses the anticipation surrounding track and field events at the upcoming Olympics, highlighting British athletes like Mo Farah and Dai Greene, as well as Caster Semenya and Usain Bolt. It emphasizes the diverse nature of athletics with a variety of disciplines and provides insights into the physical demands and benefits of the sport. Additionally, it encourages participation in athletics through local clubs and resources offered by the UK Athletics Grassroots scheme and UKA Academy.

The EIS union is considering industrial action at their annual general meeting due to unresolved workload issues facing teachers, with concerns about long working hours and potential strike action being discussed. The union is also calling for a fair pay deal without detrimental changes to conditions of service. The Scottish government is working with stakeholders to address workload concerns and has made commitments to support teacher numbers and educational quality. Other motions at the conference include calls to investigate teacher shortages and condemn budget cuts in Scottish education.

The urgency is to keep trying emergency phone numbers due to low mobile phone batteries. Experts mention challenges in verifying information from social media posts. Individuals are tweeting their addresses for rescue, but not all requests may be genuine or spotted. Social media advisor Euan Semple emphasizes the need to discern signal from noise online. Persuading people to follow Coast Guard advice may be difficult in extreme situations. A care home was rescued after a viral Twitter image, and Facebook activated safety check-in for Texas residents.

Bow Street station on the Cambrian line in Wales, which was closed in 1965, may be reopened with funding sought by the Welsh Government. The government is requesting £6.8m from the UK government to cover three quarters of the cost for the new station, with the remaining 25% to be funded by Wales. The project aims to improve economic activity in the area, particularly with the opening of a new university campus nearby. The new station is expected to reduce traffic, promote businesses, improve transport for commuters and the elderly, and enhance connectivity to Aberystwyth and beyond. The proposal includes plans for a new train station, interchange, car parking, and bus stops. A decision on the funding application is expected in early 2017, and if approved, the station could open in 2019. Additionally, there are hopes to reopen Carno station on the same railway line, which closed in 1963.
A diverse collection of photos from various locations in Africa captured this week.

Anthony Fuggle, a former classics master at Colet Court in London, admitted to possessing and making indecent images of children. He had over 1,000 images of children and was found with almost 2,000 more, some depicting very young children in various explicit scenarios. Fuggle, who also worked at St Paul's Preparatory School, had four serious charges left on file after pleading not guilty. He appeared in court and is due for sentencing in June, while also undergoing therapy. Fuggle is on bail with strict conditions, and the case is part of an investigation into historical abuse at St Paul's and Colet Court through Operation Winthorpe.

In a match where Everton initially frustrated City with a well-organized defense, substitute Mario Balotelli broke the deadlock with a deflected shot, showcasing City's patience and persistence. James Milner added a second goal late in the game, securing City's victory and top position in the Premier League. Everton's defensive tactics were solid but lacked attacking threat, with controversies surrounding refereeing decisions. City demonstrated maturity and creativity, with Silva's influence leading to the final goal by Milner. City's win highlighted their title-contending potential and ability to overcome tough opposition like Everton.

AMC CEO Adam Aron's suggestion to allow mobile phone use in cinemas to attract millennials was met with backlash on social media. However, after receiving negative feedback, the company decided to scrap the idea. AMC acknowledged the audience's disapproval and confirmed that texting will not be allowed in any of their theaters. Film fans welcomed the decision, expressing gratitude for listening to their feedback. Critics of the initial proposal called it a "horrible idea" that never should have been considered publicly.

Pope Francis used his Easter message to call for peace in troubled regions worldwide, including specific mentions of Syria, the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. He emphasized the importance of turning hatred into love, vengeance into forgiveness, and war into peace. The Pope chose not to deliver greetings in multiple languages and instead focused on interactions with the crowd, showcasing his humility and down-to-earth nature. Additionally, he touched on the challenges faced in various regions, such as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, violence in Iraq and Syria, and the need for reconciliation in Asia. The Pope's message resonated with a global audience, urging for unity and compassion in a world still marred by greed and selfishness.

Cheshire East Council has apologized for deliberate data manipulation in air quality readings from 2012 to 2014, which may have impacted planning decisions in several areas. The falsified data was found to be significantly different from the original readings, leading to concerns about the assessment of new developments. Cheshire Police is investigating potential crimes, with auditors suggesting human error was unlikely to be responsible. The council has taken steps to address the issue, and Defra is monitoring the situation closely.

Twitter has updated its rules to combat cyberbullying and extremism by clarifying what constitutes abusive behavior and hateful conduct. The company promises to suspend or close accounts that engage in abusive behavior and has introduced new protections, such as tools for reporting abuse and a ban on promoting terrorism. Pressure is mounting on social media platforms to address these issues, with the UK government considering new surveillance powers to unmask cyberbullies. Twitter has faced criticism in the past for its handling of online abuse, but the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC) welcomed the new rules as a long-overdue step in combating cyberbullying.

The event "Shifting the Curve - Sharing the Challenge" aims to address the stagnant breastfeeding rates in Scotland over the past decade. Data shows a slight increase in breastfeeding rates for babies at ten days old, but a decline by the six to eight week stage. The focus is on increasing breastfeeding rates in deprived areas to reduce health inequalities. Experts will discuss the benefits of breastfeeding, strategies for improvement, and the importance of educating mothers on its health benefits. Public health minister Maureen Watt stresses the importance of promoting breastfeeding for both mother and baby. A recent study by Unicef suggests that increasing breastfeeding duration could save the NHS money. The summit will take place on 24 February at Murrayfield Stadium in Edinburgh.

Royal College of Physicians president Prof Jane Dacre will caution the government about the growing issue of unfilled medical positions and gaps in rotas affecting patient care. The ongoing dispute with junior doctors over weekend care plans has led to thousands going on strike. Prof Dacre will express concerns at the RCP's conference, citing struggles of NHS trusts in finding sufficient staff. Research indicates that a significant number of consultant physician positions remain vacant, leading to gaps in junior doctor rotas. The shortage of trainees and consultants raises uncertainties about implementing a safe seven-day service. Prof Dacre will advocate for increased funding, given hospitals' deficits and lagging funding compared to other countries. The Department of Health mentioned investing £8bn more by 2020 to support a safe NHS seven days a week.

A new study conducted by two London universities, led by PhD student Georgie Bruinvels, found that 41.7% of female athletes reported their menstrual cycle affecting their performance. Nearly 44% had heavy menstrual bleeding, but only 22.3% sought help. Bruinvels aims to raise awareness and further research on this topic to better support female athletes.

President Duterte is working towards achieving peace in a conflict with the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) and its armed wing, the New People's Army (NPA). The insurgency, which began in the 1960s, aims to overthrow the government through guerrilla warfare. Despite previous talks and unilateral ceasefires, a lasting peace deal has been elusive. Mr Duterte has taken steps to revive the peace process, including offering confidence-building measures such as releasing high-ranking rebels from prison. Talks have been ongoing, with the next round scheduled for January. However, disagreements over issues like amnesty for detained rebels and social and economic reforms are posing challenges to the negotiation process.

A 22-year-old player released by Accrington Stanley has become Morecambe's third new signing this summer. Morecambe boss Jim Bentley praised the player's attitude and expressed excitement to work with him. Stay updated on the latest football transfers on the dedicated page.

The Powys council is facing a £1.6m loss over three years, impacting the affordability of classes and prompting a review of the financial viability and educational sustainability of its sixth forms. The Welsh government is collaborating with Powys to mitigate the impact of learning cuts. Following a previous review, the council decided not to close any sixth forms but recently approved the takeover of John Beddoes School, reducing the number of sixth forms in the county. Declining pupil numbers and funding changes are affecting learner choice and class availability. Strong representations have been made to the Welsh government about funding concerns. The Welsh government acknowledges financial challenges and is working to minimize the impact on learning. Controversial plans to save £20m in Powys have been approved, resulting in the loss of around 400 posts.

Nicola Sturgeon reported to MSPs that a target to reduce six week delays in discharging patients had been achieved, but Labour criticized her for not meeting this target for over three years. Delayed discharge, also known as bed blocking, occurs when patients remain in hospitals despite being medically fit for discharge due to a lack of care services. Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale highlighted the high number of days patients spent unnecessarily in hospital, calling the situation unacceptable. Sturgeon defended her remarks on meeting the target in the past, stating that progress was being made while acknowledging more work is needed. Critics, including Dr. Richard Simpson, disputed Sturgeon's claims, citing missed targets and high numbers of patients facing delayed discharge. Sturgeon emphasized reductions in various delay categories and a focus on discharging patients within 72 hours. Overall, there are ongoing challenges and discrepancies regarding the handling of patient discharges in Scotland.

In a recent meeting, OPEC members, led by Saudi Arabia, affirmed their commitment to maintaining a stable oil market. Brent crude prices rose slightly after US crude stockpiles decreased, with Saudi Arabia pledging to avoid flooding the market with excess production. Despite failing to cap output earlier, OPEC remains a significant player in global oil markets. Mohammed Sanusi Barkindo from Nigeria was appointed as OPEC's new secretary-general, resolving a longstanding dispute between Saudi Arabia and Iran. Additionally, Gabon was accepted as OPEC's 14th member starting from the next month.

England hooker Dylan Hartley was sent off for elbowing Tigers' Matt Smith in a game where Northampton Saints faced an uphill battle after being reduced to 14 men. Despite the setback, Saints managed to secure a thrilling victory with tries from Alex Waller, Ben Foden, and Jamie Elliott. Hartley's red card added to his disciplinary history, raising questions about his England career. The tense match saw two brawls erupt, and Tigers also scored through Niki Goneva and a penalty try. Despite the challenges, Saints emerged victorious, showcasing their championship pedigree.

The latest Markit/CIPS services purchasing managers' index (PMI) stood at 52.6, slightly lower than the previous month but still indicating expansion. The manufacturing sector had its best PMI in two years. Markit suggested that the UK economy has regained modest growth momentum since the EU referendum, with strong growth in manufacturing, reducing the risk of recession in the second half of 2016. Official growth figures for the second quarter were revised up to 0.7%. Experts believe the Bank of England may hold off on cutting rates in November, but predict continued growth slowdown due to Brexit uncertainties. Input price inflation for services firms rose in September, impacting their charges. Services make up about three-quarters of the UK economy.

On Friday at about 02:15 BST, a blue Citroen C3 crashed into a house near the Conrah Hotel on the A487 in Chancery. Three individuals were trapped in the wreckage, with one sustaining minor injuries and two serious injuries. Firefighters had to cut them free. The house suffered significant damage, and a 24-year-old man has been arrested for suspected dangerous driving. The road was closed for three hours as a result of the incident.

The Welsh government covers most tuition fees for Welsh students in the UK. Universities Wales aims to replace the tuition fee grant with a means-tested grant to focus on areas of most need. This change is supported by Prof Colin Riordan, chair of Universities Wales, as a fairer approach. Currently, millions leave Welsh higher education to fund English counterparts. The UK government allows English institutions to raise fees, which may impact the sustainability of the tuition fee grant. Concerns have been raised about Welsh universities falling behind due to the grant system. A review led by Prof Ian Diamond will inform future funding decisions after the upcoming Assembly elections. The Welsh government views their tuition fee policy as an investment in young people, providing Welsh students with significant financial benefits compared to English students.

Actor Parry Glasspool from the soap opera Hollyoaks has been fined by Channel 4 and suspended for two weeks following a controversial Instagram video where he waved a knife and made inappropriate comments about domestic violence. Glasspool has apologized, deleted the video, and will donate the fine to a domestic violence charity.

In an emergency statement at Holyrood, Humza Yousaf apologized to rail passengers for disruptions caused by overhead wiring problems affecting ScotRail services in Glasgow. The rail operator declared a major incident due to a broken insulator, leading to disruptions and cancellations. Yousaf acknowledged ScotRail's performance issues and outlined planned improvements, including earlier commuter services and additional carriages to reduce overcrowding. Yousaf faced calls to publish ScotRail's performance improvement plan, with criticism from opposition parties over handling of the rail crisis. Despite variations in reliability, ScotRail's punctuality data remained better than the UK average, but contractual requirements may lead to contract cancellation if performance drops significantly.

Jordan Amavi, a former France Under-21 international, was signed by Aston Villa in 2015 for £7.7m from Nice but has now agreed to join Marseille. Leandro Bacuna, a winger for Villa, is also close to leaving the club, with a Championship team interested in his services. The transfers were confirmed by Villa manager Steve Bruce after their recent EFL Cup win.

A man named Tim Robinson, 54, slipped and injured his leg while walking under Golden Cap on the Jurassic Coast. After crawling three-quarters of a mile, he was found by his wife who raised the alarm. Due to fog, a rescue helicopter was unavailable, so he was transferred by RNLI lifeboat to a hospital. Robinson, a member of the Territorial Army, praised the help he received, including his wife and rescue teams. It was noted that having a fully charged smartphone for emergencies is advisable while walking on the coast.

India's economy grew at a rate of 7% in the recent quarter, which was slower than the previous quarter's 7.4% but surpassed analysts' expectations of 6.4%. Economists had anticipated a negative impact from the government's demonetisation move, but the figures defied their predictions. While some experts believe the impact of demonetisation may still be felt in future GDP numbers, others argue that the growth figures may be overstated due to the unorganised sector not being adequately captured. The unorganised sector, comprising informal workers, plays a significant role in India's economy.

The Burry Inlet near Llanelli faces flooding issues due to overflow pipes that discharge sewage and rainwater. The European Court of Justice found the UK in breach of clean water laws in the area, with concerns raised about other waste water handling breaches. The UK's aging Victorian sewers are struggling to cope with increased pressure from new developments and climate change-induced storms. Welsh Water is investing in a £113m project called RainScape to improve water management. Despite efforts to comply with EU clean water laws by 2020, the ECJ criticized the UK for acting too late and contributing to water quality deterioration. The Welsh Government, along with Natural Resources Wales and Welsh Water, is working on programs to reduce spills and improve water quality by 2020.

The IBF featherweight world title defence of Lee Selby against Jonathan Victor Barros in Las Vegas was canceled, raising the possibility of future matchups with Carl Frampton, Abner Mares, and Leo Santa Cruz. Amir Khan views Selby as a talented fighter who could elevate his status by facing these prominent names. The potential for Selby to challenge Frampton in Belfast's Windsor Park was discussed, with Khan advocating for the unification of world titles in a high-profile UK bout. Additionally, Khan sees potential for a captivating match between Selby and Mares in the competitive featherweight division.

A 28-year-old Barcelona player was stretchered off the pitch following a challenge and no return timeframe was provided by the club. The team is currently without injured midfielder Iniesta. Barcelona has upcoming matches in the Copa del Rey, La Liga, and Champions League.

MasterChef Australia judge George Calombaris's company, MAdE Establishment, has apologized for underpaying 162 current and former employees at its Melbourne eateries, with an average of over A$16,000 owed per staff member. The errors, dating back to 2011, were caused by miscalculating overtime pay rates. The company is working to repay the money, with former employees being contacted. Calombaris expressed regret for letting the staff down and acknowledged the issue was first flagged by Australia's Fair Work Ombudsman in 2015.

Summary: NHS Health Scotland's final review of the Scottish government's alcohol strategy highlighted successful initiatives such as a ban on multi-buy drinks promotions. However, more actions, including implementing a minimum price for alcohol, are needed to sustain improvements. High alcohol consumption in Scotland has led to significant harm, including deaths and alcohol-related crimes. Despite progress, alcohol-related harm remains a significant issue, and further efforts to reduce drinking levels are necessary. The delayed implementation of minimum unit pricing due to a legal challenge has affected progress in tackling alcohol misuse. Public Health Minister Maureen Watt emphasized the importance of addressing affordability to reduce alcohol consumption and harm.

Charlotte Foster, a 23-year-old woman from Telford, died in January after a thrombosis caused a massive embolism in her lungs, leading to her collapse at work and subsequent death in the hospital three days later. Despite complaining of symptoms such as heart palpitations, rib pain, and difficulty breathing to her GP, she was advised to seek a massage or spa day rather than being diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism. Medical professionals have noted that her only risk factor was taking an oral contraceptive. The inquest is ongoing, with the coroner expected to provide a conclusion soon.

Konstandinos Erik Scurfield, 25, from Barnsley, South Yorkshire, is believed to be the first British person killed fighting Islamic State extremists in Syria. He joined Kurdish forces to combat ISIS due to his abhorrence of their atrocities. Family and neighbors remember him as courageous and honorable. Scurfield, an expert in battlefield medicine, was killed in a missile attack while fighting in north-eastern Syria. His decision to join the Kurdish forces raised concerns about the lack of monitoring British citizens traveling to join the fight against ISIS. The UK government discourages travel to Syria and expresses limited ability to provide assistance in the region.

Morrisons had initially agreed to rent a 73,000 sq ft store, but the site developer reported that Morrisons' lawyers were now trying to end the agreement. Morrisons has not commented on their plans for the site. The development of the car park site by Augur Buchler Partners has faced setbacks, with the construction expected to be completed by late 2015. Cheltenham Borough Council had sold the land in 2011, aiming to develop it since 2008. The councilor expressed disappointment over the latest setback and emphasized the need to resolve the legal situation with Morrisons before proceeding with other plans.

Macclesfield Town secured a 3-0 victory over Maidstone United with goals from Rhys Browne, Danny Whittaker, and Jack Mackreth. Browne scored early on, followed by Whittaker's penalty and Mackreth's goal to seal the win. Macclesfield goalkeeper Craig Ross made crucial saves, while Maidstone's Bobby-Joe Taylor received a yellow card. The victory moves Macclesfield within six points of the top five with five games remaining in the season.

Jonathan Dowdall and his father Patrick were on trial for torturing victim Alexander Hurley in their Dublin home in 2015. The attack was filmed and showed Jonathan pouring water over the victim, while Patrick threatened to pull off his fingers. The victim was tied up, threatened, and physically harmed during the ordeal. It was believed that the Dowdalls thought the victim was a fraudster. The victim suffered severe psychological injuries and stated that the trauma would never fully heal. The court dismissed claims that the Dowdalls' connections to Gerry Adams and Mary Lou McDonald posed a threat. Jonathan Dowdall was convicted, and Mary Lou McDonald stated that he had left the party years ago.

President Morales of Bolivia has established a School of Anti-Imperialism in response to the negative impact of the US-based Army School of the Americas, which trained military officers of US allies during the Cold War, some of whom were involved in serious human rights abuses in Latin America. The new academy aims to study imperialism and its consequences, and focuses on preserving life and identifying threats to Bolivia's national sovereignty. Relations between Morales and the US have been tense, with Morales accusing the US of meddling in regional politics and promoting global terrorism. The School of the Americas has a history of training individuals who later committed human rights abuses, including Argentinean junta leaders and the former Guatemalan President Rios Montt.

Pope Francis visited Cuba, where he praised improving relations with the US, urged support for Cuba's Catholics, and called for continued progress in diplomatic ties. Thousands welcomed him, and he is expected to celebrate Mass in Havana and Holguin. His visit follows recent easing of restrictions on business and travel between the US and Cuba. President Raul Castro thanked the Pope for his role in reconciliation and brokering talks with Washington. The Pope's visit is seen as a sign of hope for the Cuban people, and he is known for his leadership on climate change and poverty. Next, he will travel to the US.

A woman was attacked in Barrhead between Main Street and Cross Arthurlie Street over a 24-hour period. Although she was not physically injured, she was left severely shaken. The suspect, described as tall, well built, and bearded, is being sought by Police Scotland. Witnesses are being urged to come forward with any information that may assist in the investigation.

Richard Tutt, head of Magna Academy in Poole, introduced an assembly apology sanction for extreme behavior cases to prevent permanent exclusions, where students publicly apologize in front of their peers. The school has a reward system where students earn points for good behavior to buy items like nail manicures or footballs. However, some parents have criticized the school, accusing them of humiliating or bullying pupils. Mr. Tutt defended the approach, stating that students receive more rewards than punishments and emphasizing the importance of a supportive environment for at-risk students. The school's academic progress in 2015/16 was among the top 7% in England.

Following the European Union's decision to label goods from Jewish settlements in the West Bank, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has suspended diplomatic contacts with EU institutions on this issue. The EU considers the settlements illegal, but Israel disputes this, leading to tensions between the two entities. Netanyahu has ordered a reassessment of EU involvement in diplomatic processes with Palestinians, in response to the EU's labeling guidelines for products from Israeli settlements. The EU views settlements as hindrances to peace and the two-state solution in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

An Ipsos MRBI poll for The Irish Times shows rising chances of a hung Dáil, with Labour and Sinn Féin support decreasing while Fianna Fáil and Independents see gains. If replicated on Election Day, the results would be inconclusive. Fine Gael's support remains steady, Labour's drops to 6%, Fianna Fáil rises to 23%, and Sinn Féin falls to 15%. Independents and smaller parties gain to 28%. RTE reports no momentum for Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Labour is concerned about declining support. Fianna Fáil is pleased with the positive response, while Sinn Féin is disappointed by decreasing support.

Georgian prop Anton Peikrishvili has been suspended following an incident where he bit Ospreys player Rob McCusker during a match he played for Cardiff Blues. His ban is back-dated to 22 November and he will be eligible to play again from 2 January 2017. Prior to Cardiff Blues, Peikrishvili had a short-term stint with Ulster. The Rugby Football Union handled the disciplinary proceedings, also issuing a ban to Scarlets' Jack Condy for punching during a separate match.

Carwyn Edwards, 39, is in a Tucson hospital after having part of both legs amputated following an illness. His family is worried about the potential high medical costs. A fundraising campaign has collected £38,000, but uncertainty remains as his insurance benefits are set to stop soon. Cigna, his medical insurer, is working to address his concerns. Carwyn's brother, Aled, plans to go to Arizona to help resolve the issue and explore the possibility of transferring Carwyn to the UK for further treatment. Cigna has been in touch with Carwyn and will continue addressing his worries directly with him.

Lawand Hamadamin and his family are facing deportation from the UK to Germany, where the government believes they should have claimed asylum. The family, originally from northern Iraq, fled to the UK after escaping threats from ISIS. Lawand is receiving education at a school for the deaf in Derby, where he has shown exceptional progress. The family's appeal against deportation will be heard in the High Court. The Home Office argues that asylum seekers should claim in the first safe country they arrive in, and if evidence suggests responsibility lies with another European country, they will seek to return them there.

Russian state media reported that the USS Ross was acting aggressively in the Black Sea, but the US Department of Defense stated that the ship was conducting routine operations well within international waters. The US Navy released video showing a Russian plane passing close to the USS Ross, with Russian military sources claiming the ship was acting provocatively. Pentagon confirmed that the Russian planes were unarmed and the USS Ross maintained its course. This incident reflects ongoing military tensions between Russia and the West, highlighted by recent encounters in the Black Sea and near UK and Swedish borders.

A team is developing a portable and less expensive device to quickly detect strokes in real-time using microwave technology. This helmet with microwave antennae will provide a 3D image of the brain within 15 minutes, sending data to a supercomputing center for interpretation. The team's mathematical approach has earned recognition, and they aim to have the sensor helmets available for use in ambulances and other settings within two to four years, potentially improving survival rates for stroke victims.

West Brom rejected Manchester City's £18m bid for 29-year-old Northern Irish centre-back Jonny Evans. West Brom manager Tony Pulis stated that City have not been in contact for a couple of days and they hope to resolve the situation soon. Even though West Brom does not want to sell Evans, Pulis acknowledged that every player is available for the right price. Manchester City must first offload Eliaquim Mangala to make space for Evans, with Inter Milan interested in Mangala but facing challenges due to his contract. As a result, Evans' move is on hold for now.

31-year-old half-back Rangi Chase has joined Widnes until the end of the season due to not being in Castleford Tigers' plans for the remainder of 2017. Chase was dropped by Castleford for three games in March following an internal investigation. Widnes, currently bottom of the table, have secured a valuable signing in Chase, with coach Denis Betts expressing excitement over his quality and determination to play regularly. Chase sees the move as a clean slate and is eager to contribute to the team's challenging position.

The Welsh government is halfway through a five-year, £4.6m program to immunize badgers in north Pembrokeshire in an effort to control TB. Infection rates have decreased across Wales, but it is too early to determine the specific impact of the badger vaccination program. Dr. Christianne Glossop, who spoke ahead of a global TB control conference in Cardiff, highlighted that while infection rates have fallen, there is no current evidence showing additional benefits from the badger vaccination initiative. In the past two years, thousands of badgers have been trapped and vaccinated, but the broader TB eradication program in Wales, costing £28m annually, involves various measures such as testing cattle, biosecurity, and compensating farmers. The vaccination program was launched in 2012 as an alternative to culling badgers in the Intensive Action Area.

The 2019 Rugby World Cup will feature Ireland and Scotland in Pool A, while Wales will face Australia in Pool D. Defending champions New Zealand are in Pool B with South Africa and Italy. England coach Eddie Jones aims to win the tournament, citing a challenging pool with Argentina and France. The knockout stage structure remains the same as in 2015, with teams from the same pool unable to meet again until the semi-finals. Notable matchups could include England vs. Wales in the quarter-finals and New Zealand potentially facing Ireland or Scotland.

Besik Kudukhov, the silver medalist in freestyle wrestling at the London 2012 Olympics, passed away in 2013. Recent testing revealed he had taken the steroid turinabol, but the IOC decided to take no action on the case. Indian wrestler Yogeshwar Dutt expressed support for Kudukhov keeping his medal, emphasizing humanity over everything else. The IOC confirmed that Kudukhov will not be stripped of his silver medal.

Scott Johnson confirmed his departure from the Ospreys, stating he will not renew his contract at the end of the season. He will be available for the Scottish Rugby Union's June tour to Australia, Fiji, and Samoa. During his time with the Ospreys, Johnson focused on developing systems for homegrown talent. His departure was met with disappointment but understanding from Ospreys management. Johnson has had coaching roles with Wales, the USA, and the Ospreys, contributing to their successes. Scotland coach Andy Robinson sought an experienced coach, leading to Johnson's inclusion in the Scottish coaching team. Johnson's departure allows Ospreys to plan for the future while reflecting on the legacy of the systems and structures he helped develop there.

Lewis Hamilton will start 10th in the upcoming race in Baku after a disappointing qualifying session. He described it as one of his worst sessions ever, citing discomfort in the car and multiple mistakes. Despite facing challenges, Hamilton remains hopeful of scoring good points and potentially winning the race. His Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg secured pole position and expects an exciting and action-packed race. There is uncertainty regarding Hamilton's tires due to damage incurred during qualifying, but it is likely that the FIA will allow a change if safety is a concern.

Christophe Berra, a 32-year-old with 35 caps, is set to leave Ipswich as he desires to return north to spend more time with his daughter. Despite Ipswich having the option to extend his contract, they opted not to do so to support Berra's wish to be closer to home. Manager Mick McCarthy praised Berra's contributions to the team, acknowledging his desire to prioritize family and wishing him well in his future endeavors.

Four candidates have stepped forward for election in St Peter Port parish, but with five seats available, there will be a vacancy. The parish constable attributes the lack of candidates to a "lack of interest" and limited understanding of the role. Criticism of the douzaine over the appointment of a town centre manager may also be a factor. The chairman of the Douzaine Council suggests confusion around the parish system as another reason for the lack of interest. There has been an increase in contested elections across the island, prompting a call for an end to uncontested electors' meetings. The parish will need to re-advertise the fifth position and possibly hold another election if no additional candidate comes forward.

Paramedics at Queen Alexandra Hospital in Portsmouth are experiencing significant delays in off-loading patients, causing morale issues and impacting ambulance availability for the public. Portsmouth Hospitals NHS Trust cites extremely high demand at the A&E, with 16 ambulances queuing at one point. The situation is described as chaotic by SCAS paramedics, leading to stress and concerns over patient care. The trust notes a 15% increase in A&E attendances compared to last year, with efforts underway to address the challenges through an emergency care improvement program.

Sir Philip had previously faced criticism for an inadequate solution to the pension deficit at BHS, but has since implemented a substantial recovery plan for Arcadia's pension schemes. Following the sale of BHS, he agreed to pay £363m to bolster its pension scheme. Arcadia was revealed to have a pension deficit of nearly £565m in 2016, prompting the company to double its annual contributions to address the issue. While Arcadia's schemes have received greater support compared to BHS, concerns remain about Sir Philip's differential treatment of the two schemes. Former Labour MP Frank Field praised Arcadia's plan while criticizing the handling of BHS's pension deficit.

Swansea council was notified by the South Wales Evening Post about a noise issue in Townhill and Mayhill, following reports from readers. The council has identified a potential source of the sound and is asking the public to share any relevant information with their noise pollution team.

Patients and staff were evacuated from Cerahpasa hospital in Istanbul after a man threatened to shoot himself and others, prompting police to negotiate with the individual. Contrary to initial reports, the man did not take hostages and was alone in his room. The man, a young police officer undergoing psychiatric treatment for two years, had his firearm confiscated prior to the incident. The hospital had previously recommended against him carrying a gun. This incident occurred within the backdrop of heightened tension in Istanbul due to recent attacks, including the Reina nightclub shooting on New Year's Eve.

Roddy Smith is approaching the end of his 10-year term as chief executive of Cricket Scotland, during which the organization has achieved significant growth and success. Under Smith's leadership, the management team and turnover have expanded, while participation figures in cricket have risen. The national team secured a spot in the World Cup finals and achieved success in global events. Smith's departure comes at a time when Cricket Scotland is in good health and poised for further success. The organization is now searching for a successor, with plans for a new "world class" base in Stirling on the horizon.

Summary: Vereniki Goneva, a 31-year-old Fiji international, has signed with Newcastle Falcons after spending four years with Leicester Tigers. He has made 78 appearances and scored 32 tries for the Tigers. Director of rugby Dean Richards praises Goneva's back-line firepower and international experience, having scored 15 tries for Fiji in 39 caps. Richards views the signing as a testament to the Falcons' rising status in attracting top talent to the Premiership.

A study conducted by Oxford University suggests that kissing serves as a way for individuals to assess the quality of a potential partner through taste, smell, and fitness. Kissing plays a crucial role in mate selection, with men and women valuing it differently based on attractiveness and number of casual partners. Women tend to place a higher value on kissing in long-term relationships, as it fosters affection and attachment. Additionally, the study highlights that women's attitude towards romantic kissing may vary depending on the stage of their menstrual cycle and relationship status. Ultimately, kissing is seen as a significant factor in partner selection and relationship maintenance.

Drug Aid Cymru attributes the rise in drug-related deaths to the potency of substances and the lack of awareness among users. Recent figures show an increase in drug-related deaths in 2015 after a five-year decline. The Welsh Government pledges to consider options and prioritize reducing these figures. Drug Aid Cymru's regional director, Ifor Glyn, highlights the increase in heroin availability, stronger purity, and a higher number of individuals not accessing services as contributing factors. Collaboration among agencies is deemed necessary to tackle the issue effectively. Suggestions such as information-sharing among users or establishing safe consumption rooms are proposed solutions. The Welsh Government allocates £50 million annually towards drug services, aiming to reach individuals currently not engaging with substance misuse services.

Mark Wylie from Calne emerged victorious in a town crier competition in Bermuda, overcoming contenders from around the world. Judges evaluated entrants on factors like volume, diction, and presence. Wylie, normally clad in a heavy uniform, had a lighter outfit made for the tropical climate. Despite straining his voice, he gave his all and triumphed over the reigning champion, winning all three cries. Wylie, who received rum as a prize, credited his wife for crafting his suitable attire.

A new electrostatic coating on netting has shown promise in killing mosquitoes carrying diseases like malaria. Dutch researchers discovered that this technique can deliver lethal doses of insecticide, addressing the issue of insecticide resistance. The coating proved highly effective in killing mosquitoes, even those resistant to traditional methods. The researchers anticipate widespread applications for this technology, but caution against its use on bed nets due to potential interference from human contact and washing.

Spotify is considering a direct listing on a stock exchange, foregoing the traditional initial public offering (IPO) process. This would allow the music service to become publicly listed without raising new capital or paying underwriting fees. A direct listing involves existing shares being traded on the day of listing, based on supply and demand, rather than being purchased by new investors beforehand. Benefits of a direct listing include avoiding dilution of existing stakes, sidestepping first-day trading surges, and reducing regulatory hurdles. Spotify, valued at $8.5bn in 2015, has over 50 million paying subscribers and recently signed a licensing deal with Universal Music Group.

Global Wireless Solutions conducted a survey of 2,000 mobile-phone users, revealing that 40% experienced blackspots at home, with high instances reported in Liverpool and Cardiff. Telecom analyst Matthew Howett suggested that the situation will improve as operators utilize different frequencies for coverage. EE and Three offer solutions to bypass blackspots using existing broadband connections, while Vodafone provides signal boosters. The survey indicated that kitchens and certain types of houses have the weakest signals. O2 has committed to providing indoor 4G coverage to 98% of the population by 2017, with Mr. Howett expressing optimism that the issue will be resolved soon.

Academics from Edinburgh and Essex universities conducted a survey of voters, revealing that only 3.4% of "No" voters cited "The Vow" as their main reason for voting as such. The main factor for opposing independence was a sense of British identity or belief in the Union, noted by 29.5% of respondents. Yes voters believed that the promise of more powers swayed voters towards the Union, despite this not being the main reason among No voters. The study suggests that the impact of "The Vow" may have been exaggerated, with most voters deciding against independence prior to its publication. Overall, the survey highlights the complexities of voter decision-making and the lasting impact of the referendum on political engagement in Scotland.

Seaward achieved a significant personal best by clocking 2:14.52 in the marathon, surpassing the Rio standard of 2:17.00. Meanwhile, Paul Pollock also met the standard with a time of 2:15.38, but finished as the fourth Irish runner. Moldovan-born Sergiu Ciobanu and Mick Clohisey were also within the standard times. Ireland can only send three male marathon entrants to Rio, so Pollock may need to run faster next spring to secure his spot. Ciobanu, who switched allegiance to Ireland recently, expressed his delight at his performance. Pollock overcame injury setbacks to achieve his time. In contrast, Lizzie Lee secured her Rio selection comfortably by setting a new personal best of 2:32.51, well below the Olympic standard.

Minh To of Stockport, Greater Manchester was targeted in a fraudulent scheme where two men stole his mail, forged his signature, and attempted to auction off his five-bedroom home. The fraudsters transferred the property deeds into one of their names and put the house up for auction without Mr To's knowledge. The men involved were sentenced to jail time, with one receiving 7.5 years and the other 2 years and 9 months. A third member of the gang was sentenced for a separate fraud. Mr To was alerted to the scam by his daughter before the auction was set to take place. He is advocating for stricter regulations to prevent similar incidents in the future, emphasizing the importance of requiring multiple signatures for land registry deed changes. Authorities are warning the public to safeguard their identities and secure their mailboxes.

The Premier League club Sunderland wants manager Sam Allardyce to stay despite FA's interest in him for the England job. Allardyce's potential candidacy has caused speculation and disruption, with Sunderland urging for a quick resolution. Former players believe Allardyce's motivational skills and ability to create team spirit make him a good fit for the England role. Other contenders for the position include Arsene Wenger, Eddie Howe, Steve Bruce, Jurgen Klinsmann, and Glenn Hoddle, but Allardyce is seen as the frontrunner. The new England manager will be chosen by a three-man panel and is expected to be tactically astute and able to establish a cohesive team identity. Allardyce previously missed out on the job in 2006 in favor of Steve McClaren.

A collision between a tram and a pedestrian resulted in a fatality in Greater Manchester. A 31-year-old woman is in custody, not as the tram driver. Metrolink services on the Bury line were disrupted due to the incident during the Parklife festival. Attendees were advised to walk back to the city center from Heaton Park. Some questioned the safety of the walking route in the dark, while others saw safety in numbers. Metrolink urged passengers to avoid Manchester Victoria station, citing an ongoing medical emergency. Services returned to normal the next day, with condolences expressed for the deceased and families.

A fire broke out at a detached building in Codicote, near Welwyn, in the morning. The building had experienced a fire 20 years ago, prompting the installation of fire-proof foil under the thatch to protect the main building. Over 15 fire engines and support vehicles responded to the blaze, leading to road closures and traffic diversions in the area.

Swansea secured a 1-0 victory over Burnley, with Nathan Dyer scoring the only goal. Burnley came close to equalizing in the second half but were unable to break through. Swansea, led by Garry Monk, are now level on points with Chelsea at the top of the table. Burnley, under manager Sean Dyche, are still searching for their first Premier League point this season. Despite a strong second-half performance from Burnley, Swansea's defense held firm to secure the win.

In The Gambia, where a crucial presidential election is taking place, challenger Adama Barrow is facing off against incumbent President Yahya Jammeh. The country, known for its unique voting system using marbles, has seen high voter turnout and a sense of hope for change among its population. Jammeh, in power since a 1994 coup, faces accusations of repression and human rights abuses, while his supporters praise his efforts in education and healthcare. Ahead of the election, concerns were raised about potential violence, but campaigning proceeded relatively smoothly. The EU opted not to send observers due to fairness concerns, while the African Union sent a limited team. The outcome of the election is eagerly awaited as The Gambia aims for a peaceful transition of power after decades under Jammeh's rule.

UN and Arab diplomats in Geneva, led by US Secretary of State John Kerry, are working on a plan to reduce violence in Aleppo amid recent escalations in Syria's civil war. A cessation of hostilities has shown positive effects but has been tested in recent weeks, with ongoing air strikes and artillery attacks in Aleppo causing casualties. Kerry emphasizes the need for a broad and reinforced truce, with increased ceasefire monitors to track violations. He condemns the recent Aleppo hospital air strike and calls for all sides to observe the cessation of hostilities. The talks in Geneva follow a unilateral truce extension in Damascus and Latakia, amid rebel factions' demands for a nationwide ceasefire.

A referendum is underway in Darfur to decide whether to remain as five states or form a single region. The US has criticized the credibility of the vote, while President Omar al-Bashir insists it will be fair. There are concerns over insecurity, displaced people not being able to vote, and rebel groups seeking more regional powers. More than 2.5 million people remain displaced in Darfur, with ongoing violence and tensions dating back to 2003. President Bashir, indicted by the International Criminal Court for war crimes in Darfur, plans to step down in 2020.

Summary: Wales' coaching staff, including head coach Warren Gatland and assistants Shaun Edwards, Robin McBryde, and Rob Howley, are facing expiring contracts after the Rugby World Cup. Gatland may evaluate the coaching set-up following their quarter-final exit. Despite potential interest from other teams, such as England, Gatland is expected to honor his contract with Wales until 2019. The team's performance, which included a victory over England, will be reviewed for potential improvements moving forward.

Roberto Firmino scored twice, cancelling out Fernando Llorente's double, but Gylfi Sigurdsson's 74th-minute goal secured a valuable win for Swansea at Anfield, where they had never won before. Former player Toshack praised Swansea's performance, calling it one of the club's greatest results. He highlighted their focus and organization, emphasizing that their victory was well-deserved and not solely due to Liverpool's poor performance. Toshack had previously predicted Swansea's relegation and questioned manager Paul Clement's appointment.

West Bromwich Albion has signed 22-year-old midfielder Alex Pritchard on loan from Tottenham Hotspur. Pritchard, an England Under-21 international, can feature in the Baggies' squad for their upcoming Premier League match against Swansea City. Despite interest in striker Saido Berahino, West Bromwich stood firm on keeping him. Pritchard had a successful loan spell at Brentford last season and signed a new four-year deal with Tottenham last summer.

Southampton secured a 1-0 victory over West Brom, with the Dutchman scoring a stunning goal assisted by Dusan Tadic. Fraser Forster's heroic saves denied the Baggies, who have struggled in their recent matches. West Brom, under Tony Pulis, are aiming for a top-10 finish but are facing challenges in both scoring goals and maintaining a solid defense. Southampton's strong performance was highlighted by Forster's saves and Tadic's contributions, leading to their fifth win in six games. Pulis expressed disappointment in his team's inability to convert chances, despite having 35 shots in their last two games. Southampton manager Claude Puel praised his team's character and defensive solidity, with Forster playing a crucial role in securing the victory.

In a closely contested match, Wales secured a 24-20 victory over Argentina with a late penalty from Leigh Halfpenny proving decisive. Wales scored tries through Liam Williams and Gareth Davies in the second half to maintain a narrow lead, while Argentina responded with tries from Juan Martin Hernandez and Martin Landajo. Despite Wales dominating possession in the first half, they struggled to convert their opportunities, but ultimately managed to hold off a resilient Pumas side. Alun Wyn Jones and Liam Williams made significant impacts on their return to the Welsh team. The match saw moments of excitement, but also highlighted Wales' need to improve their composure in attack.

Joan Edwards left her estate to the government in an ambiguous will, causing confusion and public outcry. Another case involved a £500,000 legacy with a specific stipulation. The importance of clear and carefully drafted wills, potential issues with naming and identifying beneficiaries, and the consequences of an invalid will were highlighted. Making changes after signing, public record disclosure, and the impact on inheritance if no valid will exists were also discussed. It was emphasized that seeking legal advice is crucial in creating a will to avoid potential conflicts and ensure one's intentions are carried out effectively.

Kirsty Aitchison, a 30-year-old mother-of-four, was confirmed dead after going missing following a social event for deaf people. Her body was found in the Clyde near the Kingston Bridge. The police stated that her death is not considered suspicious. After leaving a bar in Sauchiehall Street early Sunday morning, she was seen on CCTV heading towards the river. Police received support from the public and the Deaf/BSL community during the investigation, and their thoughts are with Kirsty's family and friends.

Joan Crilly, 73, was hit by a car on Campbell Street on December 22 around 16:05. She was initially taken to Inverclyde Royal Hospital and later transferred to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, where she passed away on Wednesday due to her injuries. The car driver was unharmed. Police are seeking witnesses to the incident. Mrs. Crilly was married and had two children.

Cape Verde suffered a defeat to Morocco, who secured their spot as group winners by defeating them twice. Despite the loss, Cape Verde still has a chance to qualify for the finals if they collect maximum points in their remaining matches. Morocco's coach, Herve Renard, will have the opportunity to win a third Nations Cup title with a third team after guiding them to next year's tournament.

Dr. McDonnell has faced criticism for planning to continue leading his party from Westminster as an MP while stepping down from the assembly. Party figures such as Brid Rodgers and Seamus Mallon have called for him to give up the leadership, with Mallon urging him to act swiftly. In response, McDonnell expressed disagreement with Mallon's views and emphasized the support he has from party members. He dismissed the threat of a leadership challenge from internal critics, stating his commitment to working within party rules and regulations. McDonnell stressed the importance of completing the task at hand and criticized the idea of a personality contest within the party. He preferred direct communication over public negotiations but acknowledged the nature of individual autonomy within a democratic party.

In a match between New Zealand and Sri Lanka, Kane Williamson and Ross Taylor played crucial roles with two sixes each during a partnership of 117 runs in 123 balls as New Zealand posted 315-8 after choosing to bat first. Kumar Sangakkara scored 81 runs before falling in the 38th over. Sri Lanka were all out for 195 soon after. It was a dominant win for New Zealand, who will face Sri Lanka again in the opening match of the World Cup on 14 February. Williamson missed out on a century after being run out, while Taylor contributed 96 runs. Corey Anderson added 40 runs quickly, and Sri Lanka's strong start was disrupted by wickets falling in quick succession.

Francis Thomas Mooney, 60, died in a crash in Fernhill Road near Glasgow involving multiple vehicles, including a bus. The driver of the agricultural vehicle is in stable condition. No other serious injuries occurred, and the vehicles were not badly damaged. Police are investigating the incident and urge witnesses to come forward.

A fire involving two pieces of cardboard occurred in the basement car park of building 23 in the Olympic Village during Rio 2016. The fire brigade responded promptly and the AOC's emergency plan was enacted. The Australian delegation initially refused to enter the building due to maintenance issues. The occupants were evacuated but allowed back in after 30 minutes. The incident is under investigation.

Cymru Fyw from S4C has challenged some screen stars to learn Welsh. Actress Dannii Minogue shone as a judge on Let It Shine, displaying her Welsh roots despite being raised in Australia. Welsh pronunciation challenges are faced by visitors to Wales, including the Eastenders cast. The drama Casualty is now filmed in Cardiff, aiding the crew in learning Welsh body part names. The Welsh language is encouraged for all to learn and enjoy.

Home Secretary Mrs. May made a speech advocating for the UK to remain in the EU and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), citing security benefits. She differentiated between the EU and ECHR, expressing concerns about additional countries joining the EU. She criticized the ECHR for controversial human rights decisions affecting the UK and urged the UK to assert leadership in Europe. Meanwhile, pro-Leave voices warned about potential new EU members and increased immigration. Mrs. May emphasized the importance of maximizing prosperity, security, influence, and sovereignty in the EU referendum decision, suggesting the UK should stay in the ECHR but seek reform.

The Bulford Kiwi, a 130m-tall monument carved by New Zealand troops near Stonehenge, has been designated a scheduled monument by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. It commemorates the role of Kiwi soldiers in the Battle of Messines in Belgium during World War I. Another monument at Cannock Chase marking the same battle has also been protected. A Terrain Model of Messines, created by German prisoners of war, was recently excavated and covered for preservation. Historic England praises these monuments for honoring New Zealand's bravery in the war, while the New Zealand High Commissioner expresses gratitude for the protection of these important sites with strong historical connections.

An 18-year-old student fell at New Charter Academy in Greater Manchester, sustaining serious injuries. The student was taken to Manchester Royal Infirmary for treatment. The school remains open as police investigate the incident, and the principal expressed support for the student's family along with staff and pupils.

- 35-year-old Federer won his first match in six months, defeating Melzer in four sets.
- Wawrinka beat Klizan in five sets and will face Steve Johnson next.
- Nishikori overcame Kuznetsov in five sets and will play Jeremy Chardy next.
- Nick Kyrgios won his match swiftly despite a brief medical timeout for a nosebleed.
- Almagro withdrew from his match due to a calf injury, leading to Chardy's progression.
- Berdych advanced as Vanni retired, while Cilic fought back to beat Janowicz in five sets.
- Tsonga won his match against Monteiro in four sets.
- Notable upcoming matches include Federer vs. Rubin and Kyrgios vs. Seppi.

A crash occurred on Mountain Road near Trimsaran in Carmarthenshire before 23:20 BST. One boy is at Glangwili Hospital in Carmarthen, while the other was taken to Cardiff's University Hospital Wales. The road is closed for investigations, and police seized a second vehicle at the scene. Witnesses are urged to contact Carmarthenshire Roads Policing Unit on 101.

Vauxhall's pension scheme in the UK, with 15,000 members, is facing a deficit of approximately £1bn according to pensions expert John Ralfe. The proposed sale of Vauxhall will be discussed in the Commons, as PSA Group considers taking over Opel's European business. PSA may not want to inherit the pension scheme's deficit, which could impact the potential deal. The Unite union is also engaging with PSA on the deal's implications for jobs. Despite concerns, Ralfe believes Vauxhall pensioners should not worry, but emphasizes the need for attention to pension issues alongside job considerations.

The government has accepted the recommendations of the Senior Salaries Review Body, endorsing a 1% pay increase for senior public sector workers. This decision comes amid ongoing debate over the 1% cap on public sector pay rises. Despite some calls for reconsideration, ministers have reiterated the government's policy on pay restraint. The Senior Salaries Review Board recommended 1% rises for various senior groups, which have been approved by ministers. The government emphasizes the need to balance pay with job security and fiscal responsibility, while trade unions argue for more substantial pay reform for senior civil servants.

Jackie Kay's book, "Red Dust Road," won the £30,000 prize after being chosen from 91 submissions. It is the first time the public voted for a winner, with the novel also unanimously selected by the judging panel. The runners-up, Leila Aboulela, Stewart Conn, and Sue Peebles, each received £5,000. Kay, who was born in Edinburgh and adopted at birth, explores her search for her birth parents in the book. She expressed that the win feels like a victory for her whole family and that readers have found connections to their own lives in her work. Past winners of the prize include James Kelman and Edwin Morgan. Creative Scotland's chief executive praised Scotland's writers for showcasing the country's cultural profile internationally, calling Jackie Kay one of Scotland's national treasures.

In an incident at a border crossing near Jisr al-Shugour in Syria, controlled by jihadist groups, four children and four adults were killed while attempting to cross into Turkey. The Turkish military claims guards fired warning shots and the Syrians dispersed, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports that eight others were injured. Turkey, facing pressure from the EU to halt Syrian migration, has closed its borders to Syrians, where over 2.7 million refugees reside. The Observatory also highlights that nearly 60 civilians have been shot while attempting to flee Syria into Turkey since 2016.

On Friday, police seized 800 plants and electrical equipment from a workshop in Millisle. It was described as one of the largest and most advanced production operations uncovered recently. Inspector Andy Dunlop noted the presence of young plants, remnants of a previous harvest, drying space, and waste product storage. No arrests were made, but investigations are ongoing.

The government is meeting with Southern Rail to address the ongoing union dispute regarding the role of guards on new trains, which has led to delays and cancellations. The Transport Minister expressed frustration at the situation and emphasized the need for a resolution that prioritizes passengers. Southern Rail has implemented a temporary emergency timetable, resulting in reduced services, but plans to gradually reinstate the full timetable. The RMT has criticized Southern's handling of the situation and warned that the dispute may continue for several months.

The Dow Jones index and Nasdaq closed up 0.19%, with the S&P 500 managing a slight 0.02% increase. Oil prices slipped due to higher US stockpiles, leading to pressure on energy company shares. Brent Crude fell by 1.7% to $54.79, while West Texas Intermediate Crude dropped by 2.2% to $51.86. Chevron and Exxon Mobil shares decreased, as concerns arose about potential impacts on S&P 500 earnings. Michael Kors experienced the largest S&P decline of 10.8% after reporting disappointing sales and lowering revenue forecasts. General Motors saw a 4.7% decline in net profits, contributing to its stock decline.

An internal report from HMP Wayland reveals that an inmate ran down a landing with keys, prompting a struggle between officers and another prisoner trying to grab more keys. Both individuals have been transferred to a higher security facility and will receive additional time added to their sentences. The incident occurred on A wing and was quickly resolved with the offenders apprehended. Wayland is a Category C men's prison with a population of over 1,000 inmates.

A new road planned to connect Postwick to A1067 in Norwich has received mixed opinions. Norfolk Chamber supports it, anticipating economic benefits, while critics argue it won't solve traffic issues and will harm quality of life for residents.

The UK government is set to increase maximum sentences for stalking and harassment, with a proposed amendment to the Policing and Crime Bill aiming to double penalties for racially or religiously aggravated cases. The move comes in response to pressure and aims to address the severity of these crimes. Labour had previously pushed for tougher penalties, with some Conservative MPs also supporting the increase. New stalking protection orders have been introduced to provide early protection for victims, allowing police to take action before a suspect is arrested or convicted. Stalking became a specific criminal offence in England and Wales in 2012, with similar laws in place in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The Co Antrim Shield decider features an upcoming match between various teams, including Portadown, Glenavon, Coleraine, and Ballymena United. Dungannon Swifts will face Warrenpoint Town, the only non-top-flight team left in the competition. Crusaders boss Stephen Baxter is anticipating a challenging match and expects a vibrant atmosphere during the games.

Lib Dem leader Tim Farron has stated that some Labour MPs have serious doubts about the direction under Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, with many feeling distressed and seeking advice. Farron sees Corbyn's election as an opportunity for the Lib Dems to occupy the center ground in British politics. Despite speculations of defection, former foreign secretary Jack Straw believes it is unlikely due to past experiences with the SDP in the 1980s.

Summary: Multiple bomb attacks in Biu and Jos, Nigeria, resulted in at least 32 casualties. The presidential election scheduled for February has been postponed due to the unrest, with a new date set for 28 March. President Goodluck Jonathan claims the army is winning the war against Boko Haram, despite ongoing violence in the region.

The warning comes after Johnny Sexton took heavy tackles in France's win over Ireland. Sexton was forced off, and France's Maestri was warned. Wales' Biggar was also injured, but Jenkins praised his toughness. Jenkins believes targeting Biggar is a positive sign. He also mentioned that Rhys Webb needs more game-time before being considered for Wales. Webb recently made a comeback but suffered a head injury.

A man has died in an incident in Ferry Lane in Tottenham Hale, with gunshot wounds leading to an injury to a police officer who is now discharged. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) is investigating the incident, noting that a firearm was recovered. Eyewitnesses reported a confrontation between the man and police before shots were fired. The Metropolitan Police did not confirm if the man was shot by an officer. Local residents described a tense scene with multiple police vehicles, helicopters, and road closures. MP David Lammy expressed concern and called for a prompt investigation by the IPCC to clarify the circumstances of the incident.

Manchester City's Jennifer Beattie scored the only goal late in the match, leading her team to a 1-0 victory over Arsenal in the Continental Cup semifinals. This defeat marked the first time Arsenal failed to reach the final in the cup's history. City will face Birmingham City in the final, scheduled for Sunday, 2 October. The goal came from a deflection off a free-kick by Toni Duggan, moments after an effort from Arsenal's Danielle Carter hit the crossbar. City captain Steph Houghton also made a crucial goal-line clearance to deny Arsenal. Beattie's goal secured City's place in the final, as they aim to win the cup for the second time.

Ali Price, a Scotland under-20 international, signed his first professional contract with the Warriors in December. He has made nine appearances this season and expressed satisfaction with his performance and impact on the team. Warriors head coach Gregor Townsend praised Price's development as a scrum-half, highlighting his improved skills in passing, kicking, and ball-carrying. Townsend commended Price's work ethic, fitness level, and seizing of playing opportunities in key matches.

Justine Henshaw-Bryan chased cyclist Damien Doughty through Stoke Newington, north London, causing him to crash into a tree. Despite claiming her then-boyfriend directed her to follow the cyclist, the judge rejected her defense. Mr. Doughty suffered serious injuries and spent three days in intensive care. Henshaw-Bryan was found guilty of causing serious injury by dangerous driving and was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison. The judge emphasized that her actions could have been fatal and described her behavior as a calculated attempt to harm Mr. Doughty.

Former footballer who played alongside Tim Sherwood supports him as Aston Villa manager, highlighting his leadership qualities and ability to get the best out of players. Believes Sherwood deserves a chance due to his success in keeping Villa up last season despite challenges. Acknowledges pressure on Sherwood this season given the loss of key players and reliance on young, inexperienced signings. Attributes some responsibility to Villa's recruitment team for squad strength.

15-year-old Katie was found with serious injuries in Woodthorpe, York and later died in the hospital. Another 15-year-old girl, who cannot be named, pleaded not guilty to charges related to the incident. The charges include possession of a knife. The girl appeared in Leeds Crown Court via video-link and will stand trial on 3 July. The trial will be held in Leeds. Katie's funeral was held at York Minster and an inquest into her death has been opened and adjourned.

Thames Valley Police is reviewing CCTV and dash-cam footage following the rape of a 14-year-old girl who was abducted on her way to school in Summertown. Officer patrols are gathering witness information, and a team of officers is supporting the victim. Descriptions of two suspects have been released: a white man in his mid-20s and another white man in his late teens or early 20s. The police are focusing on the Marston Meadow area in their investigation.

The Oxford Bulls, a team of boys with Down's Syndrome, played their first game after two years of training together. Ayshah met the boys to learn about their love for football and to test her skills against theirs.

Sport Wales has issued an ultimatum to the Welsh Amateur Boxing Association (WABA), stating that unless new directors are appointed, they will not consider the organization's application for future public funding. This decision comes after concerns were raised about WABA's governance practices, including issues with recruitment, board meetings, and key decisions. Former directors of WABA have criticized Sport Wales for being "short-sighted" and "vindictive" in their approach. Sport Wales has cited a breakdown in their relationship with a consultant brought in to address governance issues, leading to a lack of confidence in the current leadership of WABA. Despite disagreements, Sport Wales maintains that the decision was necessary to ensure proper governance and the effective use of public funds.

Goldman Sachs reported increased first-quarter profits, but fell short of market expectations, causing shares to drop 4.7%. Johnson & Johnson also disappointed with lower revenues, leading to a 3.1% drop in its stock price. These two companies were the biggest decliners on the Dow Jones, which closed down 0.5% at 20,523 points. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices also saw slight declines.

The band One Direction has achieved significant success with 50 million records sold and 91 number one hits. However, Zayn's departure in 2015 raised doubts about the group's future. According to The Sun newspaper, Harry, Liam, Louis, and Niall are reportedly set to go their separate ways after releasing their fifth studio album in March. Fans' reactions to this news are being collected by Martin.

The recent figures obtained by BBC Radio Oxford through a Freedom of Information request reveal 411 signalling problems during the 2014/15 financial year, showing a 22% increase from 2012/13. Network Rail attributed the faults to a lack of railway investment. Signalling problems can be caused by various issues, such as power cuts or equipment age. The disruptions have drawn criticism from commuters facing rising prices, with concerns raised about the lack of service improvements despite fare increases.

In the Allianz Football League matches, Derry lost to Cork and remain at the bottom of the league with 3 points, while Down also suffered a defeat to Galway and are on 4 points. Fermanagh were beaten by Meath. Derry will face Fermanagh next, with Down playing against Cork. Key moments included Danny Tallon scoring two goals for Derry, but Cork's forward line proved too strong. In another match, Down struggled against Galway, conceding two quick goals in the second half. Meath dominated against Fermanagh, securing a comfortable win. Additional match results from various divisions were also provided.

Laura Whitford and her friend Anne Walls decorated Royston's centre with crocheted nets and bunting to promote a craft fair. The items went missing multiple times but were mysteriously returned, with some found on a bank roof and in trees. Despite the disruptions, Whitford expressed gratitude towards the vandals as the situation inadvertently boosted publicity for the fair.

Former Scotland centre Sean Lineen joins English Championship club London Scottish as director of rugby, with retired player Roddy Grant as forwards coach. The partnership aims to prevent London Scottish from being relegated and strengthen Scottish rugby development. Players from Pro12 clubs Edinburgh and Glasgow Warriors will be based at London Scottish for competitions. London Scottish chairman David Reid emphasizes the collaboration's benefits and ambition for success. Lineen works part-time at London Scottish while maintaining his role with Scottish Rugby, overseeing various aspects of player support and recruitment. Grant, a former Scotland A player, joins the coaching team for the season. Scottish players already on loan at London Scottish include Rory Hughes and Scottish Rugby Academy players.

Transport Minister Edwina Hart aims to streamline the transportation system and reduce fraud by introducing new measures. Tough guidelines introduced in 2013 to combat abuse were suspended by Neath Port Talbot council due to complaints of genuine cases being rejected. Various local authorities observed an increase in rejections after being instructed to not solely rely on evidence from GPs. A consultation has been initiated on Welsh ministers' latest proposals.

Mr. Dickie Bird, a revered cricket umpire from Barnsley, who received an OBE for his services to the game, retired in 1998 and established the Dickie Bird Foundation, which provides grants to underprivileged children to buy sports equipment. His foundation aims to keep kids active and away from negative influences. Other notable honorees in South Yorkshire include retired chief constable Med Hughes appointed CBE, world taekwondo champion Sarah Stevenson awarded an MBE for her contributions to martial arts, and Christine Manby appointed OBE for her work with South Yorkshire's Women's Royal Voluntary Service.

Three individuals, Scott Falconer, Bruce Owens, and Cameron Henry, were responsible for causing £40,000 worth of damage at a city cemetery in July 2011, where racist remarks and slogans were maliciously spray painted on headstones. The culprits were caught after police received incriminating pictures. At Glasgow Sheriff Court, they were ordered to carry out 126 hours of unpaid work. Sheriff Alayne Swanson condemned their actions as "absolutely disgusting." Owens admitted to kicking over and damaging headstones in addition to spray painting, while Falconer and Henry also pleaded guilty to maliciously spray painting racist remarks. The vandalism included swastikas, "white power" slogans, and smashed glass. The perpetrators were identified through photographs and further investigations.

Luke Robertson, 30, is undertaking the Due South journey to the South Pole, raising money for charity after surviving brain surgery. He faces extreme conditions, dragging 110kg of equipment unassisted and unsupported. He will consume 6,500 calories daily, cook freeze-dried food, and plans to spend Christmas on the South Pole. Having raised over £34,000 for Marie Curie, he experienced delays due to adverse weather but has finally started his trek. His journey can be followed on social media and his website.

A 57-year-old was threatened with a knife by a man on a footpath in Ferguslie at 07:55. The suspect demanded money and possessions but ran off when the victim refused, heading towards Abbey Nursery and Millarston Park. The suspect, described as about 6ft tall, was wearing a home-made balaclava with a blue beanie hat pulled down over his face with slits for his eyes. Police are seeking information from witnesses and are particularly interested in speaking to the driver of an old silver style Polo that was in the area at the time.

Industry experts, including previous winners like James McAvoy and Tom Hardy, are part of the jury for the 2016 award. The focus is on recognizing standout performances and supporting both newcomers and established actors. The jury aims to select nominees who have made a significant impact on screen, regardless of the type of role or film.
