The winner will be announced at the EE British Academy Film Awards in February after public voting.

15-year-old Jackson Page from Ebbw Vale in Blaenau Gwent surprised many by playing professional snooker at the Welsh Open, ultimately losing to Judd Trump. Despite his young age, Page is dedicated to his sport, with his parents fully supporting his ambitions. He is skipping school to pursue snooker opportunities and aims to turn professional by winning competitions. Local player Mark Williams has been mentoring Page, who remains focused and eager to learn from experienced players. Page's parents express immense pride and love for their son's achievements, highlighting their unwavering support.

Fires on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo, caused by slash-and-burn clearances, are annually plaguing Southeast Asia. Paper and palm oil companies are often held responsible for these fires. Indonesia has deployed military personnel to combat the blazes and declared a state of emergency in Riau province due to hazardous pollution levels. Schools in Malaysia have closed, and Singapore residents are advised to limit outdoor activities.

The Scotland national team squad for upcoming matches against Canada and Slovenia includes first-time call-ups for Ryan Fraser and Tom Cairney, as well as recalls for Allan McGregor and Jordan Rhodes. The squad also features experienced players like Scott Brown and includes players in good form such as Stuart Armstrong. Manager Gordon Strachan believes the new additions will bring freshness to the team. The squad encompasses a mix of players from various clubs, with Jordan Rhodes earning his place after impressing on loan at Sheffield Wednesday.

A Tennessee singer started her career with a lovelorn ballad that led to immense success, selling over 100 million albums, winning eight Grammy Awards, and topping the country chart 25 times. At 70, she remains prolific, having written over 3,000 songs, with her latest album focusing on love songs inspired by her 50th wedding anniversary. The singer discusses her long-lasting marriage, daily songwriting process, admiration for Adele, and the romantic themes in her new record.

Paul Clement, a 44-year-old former Chelsea and Real Madrid assistant manager, is set to become Swansea City's third manager of the season. He is likely to be in charge for their upcoming game against Crystal Palace. Clement was interviewed by the club before Bob Bradley was appointed in October. Swansea, currently at the bottom of the Premier League table, have struggled with a string of defeats. Formerly in charge of Derby County, Clement was sacked in February 2016. Ryan Giggs, Chris Coleman, and Gary Rowett were also considered for the managerial position.

Concerns have been raised about the health status of the elderly population in England, with variations in life expectancies across regions. While life expectancy among older age groups has generally been increasing, there was a fall in life expectancy in some groups between 2011 and 2012. In 2014, male and female life expectancies rose at certain ages, except in the North East region where male life expectancy did not increase. A positive national trend was noted, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a good quality of life in later years. It was highlighted that lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking and being more active, can lead to healthier aging. The need to investigate why improvements have stalled in some regions was emphasized. In Scotland, life expectancy is improving, although there are also regional variations.

New figures reveal a concerning increase in the number of children at significant risk of exploitation in Cardiff, with cases of trafficking across Wales also on the rise. Despite these figures, experts believe many cases go unrecorded. A task force established by Cardiff council highlights an increase in trafficking and sexual exploitation cases, with challenges such as a two-year waiting list for post-traumatic stress help and insufficient support for victims. NGOs like Barnardo's and Bawso play crucial roles in aiding victims, with a focus on raising awareness and improving training for professionals. A case study of a young girl named Mary exemplifies the brutal reality of trafficking, underscoring the urgent need for collaborative efforts between police, councils, and charities to combat this pervasive issue in the region and beyond.

The relationship between Gareth Bale and Cristiano Ronaldo has been under media scrutiny, but both players maintain there is no rift. Bale and Ronaldo, along with Karim Benzema, have formed a successful attacking trio at Real Madrid. Bale, who became the world's most expensive footballer in 2013, emphasizes the focus on their team's performance rather than individual dynamics. Both players have dismissed rumors of discord. Bale's three goals have propelled Wales to their first major tournament semi-final since 1958, with Bale expressing belief in Wales' championship potential. Bale is glad to be part of Wales' success after enduring taunts during Real Madrid's struggles. Bale has brought his Real physiotherapist to aid his fitness at the Euro 2016 tournament.

Michael Waldman, a 53-year-old resident of Ashford, Kent, tragically lost his life in a collision between his Kawasaki ZX-6R motorcycle and a Seat Ibiza on the B2096 near Netherfield. The incident occurred while Waldman was traveling towards Battle with three other motorcyclists on a Sunday. The driver of the Seat, a 30-year-old woman from Sedlescombe, escaped unhurt in the crash.

A 73-year-old man from Dalkeith, Mr. Davidson, was reported missing on April 26, prompting an extensive search. Tragically, his body was found in the River North Esk three days later, with police ruling out any suspicious circumstances. Both his family and the police expressed gratitude for the community's support and assistance during this difficult time.

Gloucester City Council has introduced new powers in response to complaints of drug use and aggressive begging in the city centre. Public Space Protection Orders (PSPO) will ban begging and public nuisance, with fines or prosecution for offenders. Some individuals claim a lack of support, while officials urge those needing help to engage with available services. An awareness campaign aims to promote understanding of support for rough sleepers.

David Leyonhjelm is a former veterinarian and Liberal Democratic senator from New South Wales who holds a key role in the unpredictable upper house of federal parliament. Known for his libertarian views, he has been criticized for his controversial statements and behavior, including being labeled as "the nastiest, most sexist politician in Australia." Leyonhjelm advocates for free speech, opposes section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act, and strongly defends the rights of licensed firearm owners. He has faced backlash for his comments on various issues, including gun laws and the death of journalist Rebecca Wilson. Despite being a divisive figure, Leyonhjelm has maintained his position on key issues such as immigration, same-sex marriage, lower taxes, and assisted suicide.

Finnair has cancelled 16 domestic flights due to strikes against government cutbacks, affecting public transportation in Finland. Ferries to Sweden and Estonia remain operational. Strikes stem from collapsed talks on a collective agreement over wages and working hours. The Finnish Prime Minister announced plans to revive the economy, including cutbacks on benefits and overtime pay. Protests are expected in Helsinki.
England secured their first Women's World Cup knockout win by defeating Norway with goals from Steph Houghton and Lucy Bronze. The victory sets up a quarter-final clash against Canada in Vancouver.

Luke Durbin, 19, went missing after a night out in Ipswich on 11 May 2006. No one has been charged in connection with the case. His mother, Nicki Durbin, has offered a reward in hopes of finding answers. The reward has been put up jointly by the family, Crimestoppers, Suffolk Police, and local publications. The police are looking to identify a white or silver Volvo 440 seen in CCTV footage, as well as seeking information from the public.

Farooq Shah, 21, of London, was sentenced to a minimum of 28 years for stabbing Mariana Popa to death in Redbridge. Ms. Popa was a young mother and pregnant at the time of her murder. Shah was also sentenced to six years for robbery prior to the murder. CCTV footage showed the attack, leading to Shah's arrest. Ms. Popa's tragic death left her daughter without a mother, and Shah showed no remorse for his actions.

Operation Equinox is investigating decades of reported sexual, physical, and emotional abuse from the 1940s to the 1990s. Nottinghamshire Police stated that 530 out of 636 reported crimes occurred on council property, with 485 alleged offences involving council staff. Of 432 suspects, 283 have been identified. The operation is a combination of two previous inquiries: Operation Daybreak, which focused on the Beechwood children's home, and Operation Xeres, which looked into other residential homes. Progress has been reported, including the imprisonment of former social worker Andris Logins for 20 years. The police have had 290 individuals report crimes so far, and there are ongoing trials related to historical attacks. Nottinghamshire Police has not provided further comments due to the investigation being ongoing.

Russian hackers, known as Fancy Bears, have been exposing emails and medical records related to doping in sports, particularly targeting athletes with therapeutic use exemptions (TUEs). The leaks have been linked to Russian state-sponsored doping and aim to discredit athletes and organizations. The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) has been a major target of the hackers. While Wada officials emphasize the importance of the TUE system in sports, critics question its widespread use and legitimacy. The leaks have sparked controversy and led to actions to protect athletes' privacy and integrity.

The Cube in Corby, a £48m building with completed fourth floor office space for rent, houses various facilities including council offices, a library, theater, and register office. Initially opened in 2010 with issues such as a leaking roof and a criticized helical staircase, improvements have been made to the building. The project faced cost overruns, with the Labour council leader acknowledging responsibility for them. Despite controversy and criticism, current Conservative opposition leader praises The Cube as a symbol of Corby's ambition. A recent settlement was reached by a council officer who blew the whistle on the project's escalating costs. The building is seen as a catalyst for further development in the town center.

The 2015 Spending Review may pose a threat to college budgets, with potential cuts looming. Labour has highlighted the possible impact of a 25% reduction, estimating significant losses for further education and sixth-form colleges. Shadow education secretary Lucy Powell criticized the government for jeopardizing post-16 education quality and opportunities. The Sixth Form Colleges Association expressed concerns over potential closures, while FE college staff have faced financial challenges, including a pay freeze. The government aims to reform further education to align with local labor market needs, ensuring quality courses for young people, amid calls for stable investment and adequate funding to prevent further cuts in post-16 education.

The incident occurred during an economic event "Make in India" at Chowpatty Beach, where a fire broke out under the stage while dancers continued their act above. VIPs, including the state chief minister, had to signal the dancers to stop. The fire, caused by a short circuit, was quickly controlled and fortunately, no injuries were reported.

Construction work on drainage in areas between junctions 12 and 13 of the A55 will begin in autumn pending landowner approval, following flooding on Boxing Day. Additionally, a £1.9m scheme in Tal-y-Bont is set to start in spring to address flooding issues. First Minister Carwyn Jones visited the affected areas and apologized for not stopping during a previous visit. He assured that flood alleviation measures are being implemented to reduce future risks, emphasizing the need to enhance road resilience on the A55 for safety and improved infrastructure.

President Trump referenced the need for strengthened security measures and criticized Democrats for obstructing his plans in the wake of twin terrorist attacks in Spain. He sparked controversy by promoting a debunked myth involving the use of pig's blood to deter terrorism, while facing criticism for his response to recent attacks and hate crimes, including the events in Charlottesville.

The Health Minister of Brazil announced that pregnant women will be prioritized for Zika testing. Brazil is experiencing the largest Zika outbreak, which is linked to birth defects. The government is allocating extra funds to expedite vaccine development. The main preventive measure currently is eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Over 3,530 babies have been born with microcephaly, a birth defect, since October. The US confirmed its first case of a baby born with brain damage due to Zika in Hawaii. Pregnant women are advised to avoid traveling to affected countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. Zika is transmitted by mosquitoes of the Aedes species.

Former business secretary Lord Mandelson criticized Labour for not having a strong alternative to Chancellor George Osborne's Northern Powerhouse initiative, calling it a "political mistake." He highlighted a lack of radical election policies to rebalance the economy and political system, while acknowledging that Osborne's strategy was appealing to voters. Mandelson expressed frustration that Labour failed to develop devolution policies he initiated in government, allowing the Tories to gain a political advantage. He emphasized the importance for Labour to catch up and create a coherent strategy to compete with the Northern Powerhouse. Mandelson is a candidate for the position of University of Manchester chancellor, citing the city's exciting developments as part of the Northern Powerhouse initiative.

A 70-foot finback whale, weighing approximately 80 tonnes, washed up dead on a Sussex beach 150 years ago and was bought by Cambridge University for display. The whale was temporarily removed from display during a museum renovation in 2013. It took two people four weeks to re-assemble and re-hang the massive skeleton, which will be showcased in a new glass display area when the museum reopens next summer.

The National Audit Office found that the General Practice Extraction Service (GPES) cost £40m to set up instead of the planned £14m. The system was intended to share data from GP systems in England but has only provided information to NHS England. The NAO stated that the current form of GPES is unlikely to deliver its intended purpose, which is to gather valuable health data from GP surgeries for research and monitoring. Despite running over budget and being delivered late, GPES began providing data to NHS England in April of the previous year. However, universities and other organizations have not received data due to extraction delays. The Health and Social Care Information Service, responsible for GPES, acknowledged shortcomings in the system's procurement and design and is working on improvements.

The quarter-final draw for the Women's FA Cup sees Chelsea hosting Sunderland, Manchester City facing Bristol City, Liverpool playing Notts County, and Birmingham taking on Arsenal. Arsenal defeated Tottenham 10-0 in the previous round, while other matches included local derbies and notable debuts, with all home teams progressing. The winning clubs in the quarter-finals will receive £4,000 each, and the final will be held at Wembley on 13th May.

Jose Mourinho's Chelsea team suffered a 3-1 defeat against Liverpool, leading to widespread social media mockery and discussions about Mourinho's potential sacking. Despite only a small percentage of tweets mentioning both "Mourinho" and "sack," the public interest in the situation was evident through the high volume of related tweets. Various individuals, including golfer Rory McIlroy and YouTube personality Spencer Owen, chimed in with their opinions and jokes. Mourinho's post-match news conference, where he avoided key questions, further fueled social media discussions, with the hashtag #Nothingtosay gaining traction. Overall, the defeat and subsequent reactions highlighted the intense scrutiny and pressure facing Mourinho and Chelsea.

The former head of World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada), David Howman, expressed concerns about the increasing number of children doping to reach elite levels due to the growing profitability of sports. He mentioned that drug testing is limited in non-elite events, making teenagers vulnerable to doping. Howman also highlighted varying levels of cheating across different sports and mentioned that a significant portion of cheats go undetected. He raised concerns about young athletes being influenced by coaches, trainers, and parents to take shortcuts for success. Additionally, Howman suggested that doping could become a criminal offense in the future. Despite improvements in anti-doping measures, challenges remain in catching all offenders, as seen in cases like Nigerian weightlifter Chika Amalaha and the ongoing scrutiny surrounding events like the Tour de France. Howman emphasized the need for increased resources and funding for anti-doping efforts to combat the issue effectively.

Davide Nicola successfully saved Crotone from relegation by winning six out of their final nine matches in the Serie A season. Despite facing personal tragedy with the loss of his son three years ago, Nicola achieved his goal and raised awareness about road safety. He made a deal with his players after their first away win and led the team to finish two points clear of the relegation zone. Nicola's determination and team's efforts led to Crotone's survival in their debut top-flight campaign.

The IAAF doping review board has approved seven Russian athletes, including world champions Sergey Shubenkov and Mariya Kuchina, for neutral status due to meeting exceptional eligibility criteria. Russia was banned from international athletics in 2015 for doping allegations and did not participate in the 2016 Olympics. Despite the country not having a team at the upcoming World Championships in London, these athletes may now defend their titles. In total, 12 Russian athletes have been cleared to compete as neutrals, with their participation depending on event organizers' approval.

Armed police were called to Highcliffe School in Christchurch due to a report of firearm offences, leading to an emergency lockdown. However, the school has since reopened as a 26-year-old man was de-arrested at the scene and air pellets were found. There was no risk to students or staff, and no injuries were reported. Police have completed a searched and reassurance patrols, with the investigation ongoing.

Summary: Police conducted early-morning raids in Lancashire, Tyne and Wear, and Worcestershire, rescuing eight women trafficked from Romania for prostitution. The arrests included seven men and one woman suspected of conspiring to traffic for sexual exploitation. The operation targeted a Romanian organized crime group involved in trafficking, with authorities emphasizing the ongoing prevalence of modern slavery and exploitation of vulnerable women and girls.

The state of California is facing a gasoline price surge, with prices hitting $5.69 a gallon in some areas, $1.20 above the state average. Pollution regulations requiring a special fuel blend during the summer have exacerbated the situation. Officials assure that there is enough gasoline to meet demand despite supply challenges. Some independent petrol station operators have closed down pumps due to higher supply costs, while Costco temporarily closed 14 stations. The California Air Resources Board is considering a request to switch to winter-blend fuel earlier. California's average fuel price has surpassed Hawaii, standing at $4.49 per gallon. Various disruptions, including a Chevron refinery fire and a pipeline shutdown, have contributed to the price increase.

Dogs are being trained to assist individuals with disabilities, such as autism, by helping with daily tasks and providing emotional support and companionship. For example, Phoebe, an eight-year-old girl with autism, feels calmer and more relaxed with her assistance dog, CJ, in crowded places like supermarkets. These specially trained dogs can open doors, collect mail, and even guide their owners at pedestrian crossings.

Gianfranco Zola, a former Chelsea player, has replaced Gary Rowett as the manager of Birmingham City, prompting mixed reactions from fans and observers. Despite acknowledging the challenges posed by Rowett's successful tenure, Zola is focused on guiding the team back to the Premier League. Brighton manager Chris Hughton expressed surprise at the managerial change and praised Rowett's achievements. Former Blues defender Michael Johnson spoke highly of Zola's credentials but noted his demanding nature. Zola aims to build a successful team and earn acceptance from players and fans alike.

NUT Cymru's Freedom of Information requests revealed that the average number of assaults in Welsh schools is eight per day, prompting concerns from the union about the need for action from schools, councils, and the Welsh Government. A teacher's anonymous account of being physically assaulted by a student highlights the severity of the issue. Pembrokeshire council had the highest number of incidents, with efforts made to improve reporting and support for staff. The union questions variations in reporting methods among local authorities and calls for a standardized approach to address and prevent assaults. Officials emphasize the disruptive effects of assaults on teachers and classroom environments. Responses from a head teacher and a Conservative education spokesman stress the importance of discipline, teacher support, and interventions to address behavioral issues in schools.

In a rugby match between Glasgow Warriors and Dragons, Simone Favaro scored a crucial try with the last move of the game, securing a win for Glasgow. Other try-scorers included Chris Fusaro, Zander Fagerson, and Junior Bulumakau for Glasgow, and Rynard Landman and Ashton Hewitt for the Dragons. Glasgow showed strength in depth, with key players returning from injury and making debut appearances. The Dragons put up a good fight, but errors behind the scrum cost them dearly. Favaro redeemed himself with a late try after being sin-binned earlier. Glasgow ultimately emerged victorious, with coach Gregor Townsend praising the team's resilience.

Cheltenham Town secured a dominating victory over Bromley, with on-loan striker Holman and Danny Wright both scoring braces in the game. Alex Wall scored a consolation goal for Bromley, but Cheltenham's performance was praised by manager Gary Johnson for their attacking prowess and creativity. With this win, Cheltenham remains second in the National League table, just one point behind Forest Green Rovers, while Bromley drops to 14th after a string of poor results.

Dumfries and Galloway Council, Stena Line, and the McKinney Group have partnered to develop detailed proposals for the regeneration of the East Pier in Stranraer. The project aims to introduce new retail, leisure, and housing facilities, complementing previous investments in the waterfront area. The collaboration is seen as a positive step forward by local officials and stakeholders, with plans to engage the Scottish government for additional support. The partners are enthusiastic about the project's potential to benefit the community and boost growth in the region.

The council approved a £150m project at East Tullos for an incinerator to reduce non-recyclable waste sent to landfill. The Scottish government did not see it as a national concern. Despite concerns from some community councils and campaigners about pollution and traffic congestion on Wellington Road, the project, aimed to provide heat for nearby homes, received approval from the city council with a vote of 23 to 14. The plant is set to open in 2021.

Twilio, a technology "unicorn" valued at over $1 billion, recently had a successful IPO, with shares closing over $28, more than double the initial price of $15. Its platform allows developers to integrate phone calls and text messages into their apps, with clients like OpenTable, WhatsApp, and Uber. This has boosted investor confidence in the US tech sector, and analysts predict a positive impact on other unicorns considering going public.

In Ipswich, two men, Constantinescu and Gheorghe, were found guilty of assaulting a woman in her 20s as she walked along Rope Walk. The men were described as "predators" by the judge and were sentenced for their "callous" actions. The victim still experiences nightmares and lives in fear following the attack. Constantinescu and Gheorghe targeted the woman after their advances in clubs were unsuccessful, dragging her into a car park where they used unnecessary violence before abandoning her with significant injuries. They attempted to evade CCTV cameras and change their appearance to flee the country before being arrested.

The Department of Homeland Security stated that recent hacked emails are in line with Russia-directed efforts, with data from discussions within the Democratic Party being compromised. Probing attempts on election-related systems were reported by some states, but these could not be directly linked to the Russian government. Despite Russian officials denying involvement, a joint statement from Homeland Security and the Director of National Intelligence indicated high-ranking Kremlin officials were likely behind the cyber attacks. They emphasized that altering actual ballots or election results would be challenging due to the decentralized system in place. The hacked emails revealed bias against Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary race, leading to the resignation of party chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz. US officials, including Adam Schiff, raised concerns about foreign interference in democratic institutions and called for cooperation with European allies to respond.

Two-man teams from 16 nations will compete in a golf tournament at St Albans' Centurion Club for a prize fund of one million euros. The event will feature amphitheatre-style stands, music, pyrotechnics, and player interaction with fans. The format aims to modernize golf and attract a younger audience. The teams will be split into groups on day one, with the top two progressing to the knockout stages. Matches will be played in a greensomes, match-play format, with teams earning points for each hole won. Countries will be represented by their top European Tour member, who will choose a teammate.

The Battle, also known as the Third Battle of Ypres, took place from July to November 1917, resulting in 500,000 casualties among Allied and German soldiers. Various individuals shared stories of their ancestors who participated in the battle, including Second Lieutenant Philip Duncan and Sergeant William John Timbley who survived, Private Maurice Walter Barnett and Private James Kelly who were killed in action, and Richardson Robson Flinn who was wounded. Gunner William Potterton also died in action and is commemorated at Tyne Cot Cemetery. These stories highlight the personal sacrifices and impact of the Battle of Passchendaele on individual soldiers and their families.

The Hampshire County Men's Final between Southsea Waverley and Boscombe Cliff was marred by a dispute over "bowls etiquette," leading to a Boscombe player attempting a headbutt, resulting in the team conceding the match. Waverley retained their county champions title. Both clubs expressed dismay over the incident, with Waverley's secretary emphasizing that the behavior was unacceptable. Bowls Hampshire confirmed the incident and is awaiting statements before deciding on further actions. Hampshire Constabulary has not received any reports regarding the incident.

A 36-year-old individual is set to appear in Edinburgh Sheriff Court following a gunshot incident in Dalkeith. No injuries were reported, and the property on Woodburn Road showed no damage. Police conducted searches at two locations, resulting in the recovery of a firearm. Police emphasize that it was an isolated incident with no ongoing threats. A prompt arrest was made, and the community's assistance is appreciated. Police assert a zero-tolerance policy towards firearm offenses and vow to bring any involved individuals to justice.

An Icelandic court convicted Sigurjon Arnason of market manipulation related to the 2008 financial crisis, alongside other former banking executives. The banks involved collapsed after acquiring assets significantly larger than Iceland's economy. Arnason's sentence included a suspended portion, while his colleagues received shorter prison terms. Iceland has taken a unique approach by sentencing top executives for their roles in the crisis, with the heaviest sentence going to Hreidar Mar Sigurdsson. Former prime minister Geir Haarde was found guilty of negligence but did not receive jail time.

Jean Charles de Menezes, a Brazilian electrician, was tragically shot and killed by police officers at Stockwell Tube station in London on 22 July 2005. He had moved to the UK in 2002, aiming to earn money and support his family back home. Mistaken for a suicide bomber, he was shot multiple times by officers who were conducting a surveillance operation in the aftermath of the 7 July 2005 bombings. Despite efforts from campaigners, no officers were prosecuted for his death, but the Metropolitan Police were fined for breaching health and safety laws in the operation that led to the shooting.

Christie, aged 20, recently signed with Celtic from Inverness Caledonian Thistle, where he was a key player under John Hughes. Despite facing tough competition at Celtic, he remains focused on working hard to earn his place in the team. In a recent match against his former team, Celtic won 3-0 after a shaky first half, with Christie reflecting on the experience of playing against his old teammates. He acknowledges the need to start over and is pleased with his progress in making appearances for Celtic.

Tony De Brum, a prominent advocate for small island states' rights and a key figure in the Paris climate negotiations, passed away at his home in the Marshall Islands. Witnessing the devastating impact of US nuclear bomb tests as a child fueled his political awakening, leading him to champion independence and compensation for impacted communities. De Brum's diplomatic skills and personal relationships helped establish the "high ambition coalition," crucial in achieving the Paris Agreement goal of limiting global temperature increases to 1.5C. Tributes have poured in, crediting De Brum with shaping the climate agreement and safeguarding our shared future.

The journals, penned by sailors aboard HMS Trincomalee, a historic vessel built in 1817 now moored in Hartlepool, have been discovered and will be integrated into the new National Museum of the Royal Navy. HMS Trincomalee, originally constructed in India, was brought to Hartlepool in 1987 and restored over a decade, becoming a popular attraction drawing 54,000 visitors annually. The journals, dating back to 1852 and including the log of midshipman William Dawson, will eventually be featured in the Trincomalee exhibition in Hartlepool. The partnership with the NMRN in Portsmouth aims to raise public awareness of the vessel's significance and its seafaring history, showcasing the story of the Royal Navy on a national level.

The conflict in Syria involves soldiers supporting President Bashar al-Assad against rebel groups who oppose his rule. A recent chemical weapons attack killing at least 72 people has shocked world leaders. The UK, rebel commander, and weapons expert believe it was carried out by Syrian government forces, which denies involvement. Russia backs the Syrian government. The incident has sparked international concern about the use of chemical weapons in the conflict.

- The Children's Book Award and Kate Greenaway Medal shortlists feature notable authors and illustrators.
- The Children's Book shortlist includes works such as "The Lie Tree" by Frances Hardinge and "The Rest of Us Just Live Here" by Patrick Ness.
- The Kate Greenaway Medal shortlist includes illustrations by artists like Anthony Browne and Chris Riddell.
- Notable books on the shortlists include "One" by Sarah Crossan and "Lies We Tell Ourselves" by Robin Talley.
- Winners will be announced on June 20 at the British Library, with cash prizes awarded for each medal.
- Additionally, one title from each shortlist will receive the Amnesty CILIP honour for celebrating freedom in their work.
More than 30,000 local and international artists performed at the event, which was produced by Vikas Pandey and filmed and edited by Devashish Kumar.

Seven Cameroon players initially expressed their desire not to participate in the upcoming tournament in Gabon. This decision could have led to a ban from club football during the competition. However, their non-selection in the final squad has resolved a potential conflict between club and country. Cameroon, coached by Hugo Broos, will compete in Group A against Gabon, Burkina Faso, and Guinea-Bissau. Nyom and Afobe are among the players who chose not to participate. The final Cameroon squad includes players like Ondoa, Nkoulou, Aboubakar, and Bassogog.

Actress Honeysuckle Weeks, known for her role in ITV drama, has been missing since Thursday in West Sussex. Police are concerned for her welfare as she was last seen in Chichester and had expressed feeling anxious. She has links in London and family in Wiltshire. Earlier this year, she was caught speeding and ordered to wear an electronic tag. Her agency is unable to reach her. Weeks has a history in TV shows like Foyle's War and has recently worked on shows like Lewis and The Five. She is described as 5ft 4in with cropped gingery blonde hair, and was last seen in a blue anorak and faded blue jeans.

A group of boys and girls aged between 11 and 14 went missing during a practice hike in Carrbridge. They were found by a Coastguard helicopter at a remote bothy, where they had sought shelter after getting lost. The scouts had lit a fire to keep warm as weather conditions worsened. The group's scouting training played a crucial role in their safety. They were airlifted back to their camp and reunited with their peers. The operation to locate them involved multiple partners and their preparedness with maps, food, and water contributed to their safe rescue.

The UK government is planning to introduce a road usage charge for foreign lorries on British roads, which will be offset by a reduction in vehicle excise duty for UK-based lorries. This move aims to create a fair playing field for British hauliers who have to pay to use roads in Europe. The charge will be based on the size of the vehicle and is expected to generate £20 million annually. The government intends to introduce the charge by the end of the current parliamentary term. The announcement has been welcomed by the transportation industry as a way to boost UK competitiveness and support growth.

Glasgow City Council plans to increase council tax by 3% due to a budget shortfall of £67m. This increase is expected to raise over £7m and help protect frontline services. Other councils in Scotland are yet to confirm their plans, with a third considering a similar increase. The average council tax bill in Glasgow is £1,213 (Band D), and changes this year will result in higher bills for properties in bands E to H. Labour-led councils are weighing the decision to increase taxes to mitigate cuts or freeze them to avoid asking for more from residents. The Scottish government will provide more funds for local services in the next financial year. The final decision on Glasgow's council tax is expected in February.

Coral reefs are important underwater structures made of living coral. Scientists were surprised to discover a coral reef in the muddy Amazon, typically found in clear waters like the Great Barrier Reef. These reefs are home to various fish and marine animals, prompting research for new species using mini-submarines. Greenpeace emphasizes the significance of protecting these reefs for the environment.

Smith, head of the Scottish League Managers Association, believes the SPFL should address its main sponsor Ladbrokes regarding betting activities in football. SPFL commented that betting on manager sackings is not new and is part of the industry. Partick Thistle manager Archibald acknowledges the prevalence of such bets but emphasizes not dwelling on them to avoid added pressure. Managerial changes in Scottish football, including Ian Baraclough's departure from Motherwell, have sparked discussions on the influence of betting in the sport.

Geoffrey Clark, a UKIP candidate for Kent County Council and Gravesham Borough Council, faces backlash for proposing compulsory abortion for fetuses with disabilities to cut national debt. While UKIP has suspended him pending investigation, his personal manifesto has been widely criticized by Mencap and others. Clark calls for a national debate on NHS affordability and controversial measures for the elderly, including euthanasia. Mencap condemns his views, questioning his suitability for public office. UKIP disavows Clark's opinions and apologizes for any distress caused.

Martyn Ford, a UKIP candidate for the Welsh assembly, expressed support for devolution but lacks enthusiasm for granting further powers to Wales. He criticized the current use of the assembly's powers and emphasized that local parties will choose UKIP representatives for the upcoming elections, rejecting the notion of centrally imposed candidates. Ford highlighted the opportunity for UKIP to showcase discipline and benefit the people of Wales through constructive engagement in the assembly. He stressed the importance of representing voters' voices and rebuilding trust in the institution.

Willie Cameron, a hospitality business owner in the Highlands, believes the short-term benefit of a weakened pound due to the EU referendum is positive for the tourism industry, but the long-term impact is uncertain. A survey shows that some EU nationals may be less likely to visit the UK post-Brexit. Concerns include potential decrease in investment and visitor numbers, and impact on the workforce, as many tourism industry employees are from EU states. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit poses challenges for the Scottish tourism sector and its reliance on EU workers and visitors.

The Local Government Association is advocating for exercise prescriptions to combat the obesity crisis, suggesting activities such as visits to national parks or gardening sessions. Some GPs already provide these prescriptions, with initiatives including walks, conservation work, gardening, and sailing. The LGA is urging NHS Clinical Commissioning Groups to adopt this approach nationwide. Integration between health and community services is seen as crucial for the effectiveness of social prescribing schemes. Low levels of physical activity in England underscore the importance of encouraging more exercise to prevent and manage various chronic conditions.

Five-month-old Jack McLaren died in hospital on 4 June following an alleged attack. Daniel McLaren of Fleetwood Close in Newbury has been charged with murder and pleaded not guilty via video link from prison at Reading Crown Court. The trial is set to commence on 22 January 2018.

Chesterfield defeated Colchester United 2-1 in a close match. Jay O'Shea and Ched Evans scored for Chesterfield, while Tarique Fosu-Henry netted for Colchester. Several attempts were made by both teams, with key moments including Luke Prosser hitting the bar and Tom Anderson assisting Evans for his goal. Kurtis Guthrie and Drey Wright were active for Colchester, but they couldn't secure a win. Kristian Dennis and Liam O'Neil were replaced due to injuries during the game.

Malcolm Roberts, a senator from One Nation in Australia, is confident he can prove he is not a dual citizen, a disqualifying factor for holding federal office. He claims he took steps to renounce any potential British citizenship he may have had. The issue of dual citizenship has led to the resignation of three politicians in Australia, including two deputy Greens leaders and the Minister for Resources and Northern Australia. The Australian constitution prohibits individuals with dual citizenship from sitting in parliament, as interpreted by the High Court of Australia. Similar restrictions exist in other countries like Armenia, Egypt, the Philippines, Israel, and New Zealand.

Leicester Tigers have signed back-rower Kalamafoni, flanker Ryan, fly-half Joe Ford, and versatile player Jonah Holmes from Yorkshire Carnegie. Ford is the brother of England star George Ford. Kalamafoni has played in two World Cups for Tonga and is excited for the new challenge at Leicester Tigers. Ryan has one Ireland appearance, while Holmes started his career at Wasps.

Sustainable Shetland is seeking a judicial review of the Scottish government's approval for the development of a wind farm in Shetland, which would be the third largest in Scotland and run by community company Viking Energy. Protesters believe the project is too big and would harm the landscape, while supporters argue it would benefit the local economy, create jobs, and help meet renewable energy goals. The wind farm aims to power over 175,000 homes despite Shetland's population being around 22,000, potentially bringing in approximately £30 million annually for the community.

Jacqueline Sauvage, a victim of decades of abuse, was granted a complete pardon by President Hollande after initially receiving a partial pardon in January. She had been serving a 10-year sentence for murdering her abusive husband. Despite two earlier rejections for release by the courts, her pardon led to her immediate freedom. The decision was met with joy by campaigners and her family, but criticism was voiced by some, including the head of the French union of magistrates. Ms. Sauvage's case garnered significant public support, with over 434,000 signatures on a petition and backing from various politicians.

At the British Indoor Athletics Championships in Sheffield, Robertson won the men's 60m gold, while Asha Philip retained the women's title. Kilty was disqualified after a false start and expressed determination to compete in the upcoming European Indoor Championships. Dasaolu and Ujah did not participate. Philip secured automatic selection for the European Indoors. Andrew Pozzi equaled the fastest 60m hurdles time of the year. McColgan won the women's 3,000m, and Morgan Lake and Beth Partridge shared the high jump title. The remaining events will take place on Sunday and will be streamed live on BBC Sport.

The Adcocks advanced to the quarterfinals of the badminton championships by defeating Korean opponents. They will face Indonesia's Tontowi Ahmed and Liliyana Natsir, seeking to surpass their previous performance. Meanwhile, Marcus Ellis and Chris Langridge also progressed to the quarterfinals in the men's doubles and will compete against Korean top seeds for a spot in the semi-finals.

Researchers from the Open University are examining images captured by NASA's Messenger probe to study chains of depressions on Mercury called catenae. These formations are believed to have been created by comets breaking apart under tidal forces and impacting the planet. The presence of ices and volatile compounds in Mercury's polar craters suggests a history of comet impacts. The researchers are investigating if the orientation of certain catenae formations indicates the orbits of early comets in the Solar System. Despite the impending end of Messenger's mission, the next probe to Mercury, BepiColombo, is being prepared for launch in 2017.

Recent reports highlight instances of looting, property destruction, abductions, and killings in areas recaptured from the Islamic State group. Sunni Arabs in Iraq face discrimination and accusations of supporting IS, leading to challenges and human rights violations. Concerns have been raised about potential war crimes by Kurdish fighters in northern Syria. The UN is particularly concerned about 1,300 stranded Sunnis near Sinjar and has urged the Iraqi government to investigate reported abuses and mass graves.

Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner Mark Rowley announced that Portuguese police would lead the next phase of the investigation involving British officers into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann in 2007. Scotland Yard's Operation Grange, launched last July, aims to systematically explore credible leads. Rowley emphasized that they are working through all possibilities and that the collaboration with Portuguese authorities is strong. The investigation follows a review of the case and recent efforts to identify an intruder linked to several sexual assaults on UK girls in Portugal.

Mr Harding, speaking at the British Library, emphasized the BBC's public service duty to support local news amid the challenges faced by the local newspaper industry, attributing economic woes to the shift of classified advertising online. He acknowledged the impact of competitors like Google and Facebook on the industry. The Home Secretary also raised concerns about the BBC's influence on local news and its potential to harm local newspapers. Mr Harding stressed the BBC's commitment to serving license fee payers and retaining the public's trust through accuracy and impartiality. He highlighted the importance of press freedom and independence in the face of potential encroachment.

The musical Dreamgirls, which took 35 years to reach the West End, faced delays due to casting challenges and specific demands on lead actresses. The show, reminiscent of The Supremes, tells the story of a black female singing trio in 1960s America. Amber Riley, known for her role in Glee, plays the lead role of Effie White, receiving praise for her performance. Reviews highlight Riley's powerful vocals and the production's lively spirit, with some critics divided on its overall impact. Despite mixed reviews, Dreamgirls is expected to be a hit, boasting great costumes and energetic dancing. Notable figures such as Chris Colfer and Sir Lenny Henry attended the opening night, reflecting growing calls for more representation of BAME individuals in the entertainment industry.

The annual black santa sit-out event led by Rev Dr Houston McKelvey at St Anne's Cathedral in Belfast raises funds for charities in Northern Ireland, including Christian Aid. It is expected to be challenging economically and weather-wise. This year marks Dean McKelvey's last sit-out before retiring in April 2011, with a goal of raising additional funds through community support. The tradition, started by Dean Sammy Crooks in 1976, has raised millions over the years. Dean McKelvey plans to continue the sit-out until Christmas Eve, following in the footsteps of his predecessor Dean Jack Shearer, who was known as Black Santa for his distinctive attire.

The bank's Credit Conditions Survey revealed a continued decline in demand for mortgages, particularly for high-value properties. This trend was attributed to regulatory changes, concerns over housing affordability, and political uncertainty surrounding the UK general election. However, lenders foresee a rebound in demand in the second quarter. Notably, the upper market segment is most affected by the uncertainty, as prime and super-prime buyers are awaiting election outcomes before making purchasing decisions. Additionally, lenders are becoming more willing to lend to borrowers with smaller deposits, potentially benefiting first-time buyers.

In Uganda's recent general election, President Museveni won by a landslide despite strong opposition from main challenger Besigye. Besigye insists he was the rightful winner, but the top court upheld Museveni's victory. Besigye was charged with treason and arrested, leading to criticism from foreign observers about the poll's integrity. Museveni, who has ruled for 30 years, denies vote rigging accusations and accuses Besigye of inciting violence. The US called on Museveni to rein in security forces after they arrested Besigye and used tear gas on his supporters in Kampala. Critics view Museveni as increasingly authoritarian despite his credited stability efforts in Uganda.

Since 2005, the bridge in Oxford has been closed on May Day morning due to safety concerns after several people were injured jumping into the river. However, last year some individuals disregarded warnings and jumped from the bridge. The city and county councils, along with the police, have collaborated to ensure a safe May Morning event, with Magdalen Bridge being open for the celebrations this year. Additional activities will also be taking place across Oxford. Police urge the public to respect the decision to allow pedestrian access and enjoy the celebration responsibly.

Following an attack at a rural property in Devon, a number of weapons were seized by the police. The 24-year-old victim was treated at the scene and then transferred to a hospital. Leo Michaels, aged 35, has been charged with attempted murder and wounding with intent, and appeared in court where he was remanded in custody. The incident involved a man with a crossbow, and the victim had injuries consistent with being shot with a crossbow. Michaels is scheduled to appear at Exeter Crown Court on 18 August.

Ollie Hannon-Dalby and Keith Barker took four wickets each as Northants were dismissed for 273. James Kettleborough, Ben Duckett, Adam Rossington, and Andrew Hall contributed with half-centuries. Warwickshire closed at 79-1, with Varun Chopra on 43. Yorkshire's strong position against Nottinghamshire puts Warwickshire in contention for second place. Northants' young players showed promise, but their bowling needs improvement. Young talents like Rossington, Duckett, and Kettleborough offer hope for Northants' future campaigns.

A total of 3,740 people have died crossing the Mediterranean so far in a year, with the UN noting a threefold increase in the death rate compared to previous years. Despite a decrease in the number of people attempting the voyage, smugglers are using riskier tactics, such as organizing mass embarkations in bad weather, leading to more fatalities. The agreement between Turkey and the EU has reduced arrivals in Greek islands, but there has been an increase in dangerous journeys to Italy. Rescue services are overwhelmed due to the large scale of these operations.

The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is the world's largest annual consumer technology trade show, featuring over 3,500 companies this year. Top tech companies are showcasing their latest gadgets at the event. Highlights include a compact quadcopter for HD video, advanced 3D printers, self-driving cars, quantum dot TV technology, and unique products like a gaming toothbrush and a dog collar for communication. CES takes place from 6 to 9 January.

In Sao Tome and Principe, the cocoa industry faced a decline due to falling prices in the late 1990s, leaving many farmers in poverty. However, with the support of Ifad and Cafedirect, farmers formed co-operatives and began producing Fairtrade certified organic cocoa. This initiative led to a significant increase in cocoa production, providing small farmers with improved incomes and livelihoods. The co-operatives have allowed farmers to increase their profits by cutting out middlemen and investing in processing facilities. The success of the cocoa industry revival demonstrates the potential for sustainable agriculture practices on the islands.

Northern Lights is a showcase at the V&A Dundee featuring designers who have chosen to base their businesses in Scotland. The show includes a range of products, from hand-crafted wooden furniture to ceramic jewellery. The London Design Festival is a significant inspiration, and the exhibit offers the opportunity for designers to raise their profile internationally. The show at the V&A Dundee runs from 17 to 25 September, featuring leading contemporary Scottish design talent.

Fifty athletes from various countries participated in a marathon in Antarctica, enduring sub-zero temperatures with protective gear. The race took place near the South Pole at the foot of the Ellsworth Mountains. Additionally, a separate marathon featured six runners covering a hundred kilometers without stopping.

Morgan, 31, has played 52 games for the Latics since joining from Rotherham United in June 2015, with 23 international caps. He captained the team to the League One title last season, after previously leading Rotherham. Morgan expressed his commitment to stay, citing the chairman's support as a key factor in his decision.

European Council President Donald Tusk is keeping discussions on migration and terrorism separate, despite concerns about jihadists posing as migrants in the EU. The Schengen zone's passport-free area facilitates the flow of people, but also requires improved information-sharing to prevent cross-border criminality. Reimposed border controls by several countries highlight the need to regain control over external borders and preserve Schengen. Efforts are underway to enhance surveillance and database linking to strengthen border security. The EU faces challenges in managing the influx of refugees and migrants, particularly from Syria. A new EU Border and Coast Guard is proposed to address external border issues. Divisions within EU member states on sovereignty and human rights issues further complicate the response to the migrant crisis.

George North and Alex Cuthbert scored tries for the Lions in a 23-21 win against Australia in Brisbane. Kurtley Beale missed two late penalties that would have given Australia the victory. North described the win as remarkable and spoke about the team's momentum heading into the second Test. North's impressive solo try stood out in the match, although another potential try was disallowed. The Lions face Melbourne Rebels before the second Test, and North believes there is room for improvement despite the victory. Cuthbert expects a tough challenge from Australia in the upcoming Test.

A historic locomotive, Locomotive No 563, previously used on the London and South Western Railway, has been donated to the Swanage Railway by the National Railway Museum. Descendants of its designer William Adams were present at the unveiling ceremony in Corfe Castle. Volunteers will work on restoring the 86-tonne T3 locomotive with the goal of getting it back to steam. The locomotive had a long history of hauling express trains before being withdrawn from service in 1945. It survived being scrapped and was later used in stage adaptations of Edith Nesbit's classic and showcased in Canada and London.

Fishlock, at 30 years old, achieved a milestone by becoming the first Wales international player to earn 100 caps. In a match against Northern Ireland, she scored a crucial goal, with other goals by Georgia Evans and Natasha Harding for Wales, and Rachel Furness for Northern Ireland. Angharad James of Notts County Ladies also celebrated her 50th cap. The teams are playing two back-to-back matches as part of their preparation for the upcoming Fifa Women's World Cup Qualifying campaign. This is in anticipation of the World Cup tournament in France in 2019, with the draw set for April. The two teams will face each other again on April 7th at Ystrad Mynach.

Unwired Planet reaches a settlement with Apple just before their trial was set to begin over the use of tech in iPhones and iPads, seeking $33 million and a cut of sales. Unwired, considered a "patent troll" by some, acquired the rights to the patents from Ericsson in a controversial deal. The firm aims to bring efficiency and fairness to patent licensing. They have resolved various litigations and recently won a court case against Huawei in London over 4G patents, with ongoing disputes with other tech companies like Google and HTC.

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in the UK has published a report criticizing the asset management industry for weak price competition, leading to high charges for customers. The report highlights examples of poor value for money and suggests that consultants could yield better results for pension savers. The FCA calls for greater transparency in fees, proposing an all-in fee structure and standardized cost information across the sector. The report questions the value of actively-managed funds compared to passive funds that track the market, as lower charges could result in significantly higher returns. The Investment Association acknowledges the need for industry improvements and supports the FCA's objectives. The FCA's recommendations will undergo consultation, with potential actions expected to be announced next summer.

Plans for Peelhouses Farm near Lockerbie were first proposed in late 2008, granted planning permission in principle in 2010, and extended until 2013. Developers are now considering seeking further extensions and implementing the project in phases. The original concept included an £800 million investment and job creation, aiming to transform the site into an international internet hub. The current plans feature a data center, technology park, research facility, and visitor center, excluding the initial housing development proposal. Consultants are liaising with Dumfries and Galloway Council to discuss extending the permission timeframe set to expire later this year.

Prince Harry reported for duty in Australia as part of a military secondment with the Australian army, after serving in the British army for 10 years. He laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Australian Soldier and presented a letter from Queen Elizabeth II. During his placement, he will patrol with Aboriginal soldiers and train with special forces. The Queen emphasized the shared values between the British and Australian armies. Prince Harry is looking forward to the challenging experience, which includes a brief interruption for commemorations at Gallipoli before potentially doing charity work later in the year.

Liver disease deaths have significantly increased over the past two decades, mainly due to factors such as obesity, alcohol misuse, and viral hepatitis. With support from a £1m funding from the Welsh government, a new plan aims to enhance clinical expertise in liver disease and promote individual accountability for health.

The author of Women in Love, D.H. Lawrence, expressed disgust for Pangbourne while searching for cottages in 1919 due to unpleasant smells. The note to his friend Bertie Herbert Farjeon revealed his dissatisfaction with humanity, leading to his self-imposed exile from Britain three months later. Lawrence, known for works like Lady Chatterley's Lover, was born in 1885 and passed away in 1930 at the age of 44.

- Wales achieved a total of 35,537 exams this summer.
- In 2016, 6.6% of students in Wales achieved the new top grade A*, which is lower than the UK average of 8.1%.
- Wales trails behind the UK and most regions of England in A* and A grades.
- Welsh students excel in math but lag in English language compared to England.
- The percentage of students getting top grades in French is lower in Wales compared to England.
- There is a wider gap in top grades for A-level physics between Wales and England.
- 23.5% of Welsh students got D and E grades, slightly higher than 20.6% in England.
- Girls outperform boys in Wales, but there are differences in subject choices and performance.
- Wales has the lowest percentage of A*-C grades compared to all English regions.
- 23,740 students from Wales applied to universities in the UK this year, making a total of 40,010 applications.

The breaking news story is continuously being updated for more details. Readers can refresh the page for the latest information. Email and app alerts are available for those interested in receiving breaking news notifications.

German midfielder Marco Reus, 27, and fellow midfielder Bastian Schweinsteiger, 31, have had injury concerns but Schweinsteiger has been selected for the national team. Reus has been left out due to uncertain injury prognosis. Notable inclusions are Emre Can, Mesut Ozil, and Lukas Podolski, while Julian Brandt and Karim Bellarabi have been left out. The squad includes talented players across different positions, aiming for their first European title since 1996.

Eifion Gwynne, 41, who passed away recently, wished to be buried at Plascrug Cemetery in Aberystwyth. Initially faced with the issue of limited plots, a plot has now been transferred to his family by Ceredigion council. This enables Mr. Gwynne to be buried at the desired location on Saturday. A memorial fund in his name has raised nearly £12,000 in donations. The council leader expressed sympathy and confirmed assistance in making the plot available to honor Mr. Gwynne's wishes.

In his 300th Premier League appearance, Cesc Fabregas scored for Chelsea as they defeated Swansea. After Fabregas put Chelsea ahead, Fernando Llorente equalized for Swansea just before half-time. Chelsea regained the lead with goals from Pedro and Diego Costa. Chelsea's win marked their 10th consecutive home victory, keeping them on track for the Premier League title. Despite a penalty shout for Swansea, Chelsea's attacking play ultimately secured the win. Swansea's manager, Paul Clement, felt his team defended well but Chelsea's quality made the difference. Commentators differed on whether Chelsea should have conceded a penalty. Antonio Conte praised his team's performance and urged them to continue in the same vein, while Clement was disappointed with the result but acknowledged Chelsea's strength.

- Right-back Hodgkiss, 30, signed a two-year contract after spending last season on loan at Torquay.
- Forward Wilson, 24, agreed to a one-year contract.
- George Pilkington signed a new one-year deal, and David Fitzpatrick also agreed to terms with the National League club.
- Macclesfield lost defender John McCombe to Chester and midfielder Ollie Norburn to Tranmere.
- Manager Askey extended his stay for another season.

After a pre-season friendly between Grimsby Town and Sheffield United, a disturbance occurred at Blundell Park, Cleethorpes, resulting in four individuals being charged with assault, affray, and public order offenses. Two have been released on bail, and police are reviewing CCTV footage with more arrests anticipated. Humberside Police is considering football banning orders to prevent disruptive fans from attending future matches.

Jamal al-Harith, a British man formerly known as Ronald Fiddler, received £1m from the British government after being released from Guantanamo Bay in 2004. He was later identified as a jihadist who joined the Islamic State and carried out a suicide bombing in Mosul. Criticism arose over the compensation paid to him, with Lord Carlile calling it wrong as al-Harith was considered a terrorist. Former Prime Minister Tony Blair defended the decision to release al-Harith, stating it followed a parliamentary and media campaign. Others involved at the time, such as Lord Blunkett and Jack Straw, acknowledged the risks involved in releasing Guantanamo detainees but supported the decision. Al-Harith's older brother mentioned that his sibling struggled with the aftermath of his time in detention and ultimately carried out the suicide attack.

Dallas Police Chief David Brown, known for his efforts to improve community relations and reduce force, faced a difficult situation when a racially motivated attack by a black man targeted his officers. Despite personal tragedies, including the loss of his son and former partner, Brown remained committed to reforming the department through community policing and transparency. By 2014, excessive force complaints had significantly declined under his leadership. The night before the attack, the department's Twitter displayed officers interacting positively with protesters. Despite the tragedy, Brown emphasized the need for mutual respect and unity between police and citizens.

In summary, Donald Trump faces backlash from fellow Republicans over lewd remarks and divisive behavior, with Speaker Paul Ryan among those distancing themselves. Despite Trump's "unshackled" response and loyal support from some party members like Mike Pence, tensions within the Republican Party persist. A recent poll shows Hillary Clinton leading by 11 points, while Trump continues to make controversial statements and garner mixed reactions within the GOP. Despite calls for him to drop out of the race, some Republicans like Chris Christie, Ted Cruz, and Marco Rubio still stand by Trump. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus reaffirms the party's support for Trump, emphasizing unity despite the ongoing turmoil.

A 25-year-old tennis player, supported by his 'Will-bombs' fans, discusses the benefits of a program that offers sessions across the UK to improve tennis skills and become a better player. It encourages individuals to join and enhance their playing abilities.

About 150 people in Syria, including a 10-year-old boy, gathered near the interior ministry to demand the release of political prisoners. This protest followed a previous "day of rage" where hundreds called for democracy. Among those detained were a university professor, a human rights activist, and a journalist. The ruling Baath party, in power for nearly 50 years, does not tolerate dissent, and President Bashar al-Assad has been slow to implement reforms. There are thousands of political prisoners in Syrian jails, and major opposition groups are banned. The government restricts access to the internet and tightly controls the media. Despite these challenges, recent events suggest a growing willingness to protest against the regime.

Danny Murphy discussed Jermain Defoe's role in Sunderland's important victory against Newcastle, highlighting Defoe's adaptation to playing on the right wing despite his preference for a central role as a goalscorer. Murphy praised Defoe's defensive efforts and noted his match-winning goal as a demonstration of his varied skill set. He emphasized Defoe's importance as a key player for Sunderland's survival in the Premier League, attributing their potential success to his contributions. Additionally, Murphy commended Sunderland's overall physicality and work rate, suggesting that they have the qualities necessary to avoid relegation.

Prosecutors accuse Fifa president Sepp Blatter of making a $2m "disloyal payment" to Mr. Platini, who denies wrongdoing and still aims to run for Fifa president. The Swiss attorney general stated that Platini was investigated both as a witness and an accused person. The payment to Platini in 2011, funded by Fifa, has raised suspicion due to its timing before Blatter's presidential campaign. Additionally, allegations of an "unfavourable" contract signed by Blatter have added to the ongoing corruption investigations at Fifa.

A study by the Future Leaders Trust found that the geographic distance between schools in England significantly impacts the academic performance of poorer pupils. The research showed that as the distance between schools increased, the attainment of pupils eligible for free school meals declined, with a 1-2km gap resulting in less than 42% achieving good results. Urban schools closer in proximity benefited from easier collaboration among teachers, leading to better outcomes. Additionally, schools in isolated areas faced challenges in recruiting staff and raising pupils' aspirations due to factors such as high unemployment.

In a closely contested match, Wigan secured a thrilling victory over Huddersfield, moving them to the top of the Super League table. Brierley scored a hat-trick for Huddersfield, showcasing high-quality play. Both teams traded drop-goals, with Wigan ultimately sealing the win with a one-point lead and a late try from Sarginson. Huddersfield's defeat was aggravated by an ankle injury to Jake Connor.

A Pride event was held outside Kampala, Uganda, celebrating the LGBTQ+ community despite strong opposition to gay rights in the country. Attendees hoped for progress while facing the threat of jail for homosexuality. Anti-gay legislation in Uganda was annulled last year. Participants emphasized the need to combat violence and discrimination, seeking equal rights like other Ugandans. The event featured various activities including a transgender awareness day and a beauty pageant. While some, like US President Barack Obama, support gay rights in Africa, others argue it is not part of African culture.

Spain is embarking on severe spending cuts to reduce its budget deficit, aiming to decrease it from 8.5% to 5.3%. Economists have expressed doubts regarding the feasibility of this target. The country recently received a 100 billion euro bailout to aid its struggling banks. The International Monetary Fund has suggested increasing tax revenue and further spending cuts but advised against excessively quick deficit reduction due to the economic slump and high unemployment rate. Spain has implemented significant austerity measures, including freezing unemployment benefits, reducing public sector salaries, cutting departmental budgets, and raising taxes on large corporations. However, these measures have hindered economic recovery, leading to a recession and liquidity issues in the banking sector. Despite the bailout, investor confidence remains low, indicated by high interest rates on government bonds.

The Independent Police Complaints Commission conducted a review of Operation Midland, a high-profile investigation into alleged historical sexual abuse. The watchdog found that while the operation was extensive and carried out diligently, there was no evidence of bad faith, malice, or dishonesty by the officers involved. However, the operation, which led to no arrests, faced criticism for causing prolonged stress to those under investigation. Five officers were referred to the Commission, with three being cleared of causing undue stress. One officer is being investigated for alleged failure to provide relevant information when applying for a search warrant. Key figures, including former MP Harvey Proctor, criticized the operation as bungled and disastrous, resulting in severe consequences for them. The investigation identified serious failings, including believing the main witness, known as "Nick," for too long and flawed information in search warrant applications. The IPCC will further investigate the alleged failure to provide complete information for search warrants and has discontinued investigations into other related allegations.

Mohanna Abdhou, known as Montana, was fatally shot in Malvern Road, Kilburn on Friday night. Her family expressed deep sorrow at the loss of their "loving daughter." Abdhou was approached by two males on bicycles who fired shots at her group. The post-mortem examination revealed she died from a single gunshot wound. The family remembered her as a beautiful and caring soul, while the police have found no evidence suggesting she was a targeted individual. The suspects are described as being of medium build, dressed in dark clothing with their faces covered.

Dr. Paul French, a pediatric pathologist, testified in court that 2-year-old Liam, who was not growing properly, had over 30 external injuries including fractures of his thigh bone and arm. The post mortem examination revealed internal bleeding, with fresh blood found around Liam's heart, leading to impaired heart function and rapid death. Dr. French described these injuries as severe, similar to those seen in high-speed accidents. Liam also had a low body weight and muscles below expected levels for his age, possibly due to neglect or medical issues. The defendants, Rachel Fee and Nyomi Fee, deny charges of killing Liam, blaming it on another child, as well as child neglect charges. The trial is ongoing.

A Libyan military spokesman raised suspicions about a ship's movements at the port of Derna, which is controlled by Islamist militants. The ship, Araevo, carrying 13,000 tonnes of fuel, was attacked by the military for failing to undergo inspection and allegedly transporting Islamist fighters. The attack resulted in casualties and hindered oil shipping from Libyan ports. Libya's National Oil Corporation noted the negative impact on local supplies. The incident reflects the ongoing chaos and power struggles in post-Gaddafi Libya, with militias controlling territories and competing for resources.

The Munduruku indigenous people in Brazil are protesting against government plans to build hydroelectric dams in the Tapajos River region, which will displace communities and harm biodiversity. Despite opposition, construction is progressing, driven by Brazil's need for energy to fuel development. Critics argue that the focus on energy-intensive industries like aluminum production may not serve the country's long-term interests. The indigenous community is particularly concerned about the cultural and environmental impact of projects like the Teles Pires dam, which threatens sacred sites.

Kajsa Tylen, a 38-year-old cyclist from Nottingham, plans to ride 36,000 miles inspired by Billie Fleming's 1938 record. Her mother, Tina Tylen, 65, will provide support during the European journey. Initially distant, their relationship improved, with Tina now understanding how to support Kajsa. Sports psychologist Mustafa Sarkar believes this support will be crucial for breaking the record. The cyclist has received significant support for her challenge, with Dr. Sarkar highlighting the importance of motivation and a sense of purpose in driving her forward during tough moments.

In the Snooker World Championship, the 41-year-old player reached the semi-final for the first time since winning in 2011. He defeated Kyren Wilson and will now face the winner of Stephen Maguire vs. Barry Hawkins. Despite considering Mark Selby the favorite, he believes he can win and feels more relaxed this year. Higgins credits his improved game to good breaks and aims to dominate in key sessions. He hopes to face Maguire in the semi-final for a Scot in the final, praising both players' skills and mentioning Hawkins' growth as a champion.

Warnings have been issued in Spain and Portugal due to extreme heat, with Cordoba on red alert and four regions in Portugal on orange alert. The risk of forest fires is high, with temperatures reaching up to 44C in some areas. People are advised to stay hydrated and cool. The heatwave is expected to continue, prompting concern in France and the UK. In extreme heat, the body faces risks such as heat exhaustion and heatstroke, which require prompt medical attention.

Yahoo's negotiations for a swap-deal with Alibaba Group have hit a stalemate, surprising analysts and causing a selloff in shares. The deal, which could save billions in taxes and provide cash, has not been finalized. This setback comes as Yahoo seeks to restructure and boost its fortunes. Additionally, hedge fund Third Point is pushing for changes in Yahoo's board, adding to the company's challenges following key resignations.

Transport Minister Derek Mackay has acknowledged objections to initial proposals for improvements to the trunk road at Berriedale Braes, where the road drops from 150m to 20m upon entering a valley. Caithness Chamber of Commerce has expressed frustration with the delay in reaching a plan of action. Despite this, Transport Scotland is advancing with the design work for the A9, an important link to the far north mainland coast and ferry services at Scrabster, Gills Bay, and John O'Groats to Orkney.

A recent investigation revealed that over 1,800 cases are pending processing by police, with significant delays in some instances, such as a case in Wiltshire delayed for over 21 months. Hi-tech crime units play a vital role in analyzing data from electronic devices for evidence in cases of child exploitation. Many UK police forces reported delays of at least three months in allocating cases to forensic analysis. Delays in examining evidence were found to increase risks to children, allowing potential offenders to remain free while evidence is analyzed. Families of victims expressed frustration over delays in investigations, with concerns about offenders being free to continue their abuse. Police forces, such as Lincolnshire Police, are facing challenges in meeting the demand for hi-tech investigations into child exploitation. The government has prioritized child sexual abuse as a national threat and is taking steps to address delays, including allocating additional resources to hi-tech crime units.

Violence erupted in Belfast after council contractors removed material from an anti-internment bonfire, leading to car fires, petrol bomb attacks, and clashes with police. Belfast City Council faced backlash for its decision, with a council worker injured and community centers closing early. Police are increasing patrols to combat the unrest and are calling for community leaders to help prevent further violence. Local leaders condemned the actions of those involved in the disorder, emphasizing that they do not represent the community.

Attendees at the Anglesey festival were asked to take shuttle buses to the Bodedern Maes due to ground conservation efforts following heavy rain. Some visitors experienced long wait times for buses, prompting Eisteddfod chief executive Elfed Roberts to urge patience. The shuttle bus system will continue on Tuesday, with special arrangements for blue badge holders to park at Ysgol Uwchradd Bodedern.

Ryan Giggs has taken a year off from his longstanding football career, which began in 1990 with Manchester United. Despite being linked to managerial roles, including potentially succeeding Chris Coleman as Wales manager, Giggs remains noncommittal. He respects Coleman's contributions to Welsh football and appreciates the break from the intense pressures of the sport. During his sabbatical, Giggs has kept busy with TV work, futsal in India, punditry, and overseeing Salford City, a club he co-owns. He is open to returning to coaching if the right opportunity arises but is currently enjoying his time away from the game.

Summary: In Maiduguri, Nigeria, at least 15 people were killed and over 35 injured in bombings at a mosque and a vigilante leader's house. The attacks come amidst ongoing violence by Boko Haram militants, who have killed over 17,000 people since their insurgency began six years ago. President Muhammadu Buhari has intensified efforts to defeat the group, with the military reclaiming territory and freeing kidnapped individuals. However, challenges remain, as a multinational force struggles to commence operations due to funding issues. Boko Haram, which now has ties to the Islamic State group, remains a significant security threat in Nigeria.
