Mark Allison, a software developer from Northumberland, has completed runs across the USA and Australia and is now taking on a 3,400-mile route from Lisbon to Istanbul. He aims to finish the journey through 14 countries in 100 days, raising funds for the Children's Foundation and the Sir Bobby Robson Foundation. Starting in Tynemouth, he will use a motor home as his support base and will take a ferry from Portsmouth to Spain. Allison acknowledges the challenge's significant elevation gains, including tackling climbs like the Stelvio Pass and 15 Tour de France climbs.

Six-month-old Molly-Mae Wotherspoon was tragically killed by a pit bull in her mother Claire Riley's Daventry home. Both Ms Riley and the baby's grandmother, Susan Aucott, have been charged with owning a dangerously out of control dog resulting in the death. The incident occurred on 3 October and the baby passed away due to blood loss from head wounds inflicted by the American pit bull, a breed prohibited for ownership under the 1991 Dangerous Dogs Act. Ms Riley was unable to appear before Northampton magistrates due to illness, while Ms Aucott, 55, appeared before magistrates and was remanded on bail for a court appearance on 7 October. Ms Riley's magistrates hearing is pending arrangement, and she was remanded on bail in her absence.

British player Dan Evans, ranked 179th, lost a hard-fought third-round US Open match to Tommy Robredo despite having set points to extend the match. Evans missed key opportunities in the fourth set, allowing Robredo to claim victory in four sets. Evans earned valuable prize money and points, but missed out on a potential match against Roger Federer. Despite the disappointment, Evans showcased his potential and gained valuable experience in his first main draw Grand Slam appearance.

Jordan Kemlo, 18, has admitted to carrying out sexual assaults in Peterhead between 2011 and 2014. Lord Burns at the High Court in Edinburgh ordered Kemlo to be supervised for five years post his release from custody, stating there was no alternative to custody. Defense advocate Drew McKenzie informed the court that Kemlo expressed remorse for his actions and acknowledged the wrongdoing in his actions towards the victim.

Gloria Ristesund, 62, won a case against Johnson & Johnson for $55m after using talc-based powder on her genitals and being diagnosed with ovarian cancer. J&J, facing numerous similar claims, maintains their products are safe and will appeal. Research on talc's link to cancer is inconclusive. Some studies suggest a risk, but others find no connection. J&J disputes the claims, stating 30 years of research support talc safety. The ongoing debate continues, with J&J defending its products while facing multiple lawsuits related to talc use and cancer risks.

A pedestrian was fatally struck near Cardiff Gate while chasing a loose dog onto the carriageway. The woman was pronounced dead at the scene by the Welsh Ambulance Service. The incident led to the closure of the westbound lanes between junctions 29 and 32 as police conduct an investigation. Motorists are advised to avoid the area with traffic being diverted to the A48M at junction 29.

Five-foot tall models of the Oscar-winning animated characters Wallace and Gromit will be painted by artists to raise funds for Bristol's Children's Hospital through sponsorship and a charity auction. The models will be displayed similarly to the Bristol Zoo gorilla trail, with each artist painting them in their chosen style. Wallace and Gromit creator Nick Park expressed his satisfaction with the models and hopes people will support the cause. This initiative by Wallace and Gromit's Grand Appeal aims to continue their mission of supporting the children's hospital, which began 17 years ago with a public charity appeal.

The Progressive Unionist Party (PUP) criticized fear tactics employed by other parties and highlighted the dysfunction within Stormont. They emphasized the importance of addressing key social and economic issues such as healthcare, education, and housing. PUP's assembly election manifesto, "Country Before Party," outlines commitments to improve crisis intervention for suicide prevention, tackle educational underachievement, support small businesses, and revitalize town centers. PUP leader Billy Hutchinson emphasized moving forward from past conflicts, while deputy leader Dr. John Kyle expressed concerns about smaller parties being marginalized in a shrinking Stormont.

Dawn McKenzie, 34, was fatally stabbed by a 13-year-old boy in 2011. The boy had watched videos of his siblings with knives and a gang logo before moving in with the McKenzie family. A social worker testified that the boy had a stable placement with a foster couple but was moved to the McKenzies after the couple's family member fell ill. The boy stabbed Mrs. McKenzie seven months later and was detained for seven years. Both he and his sisters had troubled pasts in care. Prior incidents of threats with a knife and violent behavior were reported. The inquiry highlighted the boy's troubled history and circumstances surrounding the incident.

Terre des Hommes reported an increase in police killings in Rio prior to the 2016 Olympics. Despite positive ratings on security from tourists, the report highlighted human rights violations, including police violence against youth and children, and forced evictions to clear space for the Games. Amnesty International also noted a rise in police-related deaths and repression of protests during the Olympics. Both organizations recommended that the IOC ensure future host cities comply with international children's rights standards and address human rights violations. The IOC stated its commitment to investigating such issues but emphasized it can only intervene in matters directly linked to the Games.

- Eight engines and 40 firefighters responded to a fire at the Hampton by Hilton Hotel in Corby, with all guests accounted for and four individuals treated for smoke inhalation.
- The cause of the fire at Rockingham Leisure Park is under investigation, and the hotel remains closed.
- Northamptonshire Fire Service relocated all guests and returned crews to base by Sunday morning.

Sir Bobby Charlton scored the first goal in an FA Cup tie against Reading, equaling a record. He played 758 times for Manchester United from 1956 to 1973, winning the League title three times, the European Cup, and the World Cup with England. Wayne Rooney broke Sir Bobby's goal scoring record for England in 2015 and is one goal away from doing the same for Manchester United.

A Welsh health board has approved a new policy banning smoking and e-cigarettes at hospital sites. Patients will be supported with nicotine replacement patches and smoking cessation services to address their addiction. The ban, aimed at decreasing cigarette consumption and promoting quitting, will go into effect on 1 October. E-cigarettes will not be allowed due to lack of evidence supporting their effectiveness in smoking cessation.

The Supreme Court of India upheld the death penalty for Mohammad Ajmal Amir Qasab, the lone surviving gunman from the 2008 Mumbai attacks. The debate over the death penalty has been reignited, with the main opposition party BJP calling for swift execution. Qasab can appeal to the highest court and seek clemency from the president. Critics argue that the death penalty does not deter crime, and many countries have abolished it. India has rarely executed convicts in recent years, with most death sentences being commuted to life imprisonment. Practical challenges, such as a shortage of hangmen and errors in death penalty decisions, have also been highlighted. Former judges and legal experts are advocating for the abolition of the death penalty in line with global trends.

Farid Khan was stripped, beaten, and hanged by a mob in Dimapur, Nagaland. Police fired to disperse the crowd, leading to injuries. Tensions in India are high due to the banning of the film "India's Daughter," about a 2012 gang rape case. The suspect was a Muslim trader from Assam, accused of rape. Ethnic tensions in the region have fueled protests against the alleged rapist. Vigilante justice is uncommon at this scale in India. A curfew was imposed in Dimapur after incidents of arson. The documentary's broadcast has reignited discussions on India's rape crisis.

Andrew Wright, based in Selby, UK, conducted eight trips from Germany to the UK, importing 268kg of cocaine using his light aircraft through his firm, Skyviews R Us Ltd. Wright pleaded guilty to conspiracy to import cocaine at the Old Bailey. He collected the drugs from Germany and delivered them to gang leader Mark Dowling in Essex with the help of gang member Jamie Williams. The operation was uncovered in 2014 when cocaine was found in Wright's vehicle and aircraft. Williams and Dowling were both sentenced to lengthy prison terms. The gang used literary aliases like Biggles, Ginger, and Skippy. Wright's involvement was attributed to financial difficulties after the death of his wife's son in 2013. The National Crime Agency dismantled the criminal enterprise with the assistance of various law enforcement agencies.

Italian striker Mario Balotelli, 26, scored 15 goals for Nice in the French Ligue 1 last season, helping the team finish third and qualify for the Champions League. He joined Nice on a free transfer from Liverpool in August 2016 after a £16 million move to Anfield. Balotelli, a former Manchester City player, has scored 13 goals in 33 appearances for Italy, but has not featured for the national team since the 2014 World Cup.

Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe has unexpectedly become a fashion icon for a designer label called House of Gushungo. The label's signature clothes feature Mugabe's name and image, sparking a dispute with his party, Zanu-PF, over profits from the brand. Sales of the merchandise have been growing, with a focus on attracting young urban voters ahead of the upcoming elections. The company, Yedu Nesu, has exclusive rights to market and manufacture the brand, with plans to donate profits to humanitarian causes. Despite the fashion craze, opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai believes the designer clothes will not influence voting decisions in the elections.

Mark Robins, who took over as manager of Huddersfield in February 2013, has left his post following a 4-0 home defeat against Bournemouth. Robins helped the team avoid relegation in his first season and led them to a 17th-place finish last season. However, the team's recent poor form, winning only two of their last 13 league games, led to the decision to part ways. Assistant manager Steve Thompson will oversee the team alongside first-team coach Steve Eyre, with Robins leaving after 16 months in charge. Huddersfield chairman Dean Hoyle acknowledged Robins' efforts but stated it was in the best interest of all parties to part ways.

English golfer Tyrrell Hatton recently achieved a career-high finish of tie for fifth at the Open at Royal Troon, following his runner-up performance at the Scottish Open. Despite needing to work on maintaining a cool head on the course, he has risen to 55th in the world rankings and credits his improved performance to his new caddie, Chris Rice. Hatton's success has earned him a spot in the upcoming US PGA, where he aims to continue his momentum. While eyeing a potential Ryder Cup spot, he plans to enjoy a vacation in New York with his girlfriend after the tournament. Hatton's strong performance at Troon showcased his prowess on links courses and his steady short game, allowing him to secure a top-5 finish.

Gilbert Corette, 45, admitted manslaughter of his 81-year-old mother and causing grievous bodily harm to his sister due to diminished responsibility. He received a hospital order and restriction order with no time limit. Corette, diagnosed with depression and Asperger's syndrome, was sectioned in 2015 and given day release to visit his mother before the tragic incident. The court found he was suffering from a mental disorder. The family expressed concerns about his release and called for improvements in mental health care. The South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust conducted an internal investigation and is participating in an ongoing domestic homicide review.

McGeady, a 31-year-old footballer with an extensive career, will be joining Sunderland under the management of Simon Grayson, whom he played for at Preston North End last season. He started his career at Celtic, moved to Everton from Spartak Moscow, and has represented the Republic of Ireland in 90 matches. Check our dedicated page for all the newest football transfers.

In 2013, an article accused J.K. Rowling of fabricating a story about being stigmatized by churchgoers in the 1990s. The Mail apologized and paid damages to Rowling in 2014 but disputed her right to give a court statement. The Court of Appeal rejected the newspaper's objections, allowing Rowling to issue a statement as part of the settlement. Rowling clarified that she did not criticize her treatment by churchgoers as claimed in the article and expressed gratitude for her time at the church. Despite initial resistance from the newspaper, the author's libel case was successful, leading to a retraction and apology. Rowling explained that the false allegations had caused distress, but she was now satisfied to resolve the matter.

The National Deep Rummage Team (NDRT) in the UK is tasked with uncovering illegal substances smuggled by criminal gangs on commercial vessels entering UK waters. These vessels, which can be massive, offer numerous hiding spots for drugs. The team must search these vessels meticulously, sometimes facing dangerous conditions in confined spaces. Communication with the ship's crew is also important in detecting smuggling activities. Since its formation in 2004, the NDRT has seized substantial amounts of class A drugs. Working with other maritime authorities and agencies, the team plays a crucial role in preventing illegal goods from reaching the UK streets.

The Hoegh Osaka, a vehicle transporter ship, is undergoing a pumping operation to remove 3,000 tonnes of water due to being grounded off Bramble Bank. Poor weather conditions have halted salvors from boarding, with high winds causing the vessel to drag anchor. Salvage efforts are ongoing to reduce the ship's 50-degree list by pumping lightly contaminated water from the hold. Divers are waiting for improved conditions to inspect the hull, and an exclusion zone has been set up around the vessel. The ship unexpectedly refloated itself and was intentionally grounded to avoid further damage. All crew members were rescued, and salvors are optimistic about the operation's success despite challenges.

Andy Goode, a Coventry-born fly-half, scored 33 points in a remarkable performance for Wasps at their recognized home ground, the Ricoh Arena in Coventry. Goode kicked eight penalties, two conversions, and scored a try to secure the victory. Joe Simpson, Elliot Daly, and Andrea Masi also scored tries for Wasps. The match attracted a record Premiership crowd of 28,254, and Wasps dominated London Irish in the second half. Despite a strong start from the visitors, Wasps pulled away with a commanding performance. Goode's standout display was key in Wasps' win, with the team earning a bonus point in the final minute. Andy Goode expressed his joy at playing in his hometown and setting an individual Premiership points record. Wasps captain James Haskell praised the team's disciplined performance, while London Irish coach Brian Smith acknowledged Wasps' strong showing and commended their decision to move to Coventry.

President Barrow of The Gambia returned to Banjul following the departure of former President Jammeh, who had initially refused to step down after losing the December elections. Barrow, welcomed by jubilant crowds, expressed happiness and vowed to prioritize forming his cabinet. West African forces ensured his security as he re-entered the country, with plans for a public inauguration in the national stadium. Thousands celebrated his return, hopeful for a new era after 22 years of authoritarian rule under Jammeh. The UN is set to assist in guaranteeing security while rogue elements loyal to Jammeh are monitored within the security forces. Additionally, allegations of missing state funds have surfaced, prompting investigations.

HSBC has agreed to a settlement that includes a $100 million fine and $370 million in consumer relief to borrowers following investigations that started in 2010. The bank was found signing foreclosure documents without proper review. The agreement will require HSBC to provide relief to homeowners close to default by reducing loan amounts and changing internal practices related to foreclosures and loan modifications. The settlement addresses concerns related to the financial crisis and settles claims with 49 states, the District of Columbia, and the federal government. The deal is comparable to settlements reached with other US banks like JP Morgan and Bank of America in 2012.

Despite four falls on the beam and uneven bars, the British team secured a silver medal at the gymnastics competition, finishing nearly five marks behind the gold-winning Russian team and nearly two ahead of France. Becky Downie expressed pride in the team's improvement despite the disappointing falls. The team, consisting of Becky and Ellie Downie, Claudia Fragapane, Gabby Jupp, and Ruby Harrold, showed resilience and determination throughout the competition. The absence of Amy Tinkler, who was focused on school exams, was notable, while the return of Jupp after three years of injuries was a positive development.

Leicester Tigers secured a 21-16 victory over Bristol in a closely contested match. Adam Thompstone and Ellis Genge scored tries for Tigers, while Freddie Burns' kicking extended their lead. Bristol fought back with a try from Rob Hawkins and Adrian Jarvis' penalties, earning a losing bonus point. Manu Tuilagi made his return for Leicester after injury. Despite the loss, Bristol's interim head coach commended his team's performance, while Tigers' director of rugby praised their resilience in a tough away game.

A woman gave evidence against Det Sgt Andrew Mottau, who denied gross misconduct while working as a South East Counter Terrorism Unit supervisor. She accused him of using a black monkey toy to signal whose turn it was to make tea and coffee, which she found offensive and racist. The woman felt ridiculed and harassed by Mottau's actions, stating they had racist undertones and violated her dignity. The misconduct hearing also includes allegations of racist remarks and instructions related to the toy. The hearing is being held at Thames Valley Police's headquarters and is set to last four days.

The St. Patrick's Day parade in Birmingham, featuring floats, pipe bands, and dancers, took place in Digbeth with more than 80,000 attendees. This annual event, established in 1996, is the third largest parade worldwide. The theme of this year's celebration is The Gathering, aimed at encouraging Irish descendants to visit their ancestral places. The parade serves as a way for people to embrace their roots and educate local children about their cultural heritage. The Lord Mayor of Birmingham noted the success of the festivities and praised the community's preparation and spirit.
The photo collection showcases a variety of images capturing people and scenes from Africa and Africans around the world, highlighting the diversity and vibrancy of the continent and its diaspora.

In the six months to September, 39,174 people received three days' emergency food from the Trussell Trust, marking a 20% increase from 2013. The Department for Work and Pensions denies a clear link between benefit changes and food bank usage. In Ebbw Vale, the Blaenau Gwent food bank has assisted over 1,500 individuals in 2014, with the main reasons for seeking help being benefit delays, low income, and benefit changes. Oxfam Cymru attributes the rising demand to a combination of benefit cuts, low wages, sanctions, and insecure jobs, while the DWP insists that welfare changes are not the primary cause.

Newly elected MP Zac Goldsmith won the Richmond Park seat by a narrow margin of 45 votes, defeating Liberal Democrat Sarah Olney. Goldsmith had previously lost his seat after resigning in protest over the expansion of Heathrow Airport, triggering a by-election. The closely contested result included four recounts and a voter turnout of 79%. Goldsmith expressed gratitude to his constituents for giving him another chance to represent them, vowing not to let them down. Olney's victory was linked to Goldsmith's pro-Brexit stance in the predominantly Remain-voting constituency.

Researchers have found evidence of significant water trapped deep within rocks, suggesting that rocky planets like Earth may store large amounts of water in their interiors. A diamond from Brazil contained a mineral called ringwoodite, typically formed between 410km and 660km below the Earth's surface, with approximately 1% water content. This discovery challenges previous beliefs about the deep Earth's dryness and raises questions about the role of water in planetary processes. The study highlights the value of natural diamonds in revealing insights into the deep Earth and suggests that this finding could have implications for understanding water cycles on Earth and other rocky planets.

A major report highlights poor diets causing around 70,000 premature deaths annually, prompting calls to use extra revenue from taxing unhealthy food for subsidizing fresh fruits and vegetables. The report emphasizes the harmful effects of sugar consumption on health, suggesting a 20% tax on sugary drinks to deter customers. The British Medical Association warns about the rising obesity rates due to sugar intake and advocates for creating an environment where healthy food choices are default. The government aims to reduce calorie content in foods to combat obesity. The UK's Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition is set to release final advice on sugar intake, with current recommendations falling short for many individuals. The food industry is urged to make further efforts to cut sugar content, while taxes on certain foods have shown limited effectiveness in driving lasting dietary changes.

Worcester City will be playing their football at Kidderminster Harriers' ground due to their own ground being redeveloped, with hopes of one day returning to the city. Their famous victory over Liverpool in 1959 marked a significant moment in their history. Memories of that day, including stories from former players like Peter King, are cherished by fans. Commentators like Dan Johnson have fond memories of St George's Lane and hope for a bright future for the club. Former player Peter King recounts his experience and the advice he received during his career. Overall, Worcester City's journey reflects a mix of nostalgia, hope for the future, and the enduring spirit of the club.

Summary:
Fossils found on the Indonesian island of Flores indicate that primitive human ancestors shrank rapidly to become Hobbit-sized, with remains dating back 700,000 years. The small-sized species, Homo floresiensis, was thought to have existed between 50,000 and 60,000 years ago. The discovery challenges theories on the evolution and arrival of humans on the island, suggesting the possibility of Homo erectus shrinking due to limited resources. Further research aims to uncover more fossils for a complete understanding of the early human presence on Flores.

A 34-year-old woman from Bradford, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was stopped by Turkish authorities last October for attempting to travel to Raqqa with her children. She pleaded guilty to abducting children under 16 and was sentenced at Leeds Crown Court. She believed in living under strict Sharia law and thought it could only be found where IS controlled. The judge highlighted the dangers of Raqqa under IS control, including extreme violence. She had planned to travel to Syria and then to Mosul in Iraq without informing her family. Born in the UK, she spent her early years in Pakistan before returning to Bradford.

In April, Tottenham Hotspur won all six league matches with Son scoring five out of their 16 goals. This marked the first time this season that Argentine manager Pochettino won the award. Son, hailing from South Korea, claimed the players' prize for the second time this season, having previously won in September. Spurs defeated Burnley, Swansea, Watford, Bournemouth, Crystal Palace, and Arsenal during the month. The team is currently second in the table, trailing leaders Chelsea by seven points with three games left. It is notable that Tottenham has secured five out of the past 11 Player of the Month awards.

In early trade, the FTSE 100 index fell by 5.51 points to 6,815.28. Mining shares, including Anglo American and BHP Billiton, dropped due to pressure on commodity prices from a stronger US dollar. Morrisons saw a 2.4% decline in shares after a "sell" rating from Goldman Sachs. However, banking shares performed better, with HSBC up 1.4% and Barclays up 0.5%. The pound weakened against the dollar but strengthened against the euro.

The Siberian or Amur tigers are facing threats from deforestation, poaching, and now canine distemper virus. This virus, known for infecting dogs, has been identified as the cause of illness in several tiger samples. Once thought to only affect domestic cats, this virus has shown its ability to jump to various species, including lions, hyenas, leopards, and even primates. The potential for CDV to infect humans exists, as the virus only needs a small mutation to utilize human cell receptors. While this raises concerns, further research is needed to fully understand the extent of this threat.

Severe flooding along the Uruguay River in Entre Rios province has caused significant damage to Concordia and neighboring areas in Paraguay and Uruguay. Thousands of people are affected, with a quarter of Concordia underwater and ongoing evacuations due to rising river levels. The provinces of Formosa, Chaco, and Santa Fe are also heavily impacted. Authorities are implementing assistance plans for those affected, potentially linked to the El Nino weather phenomenon.

Joseph Tsang, a 31-year-old IT worker from Oxford, was convicted in his absence of two counts of rape and two counts of sexual assault, committed in Hampshire. He was also awaiting sentencing for three counts of sexual activity with a child under 16. Tsang, a Chinese national, fled and was due to appear in court in Hong Kong. His victims were described as having gone through a "living nightmare." The process to bring Tsang back to the UK for sentencing is now underway.

Rick Astley's album "50" has become his first UK number one in almost 30 years. It is nominated for the BBC Radio 2 album of the year award along with Adele, Coldplay, ELO, and Michael Kiwanuka, but David Bowie's "Blackstar" was not included in the shortlist. The winners will be announced at the BBC Music Awards on 12 December. Bowie was previously nominated for a BBC Music Award. Astley previously won awards in his early career and enjoyed success with the Rickrolling phenomenon. Eligible albums for the BBC Music Award must have been released between October 2015 and October 2016.

Peter Whittle expressed support for Paul Nuttall as a leader who understands the UKIP party well and can unite its members. Nuttall is competing for leadership against Suzanne Evans and John Rees-Evans, with Raheem Kassam having withdrawn. Whittle highlighted the significance of the recent High Court ruling on Article 50 and emphasized the need for UKIP in advocating for the Leave vote in the EU referendum to be respected. Nigel Farage has resumed his role as interim leader following Diane James' brief tenure.

Willard Wigan, a 57-year-old micro-sculptor known for creating art that fits within the eye of a needle or on a pin-head, will have an exhibition of his works at the Library of Birmingham starting from 11 January. His intricate pieces, including miniature versions of popular figures like Usain Bolt and cartoon characters, are inspired by his "fantasy world". Wigan, who was awarded an MBE for his contributions to art, supports literacy and learning initiatives and believes they are crucial in Birmingham, where literacy levels are low. Part of the proceeds from the exhibition will assist community programmes operated by the library.

Several councils in north-west England have granted or renewed permits for over 300 convicted drivers since 2012, prompting concerns about public safety. The mother of a student who was killed by a fake taxi driver criticized the practice, and MP Andrew Gwynne called for stricter legislation. One in five drivers applying for a taxi license in the region had a criminal record in the last two years. Councils have the discretion to decide if applicants are "fit and proper" drivers, considering various factors. Concerns were raised about drivers offering illegal unbooked journeys and operating without proper licensing. The Licensed Taxi Drivers Association emphasized the need for robust minimum licensing standards to protect the public. The tragic case of a student murdered by a fake taxi driver underscores the risks associated with granting licenses to individuals with criminal convictions, particularly those for sexual offences.

An ongoing internal investigation at Glasgow City Council's land and environmental services department has raised concerns of cronyism and procurement irregularities. The department's executive director resigned last November amid the probe. Police Scotland is now involved in inquiries at an early stage. The investigation includes individuals with personal links to a housing repair company and potential conflicts of interest. The issue of transparency within the council has become a key theme in the upcoming local elections, with Labour supporters highlighting their seriousness in addressing such matters and the SNP emphasizing the need for more transparency. The council's ties with companies are being scrutinized, with a focus on adherence to procurement rules and avoiding unfair advantages for companies with personal connections to council staff.

Bert Williams, a 71-year-old angler from Prenton, Wirral, caught a 93lb cod off the coast of Norway, just shy of the world record. Initially mistaking it for a dolphin, it took two anglers over 25 minutes to land the massive fish. Despite having to pace himself to lift it out of the water, Mr. Williams, who has a heart condition, successfully reeled it in with the help of guides. The catch, the largest by a British angler and a disabled angler, will be memorialized as a fibreglass replica by the fishing trip organizers.

Labour MP Peter Kyle expressed the urgent need for more armed officers in Hove due to only seven being on duty. Calls for assistance from neighboring forces have increased by 43%. Prime Minister acknowledged the possibility of increasing armed police but opposes routine arming. The MP sought assurance that local forces can handle a terrorist attack without help from neighboring forces. The Prime Minister emphasized the tradition of police forces supporting each other in times of need, recalling the IRA bombing at Brighton's Grand Hotel in 1984.

"I, Daniel Blake" is a film directed by Ken Loach, who sheds light on the UK welfare system through the story of Daniel Blake, an older man struggling to navigate bureaucracy after a heart attack leaves him unable to work. The film aims to evoke both empathy and anger in its audience towards the challenges faced by those in need. Loach criticizes the current benefits system as intentionally inefficient and designed to push claimants into despair. Drawing on real-life encounters, the film portrays the harsh realities of poverty and hunger experienced by many in Britain, emphasizing the impact of government policies on individuals and communities. Loach's poignant exploration of social issues has garnered critical acclaim, with reviewers applauding the film's emotional resonance and relevance.

Prince passed away in April 2016 due to a fentanyl overdose without leaving a will or any children. His estate is valued at around $200 million, with taxes likely taking up half of it. A legal battle involving 45 potential heirs, including a false claimant in Colorado, ensued over his assets, which include properties and music rights to his hits. A judge dismissed claims by 29 potential heirs, ordering genetic tests for others. Prince's sister and five half-siblings must wait another year for their share of the estate. Plans are in place to release remastered albums and unreleased tracks in the future.

Summary: Stephen Hendry, a snooker legend, announced his retirement from tournament snooker at the age of 43. He cited reasons such as schedule, not enjoying practice, and wanting to pursue other commitments, particularly in China. Despite a career filled with achievements, including seven world titles and numerous records, Hendry felt it was time to step away from competitive snooker. The decision came as a surprise to many in the snooker community, with fellow players, fans, and officials praising his contributions to the sport and acknowledging his unparalleled talent and dedication.

A former employee armed with a knife entered a Ludlow restaurant in Southbank, cornered a woman, and barricaded himself in a back room. After negotiations, the woman was released unharmed, and the man was Tasered by police, arrested, and taken to the hospital. The incident stemmed from employment issues with the restaurant, and the woman was not directly threatened during the siege.

A woman, who has not been identified, was kidnapped in a central Kabul neighborhood but has been released. The German aid worker was in good condition and is relieved and happy. The circumstances of her release have not been disclosed. This was the second abduction of a GIZ employee this year. German Foreign Minister expressed relief and gratitude to Afghan authorities. In a separate incident, five Afghan workers for Save the Children were found dead after being abducted in Uruzgan province.

The artist from Aberdeen has been awarded the Livingstone Medal by the RSGS for her efforts in raising awareness about HIV/AIDS on a global scale. This prestigious award, first given in 1901 to explorer Sir Harry H Johnston, is seen as a significant honor by the singer.

The article discusses the ongoing tensions and complexities surrounding Crimea three years after Russia's annexation. A BBC journalist's journey to Crimea highlights the challenges of accessing the region due to political disputes between Moscow and Kiev. The journalist faces scrutiny and questioning at border checkpoints, reflecting the suspicion and control surrounding entry into Crimea. The narrative provides insights into the ongoing geopolitical dynamics and the scrutiny faced by journalists operating in the region.

Daniel Pike, 28, built a clay hut in Merry Hill Wood near Watford over two years. The Woodland Trust, which owns the land, removed the hut, citing the need to safeguard the area. Mr. Pike was arrested during the removal and has since stated that his hut was destroyed. He is now staying with his mother and plans to return to his job at a supermarket. The Woodland Trust stated that the eviction was part of their policy to prevent occupation of their woods for conservation reasons.

A man was struck and killed on the A466 Wye Valley Link Road in Newhouse, Chepstow. The road was closed in both directions between the M48 junction 2 and A48 during the investigation. Emergency services responded, including an air ambulance, but the man was pronounced dead at the scene.

M Squared Lasers, a company based in Glasgow and with offices in the US, has secured funding of over £3.25m from Barclays and BGF. The company specializes in developing and manufacturing lasers and photonic instruments for various sectors. With a focus on expanding their export business, M Squared has experienced significant growth, particularly in the US market where revenues doubled in 2014. The company employs over 50 staff, has a turnover of £10m, achieved 40% revenue growth in 2014, and anticipates similar growth in the upcoming years.

In late December, militants led by Isis took over parts of Falluja and Ramadi, leading to ongoing struggles for control by troops and allied tribesmen. The number of displaced individuals is at its highest since the peak of sectarian insurgency in 2006-2008, with 1.1 million internally displaced people in Iraq yet to return to their communities. The tourist village of Habbaniya has become a refuge for those fleeing Anbar, with inadequate living conditions and health risks for its occupants. The UNHCR reports that around 50,000 families have fled their homes due to the clashes in Ramadi and Falluja. The situation in Anbar continues to lead to civilian casualties and significant hardships, with many displaced persons urgently in need of humanitarian aid.

The 2016 Olympics in Brazil were launched with a spectacular display of fireworks, a parade of nations, and the iconic lighting of the Olympic torch. Newsround reporter Ricky was present to capture the excitement.

Mock hangings involving blow up dolls dressed in Rangers scarf and Orange sash occurred at a game. Police have established a dedicated email to collect video evidence of disorder and vandalism. Vandalism of toilets in the away section prompted both clubs to release statements on fan behavior. Detective Stewart is leading the investigation and requests those with footage to come forward. CCTV and broadcaster footage are being utilized to identify those involved in disorder. Police urge individuals with information to send it to CelticRangersDisorder@scotland.pnn.police.uk.

Dozens of birds were discovered placed in a line along a road in Devon by the police. Feathers and a discarded seed bag were also found nearby. The cause of death is still under investigation, and witnesses are being sought. Pigeon fanciers in the area are encouraged to check their flocks.

President Ouattara has indicated that none of his supporters will face prosecution at the International Criminal Court (ICC), in contrast to his rival Laurent Gbagbo who is currently on trial for war crimes related to the civil war that followed the 2010 election. Both sides were accused of atrocities during the conflict that resulted in 3,000 deaths. President Ouattara stated that Ivory Coast now has a functional justice system for future prosecutions to be handled nationally. While Gbagbo's trial at the ICC has begun, his denial of charges such as murder and rape will be addressed over a period of three to four years. The ICC has been criticized for potentially showing bias by only prosecuting one side of the conflict, neglecting atrocities committed by pro-Ouattara forces. Notably, former pro-Ouattara leaders have also faced indictment in Ivory Coast, with some still at large. Simone Gbagbo, the former president's wife, faced prosecution in Ivory Coast and was sentenced to 20 years in prison in 2015 for undermining state security.

The Afrobasket 2015 is taking place in Rades, near Tunis, after being moved from the coast due to recent attacks. Winners will become African champions and qualify for the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. The opening match is between Egypt and Gabon, with defending champions Angola favored to win. Three other semi-finalists will compete in an Olympic qualifying tournament next year.

Multiple news organizations, including Associated Press and Vice Media, are suing the FBI to reveal information about the unlocking of the iPhone used by Syed Rizwan Farook. The FBI has not disclosed the identity of the security firm or hackers who helped unlock the phone. The groups argue that revealing this information is essential for public transparency and government accountability under the Freedom of Information Act. Apple had initially resisted a court order to assist in unlocking the phone, leading to speculation that the FBI paid over $1.3 million for the service. FBI Director James Comey indicated that the cost was significant but worthwhile, although no details of the phone's contents have been made public.

Eliza Szonert, involved in a custody dispute with businessman Ashley Crick, took her son with the help of a child recovery agency in Malaysia. Police detained her when she refused to disclose the child's location, but she has now been allowed to leave with her son without facing charges. The case gained attention after a video of the incident went viral. Mr. Crick is reportedly back in Australia seeking custody through the court system. Ms. Szonert expressed gratitude for the support and is eager to return home and be reunited with her son. Child Recovery Australia, the group that assisted her, claimed another successful recovery. Ms. Szonert accused Mr. Crick of taking their passports after a disagreement.

Wavegarden Scotland plans to convert Craigpark Quarry pit near Ratho into a lake with artificial waves for surfers of all levels. The project aims to create over 80 jobs and boost Scotland's surfing industry. Positive responses have been received from developers, local officials, and surfing organizations. Public consultations will be held to gather feedback on the proposal.

The match between Notts County and Morecambe was promising, with Stanley Aborah and Haydn Hollis creating opportunities early on. However, the game was interrupted due to heavy rain causing the pitch to be waterlogged. Referee Dean Whitestone eventually abandoned the match, ending in a goalless draw. Michael Rose received a yellow card for a foul, and there were notable saves by Barry Roche and attempts from both teams.

Lance Corporal David Gwilt and Rifleman Dale Harris, both aged 24 and serving in The Rifles, died in a collision near Cullybackey in August 2014. Their colleague, Rifleman Matthew Robins, survived with minor injuries. The soldiers, unfamiliar with the area, were involved in the accident when their car failed to stop at a junction and collided with a tractor. Despite efforts from on-site medical personnel and the introduction of additional safety measures at the junction by Transport NI, the soldiers tragically lost their lives. The coroner extended sympathies to their families and commended the rescue efforts.

Inmarsat has ordered two spacecraft from Airbus for around 550 million euros, to be built in Southern England. The new Inmarsat-6 series will update services in the L-band radio spectrum, with a Ka-band payload for future growth. These "all-electric" satellites will be more efficient and flexible, using ion engines. This decision supports UK space manufacturing and investment in telecoms.

South African cricketer Parnell, who joined Glamorgan for the T20 Blast, is set to play his final game against Somerset before joining South Africa's T20 squad in Bangladesh. He expressed his desire to return to Cardiff and praised the city and the support he received from Glamorgan. Despite Glamorgan's recent T20 defeats, Parnell sees potential in the team's players, highlighting performances by Michael Hogan, Graham Wagg, and Andrew Salter.

Mark Beaumont, a 33-year-old adventurer and former world record holder for cycling around the world, has been elected as the new rector of the University of Dundee. He succeeds actor Brian Cox and will represent students' interests in the university's governing body. Beaumont expressed his excitement for the role and his commitment to contributing to the university's future successes. He will be formally installed as rector in a ceremony at a later date. The university's principal, Professor Sir Pete Downes, welcomed Beaumont into the university community and expressed confidence in his ability to be an excellent representative for the students.

The Commission on Widening Access in Scotland has emphasized the need for change to address socioeconomic inequalities in university access. The commission's interim report highlighted the impact of parental experience on university entry and argued for equal opportunities to maximize talent and eliminate inequality. The report emphasized the benefits of higher education in breaking cycles of deprivation and contributing to a fairer society. Education Secretary Angela Constance acknowledged the progress made but stressed the ongoing need to tackle educational inequality. Contextual admissions are considered a tool to widen access without compromising academic excellence. The final report is expected next year.

During the second quarter, Scotland experienced growth in services and production while construction contracted. Scottish GDP grew by 0.7% over the past year, with a slower rate compared to the UK. The closure of a coal-fired power station affected GDP but is seen as a one-off impact. The Chambers of Commerce highlighted the need for continued efforts to boost the economy. The Federation of Small Businesses emphasized the importance of achieving growth levels on par with the UK. Both organizations called for a focus on economic welfare post-Brexit to support businesses and local communities.

A recent study reveals that Indonesia has surpassed Brazil in the rate of deforestation, with land cleared for palm oil plantations and farms. The loss of primary forest in Indonesia has led to increased greenhouse gas emissions and loss of biodiversity. Despite a government moratorium on deforestation, corrupt practices persist, prompting calls for more monitoring and sanctions. Forest fires last year caused health concerns in neighboring countries, prompting Norway to pledge financial support to Indonesia for halting deforestation.

The article discusses the career of Vernon Anthony Cotter, a New Zealand rugby coach who had successful stints in France before becoming the Scotland national team coach. Cotter's experiences in French rugby shaped his coaching philosophy, emphasizing character and defending the team jersey. Known for his success at Clermont, where he transformed the team into a top contender, Cotter's coaching tenure in Scotland has seen mixed results but with notable player development. His time in France and the cultural influence on his coaching style are highlighted, showcasing his journey from player to esteemed coach in world rugby.

In the Test match, a 23-year-old player scored an entertaining hundred after being dropped three times. South Africa scored 475, with De Kock unbeaten on 129. England took early wickets but De Kock's partnerships helped South Africa build a solid total. England's Hales fell cheaply, while Cook scored 67. South Africa bowled out for 475, with De Kock scoring freely. England struggled in the field with missed chances. The pitch's uneven bounce favors South Africa, who have lost the series but aim for a consolation victory. England's captain Cook showed good form, while Hales continued to struggle. Former captains Vaughan and Boucher analyzed the match dynamics and predicted challenging conditions for batting in upcoming sessions.

Former SDLP party leader Mark Durkan, who had been the MP for Londonderry since 2005, lost by 169 votes to Sinn Féin's Elisha McCallion. Durkan had held the city seat coveted by SDLP since John Hume's election in 1983. This election saw all 18 of Northern Ireland's MPs confirmed, with SDLP and Ulster Unionist Party experiencing losses. Durkan attributed his defeat to Sinn Féin's greater campaign funding and the lack of a "progressive alliance." McCallion, the first-ever republican MP in the city, acknowledged Durkan's contribution and expressed delight at her election. SDLP leader Colum Eastwood faces the challenge of rebuilding the party post-election. Colleagues mourned Durkan's loss from the House of Commons, highlighting his eloquence and unique presence in Parliament.

HMP Shrewsbury, also known as the Dana, was closed by the Ministry of Justice to save money. Bids from private companies are now being accepted to potentially repurpose the Grade II listed building as flats or a hotel, according to English Heritage. The hope is to find a new and useful function for the historic prison.

London-based law firm Public Interest Lawyers (PIL) will cease operations at the end of August due to the Legal Aid Agency (LAA) withdrawing its funding. The firm had represented complainants in the Al-Sweady inquiry but was criticized for allegations based on "deliberate lies". PIL also submitted bids to prosecute British politicians and military figures for alleged war crimes in Iraq. Defence Secretary Michael Fallon welcomed the firm's closure, calling it the "right outcome for our armed forces". The UK government aims to prevent firms like PIL from making spurious claims by considering stronger penalties for abuse of the legal system.

The head of Clarksfield Primary School in Oldham, Patricia O'Donnell, has alleged receiving death threats which were investigated by Oldham Council and found to have no concerns. The leaked report stated that there were no basis to the 'Trojan Horse' allegations at the school. Other schools in Oldham raised concerns over Islamic teaching sessions and other activities, but the Department for Education is collaborating with the council. The National Association for Head Teachers union is supporting members in the area with similar allegations. This situation is reminiscent of the Birmingham "Trojan Horse" inquiry involving Islamist hard-liners attempting to control schools.

Statistics obtained under the Freedom of Information Act reveal that nine councils in Wales have decreased their planned spending on respite care, raising concerns about the impact on vulnerable groups. Some councils have cut defined respite budgets while others have reduced overall residential care budgets that include respite provisions. Swansea Council, for example, has significantly reduced its respite budget. Families who rely on respite care, such as Suzanne Hayes caring for her stepson with cerebral palsy, are expressing frustration with the potential cuts. The charity Carers Wales highlights that respite provision is already limited and further cuts will exacerbate the situation. The Welsh Government acknowledges the importance of respite care and has committed to protecting the social services budget, with an increase in funding planned by 2013-14. Discussions on the future of respite care in Wales are ongoing following an independent review.

Janse, a versatile 30-year-old player, joins Brisbane Road after playing for Italian Serie B side Ternana. He is an ex-Netherlands Under-21 international who primarily plays at right-back but can also feature across the back four and on the right side of midfield. This move follows the recent signing of midfielder Zan Benedicic, who also joined on a deal until January. Stay updated on the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.

A former aide testified in federal court about a political revenge plot involving New Jersey Governor Chris Christie following lane closures at the George Washington Bridge. The plot was allegedly to punish the mayor of Fort Lee for not endorsing the governor in his re-election bid. While the governor denied knowledge of the scheme and was not charged, two of his aides are on trial for conspiring to misuse Port Authority property. The scandal, known as "Bridgegate," has resurfaced with new revelations and claims, including photographic evidence and testimony pointing towards Governor Christie's awareness.

The British film Paddington has been awarded a PG certificate due to mild innuendo and scenes involving potential imitation by young viewers. The movie features a playful bear in various adventurous situations, including a scene where Paddington hides inside a refrigerator and encounters a villainous taxidermist played by Nicole Kidman. Despite some concerns raised by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC), the film's overall tone is light-hearted and family-friendly. The decision to classify Paddington as PG was based on public feedback and regular guideline reviews by the BBFC.

Bristolian Tavare, 26, and South African Van Buuren, also 26, have signed contract extensions with the club until the end of the 2019 and 2018 seasons, respectively. Head coach Richard Dawson is pleased with their commitment, noting that both players are still developing their skills and will strengthen the squad. Van Buuren joined from the Titans in South Africa earlier this year and is classified as a non-overseas player due to his wife's British passport. He expressed his excitement to continue with the club for the next few years and is looking forward to the upcoming 2017 season.

A tragic fire at a prison in Honduras resulted in 358 deaths, with forensic experts working to identify badly burned victims through DNA testing. Only 18 bodies have been released for burial so far. The prison was overcrowded and lacked an emergency evacuation plan. The US ATF is assisting with the investigation into the causes of the fire. President Lobo has ordered a safety review of all prisons and pledged to improve conditions in the country's facilities holding over 13,000 inmates.

The Care Quality Commission investigated an incident at the Melbury Lodge in Royal Hampshire County Hospital where a patient sustained serious injuries after falling from a low roof in December 2015. The Southern Health trust is accused of failing to provide safe care and treatment to the patient receiving care for severe mental health problems. The case is set to be heard at the Basingstoke Magistrates' Court later this year.

Four schools in Moray - Applegrove, Millbank, Seafield, and St Gerardine - will undergo refurbishment including new roof coverings, windows, doors, toilets, and heating/electrical systems. The project, funded by a £10m government grant and Moray Council, will be carried out by Galliford Try. Work is set to begin in the summer break and be completed by spring 2017. Galliford Try, which owns Morrison Construction, has experience in recent local projects including Elgin Town Hall refurbishment and Moray's flood alleviation schemes.

Linda Norgrove, a woman from Lewis, was taken hostage by rebels in Afghanistan in 2010 and tragically killed during a rescue operation by US special forces. The Linda Norgrove Foundation, established in her honor, supports the Ascend project in Afghanistan, which trains young women in mountaineering skills. Last year, a team of 13 women climbed three peaks, including an unclimbed mountain they named, with limited resources such as sharing boots. The project aims to empower Afghan women and has already impacted the lives of many. Linda's family, avid climbers themselves, are inspired by the project's impact and help raise funds for similar initiatives benefiting women and children in Afghanistan.

A four-piece band and their manager tragically died in a car accident in Sweden after a gig in Stockholm. The inquest revealed that no alcohol or drugs were involved in the incident. The band members had played at various festivals and were on their way to another event when their car crashed into a canal. The car was seen driving over the speed limit and navigated past barriers before hitting a raised section of a bridge. The post-mortem examinations showed that the band members died from head injuries, except for one who drowned. Despite the tragic event, the band's music continued to gain recognition posthumously, with their debut album reaching number one on the charts.

In October, the UK will implement a 3% increase in the national minimum wage, benefiting a million workers. This is the first time in six years that the rise surpasses inflation. Various age groups will see wage increases, with rates for 18-20-year-olds rising by 10p to £5.13/hr, 16-17-year-olds by 7p to £3.79/hr, and apprentices by 5p to at least £2.73/hr. Business Secretary Vince Cable emphasized the importance of companies sharing economic benefits with all staff. There are calls for reform to the minimum wage, including setting it closer to the living wage of around £7.65-£8.80/hr. Trade unions express dissatisfaction with the current rate and pressure for a higher wage increase in the future.

The by-election in Stoke Central saw Labour narrowly retain their seat, with low voter turnout attributed to disillusionment with politics and a lack of belief in meaningful change. Labour's win was seen more as a relief that UKIP did not clinch the seat. Residents expressed concerns about the declining industrial landscape and economic challenges facing the community, with high levels of unemployment. Despite the area's historical ties to Labour, the changing political landscape over the years reflects a growing disconnect with Westminster and a sense of alienation among the working-class voters.

Under-20s coach Murty has led Rangers for three matches following Warburton's departure. The team bounced back with a 3-2 win against St Johnstone, earning Murty his first Premiership victory. Players praise Murty's impact and effort, emphasizing the importance of the win. Rangers are focused on upcoming matches and closing the gap with Aberdeen in the league standings. Discussions about appointing a new head coach continue, with players expressing optimism for the future.

A report by Gizmodo accused Facebook staff of burying articles they disagreed with in the Trending Topics section. Facebook denied the allegations, stating they found no evidence. Mark Zuckerberg's criticism of Donald Trump did not influence the selection of stories. The Trending Topics list is edited by humans to ensure accuracy, with a focus on trending news in the real world. Facebook's Tom Stocky refuted claims of staff tampering with stories and bias against conservative sources. The company has strict guidelines for topic reviewers and does not allow discrimination against sources of any ideological origin.

Strathspey Steam Railway plans to recreate a historic 1863 train journey from Aviemore to Broomhill, with passengers in Victorian attire traveling for free. The railway currently runs on a 10-mile track and aims to extend it by 3 more miles to Grantown-on-Spey. The anniversary event will include decorated platforms, a send-off by the Earl of Dysart, and encouragement for participants to dress in Victorian clothing for a fun and memorable experience. Suggestions for attire include a lum hat and tail coat, with inspiration drawn from the 2012 London Olympics opening ceremony featuring actor Kenneth Branagh as Isambard Kingdom Brunel.

The theatre's owners were granted an eviction order due to technical reasons, but the comedian can remain during the appeal process. Dieudonne, known for anti-Semitism and hate speech, has faced multiple convictions, including one following the Charlie Hebdo attack. The theatre's owners claim his current company doesn't have the lease rights. Multiple French cities have banned his performances. Dieudonne gained fame for creating the "quenelle" gesture, often seen as a controversial symbol, despite his denial of anti-Semitism.

Ilkay Gundogan, who suffered a knee injury in December, is taking a cautious approach to his recovery to ensure he is fully ready to return to the field. Despite missing previous major tournaments due to injuries, he remains optimistic about the upcoming season with Manchester City. Manager Pep Guardiola has made new signings and the team is gearing up for a strong campaign. Gundogan also sees Tottenham as a significant threat in the Premier League title race, acknowledging their strong performances against top teams.

The Sauchiehall Street building, originally designed by Mackintosh for Kate Cranston in 1903, is being refurbished by the Willow Tea Rooms Trust. The separate Willow Tea Rooms business relocated to a nearby Watt Brothers store under owner Anne Mulhern's direction, aiming to recreate the original tea room's grandeur with a nod to its historical design. The refurbishment project seeks to restore the building to its former glory and preserve its fascinating history.

Major Tim Peake, the first Briton selected as an astronaut for the European Space Agency, expressed pride in representing both Britain and the European Space Agency during a live link-up with schoolchildren in London. He discussed the rigorous training process and preparations for his upcoming mission to the International Space Station in December on a Russian Soyuz rocket. Peake emphasized the importance of retaining vast amounts of information throughout the training and highlighted the significance of the UK government's support for human spaceflight in benefiting British industry, education, and scientific research. The event was organized as part of the UK Space Agency's Esero program, aimed at enhancing science education through space exploration. Attendees, including schoolchildren, were inspired by the experience and viewed it as a unique opportunity.

BP will have to make payments stemming from the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion despite their arguments against inflated or bogus claims. The Supreme Court rejected BP's appeal, leading to a series of setbacks for the oil firm. The settlement agreement has no cap, but BP faces uncertainty over the total cost. BP has already paid out a portion of the compensation claims to individuals and businesses, with a total of $43bn set aside. In September, a US judge ruled BP, Transocean, and Halliburton were negligent in the 2010 oil spill, leading to further legal proceedings.

A woman was walking along the Sydenham Bypass around 10-11 PM on Saturday when she was forced into a dark-colored car and attacked. She managed to escape. The car was seen heading towards Holywood after the incident. The suspect is described as a man in his 30s wearing a dark hooded top.

HS2 Ltd is overseeing the expansion of Euston station in London to accommodate passengers using the new rail line between London and the Midlands. Originally planned to be completed by 2026, the project is now expected to finish by 2033. The development will include six new platforms and an additional concourse, with building works starting in 2017. HS2 Ltd has proposed delaying the construction of five additional platforms to align with phase two of the project, running from London to Leeds and Manchester. The changes aim to ensure smoother construction management and avoid negative impacts on daily train capacity at Euston. Camden Council has raised concerns about the extended works causing long-term disruption to the area. The new plan will be submitted to Parliament, with the budget for the Euston project increasing to £2.25 billion, while the overall HS2 budget of £42 billion remains unchanged.

Barcelona forward scores stunning free-kick in Brazil's win over Colombia at Olympics. Luan adds second goal; Brazil to face Honduras in semis. Neymar nets long-range strike, sparks brawl with Colombia. Germany to play Nigeria in other semi-final after victories over Denmark and Portugal.

Deutsche Bank has announced plans to purchase €3bn in euro-denominated bonds and $2bn in dollar-denominated bonds. This news initially caused a surge in the bank's shares, which had already seen a 10% increase earlier in the day. The bank stated it had the liquidity to make the purchases without altering its 2016 funding plan, signaling its financial strength. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble dismissed concerns about the bank's stability, affirming that Deutsche Bank has sufficient capital. Despite assurances of a solid balance sheet, the bank's shares fell by 13% on Monday and Tuesday.

In 2014, Camden Council approved a £41 million revamp of a central London street, which included a daylight ban on cars six days a week. The decision faced opposition from the Licensed Taxi Drivers Association, who sought a judicial review but were refused. The council argued that the redesign aimed to improve safety, support businesses, and prepare for the opening of a Crossrail station in 2018. The ban would only allow buses, bicycles, and local access on the street during specified hours, with limited access for other vehicles on side streets to prevent traffic congestion, poor air quality, and increased collisions.

The UK party leaders are in a dispute over televised debates ahead of the general election. Labour leader Ed Miliband criticized Prime Minister David Cameron for not agreeing to take part in a debate if the Green Party is involved. Cameron accused Miliband of avoiding facing the Greens, insisting that all "national parties" should be represented. Broadcasters remain committed to holding debates, even in Cameron's absence. The debate has become a high-stakes struggle for power, with legal action looming as a possibility. Miliband, Clegg, and Farage have called for debates to proceed even without Cameron, offering an empty podium for him. The proposed debates would include the Conservatives, Labour, Lib Dems, and UKIP, with dates set for April. Farage suggested the BBC could go ahead with a debate without Cameron.

In February 2008, an East Midlands Trains service derailed in Leicestershire after being hit by an engineering works tipper lorry that had raised the back of its truck, causing a bridge collapse. The train was unable to stop in time despite a warning message. The train driver was trapped and sustained serious leg injuries, while no passengers were harmed. The court found that Network Rail's inadequate construction site safety measures endangered the public. The incident left the train driver traumatized, with ongoing flashbacks. Network Rail apologized for the incident.

Prof. Higgs, lacking a mobile phone, learned of his Nobel Prize win from a former neighbor. The 84-year-old physicist from the University of Edinburgh won for his work on the Higgs boson theory, sharing the prize with Francois Englert. The "God particle" was confirmed by Cern's Large Hadron Collider after 50 years. Prof. Higgs expressed relief and delight, highlighting the collaborative effort of many theorists and researchers. He noted the challenges in crediting contributions, acknowledging his part in a theoretical program started in 1960. Born in Newcastle, he developed his theory at Edinburgh. The landmark research was published in 1964. The $10 billion LHC team at Cern confirmed the Higgs boson in 2013. Prof. Higgs, emotional at the announcement, expressed satisfaction at being right.

Former First Lady Michelle Obama joined James Corden for Carpool Karaoke where she sang along to hits by Beyonce, Stevie Wonder, and Missy Elliott. She revealed that she rarely rides in the passenger's seat of a car due to security reasons. Missy Elliott also joined the ride, performing "This Is For My Girls" in support of Mrs. Obama's Let Girls Learn initiative. The segment took place as part of Corden's hosting of The Late Late Show on CBS, where other celebrities like Adele, Sir Rod Stewart, and Justin Bieber have also been guests on Carpool Karaoke.

Julian Salvi, a 31-year-old Australian rugby player for the Exeter Chiefs, sustained a serious injury during a recent Champions Cup match against Ulster. He will require surgery for the undisclosed injury. Salvi, who joined the Chiefs in 2015 from Leicester, has been a key player for the team, contributing significantly to their success. Head coach Rob Baxter praised Salvi's consistent performance and his importance to both defense and attack, highlighting his role as a top tackler and clearout player. Salvi's absence will be sorely felt by the team due to his all-round contributions on the field.

The Lionesses achieved a historic third-place finish in the 2015 World Cup under Sampson's leadership, marking a significant improvement from their previous performances under Hope Powell. Players have praised Sampson for instilling a sense of togetherness and passion within the team, creating a family-like atmosphere that has contributed to their success. Former players criticized the negative environment during Powell's reign, highlighting the positive changes brought by Sampson.

The Scottish women's national team, coached by Anna Signeul, have scheduled friendly matches against Romania and Republic of Ireland leading up to Euro 2017. They will also face Sweden before heading to the tournament where they will make their debut at a major final. In the competition, Scotland is drawn in Group D with England, Spain, and Portugal. Dates for the friendlies are as follows: Scotland vs Romania on 9 June, Sweden vs Scotland on 13 June, and Scotland vs Republic of Ireland on 7 July.

Senior NHS whistleblower shared confidential documents detailing a £400m funding gap faced by the NHS in Scotland, leading to the need for significant changes to achieve financial balance. The documents suggest that the current healthcare model is unsustainable and call for radical decisions such as centralizing hospitals and closing services. The Scottish government is committed to protecting and increasing the NHS budget, but challenges are attributed to conflicting policies and inadequate funding. The whistleblower highlights issues across various health services, emphasizing the disconnect between policy announcements and financial commitments. The Health Secretary asserts that despite budget cuts, the NHS in Scotland has seen increased funding, but the documents point to ongoing challenges and the need for urgent action to address the funding gap.

Gramercy, a Connecticut-based hedge fund, purchased discounted defaulted debt from Peru in 2008. Peru's government opposes any legal action outside its borders. Buying defaulted bonds cheaply for profit in settlements is a common hedge fund strategy. Peru defaulted on $5.1bn in bonds in the 1980s. Gramercy threatened legal action against Peru under a US-Peruvian trade deal. Critics call this approach "predatory." Argentina is also in a court battle with hedge funds over defaulted bonds. Peru recently hosted meetings discussing how to help countries restructure debt after defaults to avoid lengthy legal battles.

Natacha Bouchart, a French politician, accused the UK Prime Minister of showing contempt towards Calais residents by not accepting any migrants from Europe in an offer to take in 20,000 migrants. She claimed that migrants in Calais view Britain as an attractive destination due to perceived lenient benefits and work opportunities. Bouchart stated that most migrants in Calais refuse asylum in France and prefer to come to England, citing lack of control and opportunities in the UK. She emphasized that even if more places were available in France, migrants would still choose England.

George Kay, 35, was charged with assault by beating, unlawful possession of a stun gun disguised as a torch, and possessing a bladed article (a hunting knife found in a wardrobe). He did not enter a plea at Brighton Magistrates's Court, and is set to appear at Lewes Crown Court on 11 January following his arrest on 3 October at his house in Crowborough.

A 29-year-old golfer finished strong with three birdies in the last four holes to win the tournament with a score of 20 under par, surpassing the Canadian leader Adam Hadwin. Hadwin, who shot an impressive round of 59 on Saturday, finished as the runner-up with a score of 19 under par. Scotland's Martin Laird was the highest-placed European player, tying for ninth place with a score of 14 under par.

Provan, a versatile player who can also play as a winger, joined Notts County Women's Super League One team after leaving Reading at the end of the 2016 WSL season. Both Provan and manager Rick Passmoor expressed excitement about her joining the experienced squad. The Spring Series, a transitional competition, features top-flight teams playing each other once over six weeks before the WSL switches to a winter calendar.

Mick Schumacher, 18, is set to drive demonstration laps in a 1994 Benetton car, following in his father's footsteps who achieved immense success in Formula 1 with 7 world titles. The Schumacher family has been in the public eye following Michael Schumacher's skiing accident in 2013, after which he retired from racing. Mick Schumacher is currently competing in European Formula Three.

England made 134-8 in their innings, with Imran Tahir taking 4-21 and Jos Buttler top-scoring with 32 not out. South Africa successfully chased down the target with Chris Morris scoring 17 not out off seven balls, securing a dramatic two-wicket win. England's bowlers performed well, with Chris Jordan taking 3-23, but South Africa managed to edge past them. The defeat was England's first in seven Twenty20 internationals. South Africa's Faf du Plessis credited his team's victory to solid bowling and resilient batting.

Summary:
On BBC Radio Ulster's Inside Politics programme, it was revealed that Sinn Féin has suggested a candidate to chair new talks, with no response yet from British and Irish governments. Criticism was expressed regarding previous negotiations, prompting further talks initiated by Mr Brokenshire. The UK and Irish governments aim for productive discussions at Stormont Castle and described the process as intensive. While the power-sharing executive deadline was missed, there is hope for further dialogue, as Mr Brokenshire does not foresee a snap election or a return to direct rule.

Lt Gen Zaid al-Saleh has told rebel fighters in Aleppo to surrender or face death, as government forces close in on victory. Tens of thousands of civilians are trapped in the rebel enclave, with reports of potential massacres. The rebels have lost over 90% of their territory since the government's offensive began a month ago. Russian-backed government forces have made significant advances, leading to a siege on the rebel-held areas. Efforts to secure safe evacuations for vulnerable civilians have been unsuccessful. The fall of Aleppo would be a major setback for the opposition, leaving the government in control of Syria's four largest cities. However, opposition groups remain determined to overthrow President Assad.

The Police Federation, representing PSNI officers, expressed low confidence in the ombudsman's office, citing ongoing issues and lack of officer trust. Chairman Mark Lindsay emphasized the need for reform due to budget cuts and reduced officer numbers, labeling the PSNI situation as a crisis. Criticism of the ombudsman's office is not new, with concerns raised about investigations and lack of officer confidence. Lindsay called for tougher measures to protect officers, including the use of spitguards, and urged politicians to prioritize policing and reconsider austerity policies.

Leicestershire Police are conducting searches in Braunstone Avenue in connection with the death of Megan Bannister, whose body was found in a car crash. A post-mortem examination revealed her injuries were not consistent with a crash. Two men, aged 27 and 28, are being questioned on suspicion of murder. Megan, due to take her GCSE exams, was found dead before a collision between a car and a motorbike. She was described as bright, talented, and wanting to become a midwife by her family and school.

Leicestershire played a key role in Richard III's campaign against Henry Tudor in 1485, with the king staying in Leicester before marching out to confront his rival. Richard's death at the Battle of Bosworth has left a lasting impact in the area, with the recent discovery of his remains adding to the historical significance. On 22 March, a reburial cortege will pass through various locations in Leicestershire, including Fenn Lane, Bosworth Heritage Centre, and both Dadlington and Sutton Cheney Churches before arriving in Leicester city center.

Ed 'Stewpot' Stewart, a former BBC radio DJ and Crackerjack presenter, passed away in hospital in Bournemouth. His colleagues and friends, including Tony Blackburn and David Hamilton, shared fond memories of him as a talented broadcaster and a great person. Stewart had a successful broadcasting career spanning over 50 years, hosting popular shows like Junior Choice and Top of the Pops. He was known for his catchphrase, "'Ello darling," and his love for golf and Everton FC. Many in the industry, like Noel Edmonds and Simon Mayo, paid tribute to his influence and contributions to radio.

Natalie Bennett experienced a rapid rise through the ranks of the Green Party, becoming its leader within six years of joining. She aimed to promote the party's message of combining economic and environmental justice, facing challenges in conveying this idea succinctly to the media. Bennett's struggles with interviews, particularly with BBC's John Humphrys, and a difficult moment on LBC's Nick Ferrari's show are highlighted. She believes British politics is broken and criticizes the focus on personalities over policies in the media. Bennett emphasizes the importance of journalists asking better, more sensible questions. Despite facing tough moments, such as a public struggle during a radio interview, she also had satisfying moments like challenging David Cameron on welcoming Syrian refugees.

Piers Linney, the joint chief executive of Outsourcery, will join the cast of the BBC Two show "Dragon's Den" alongside regulars Duncan Bannatyne, Peter Jones, Deborah Meaden, and new Dragon Kelly Hoppen. Linney, a former participant in Channel 4's Secret Millionaire show, aims to attract information economy entrepreneurs to the Den, believing they are crucial for the UK's future economy. With a background in law, investment banking, and venture capital, Linney heads Outsourcery, a company employing 150 people across the UK. The show's executive producer praises Linney's inspiring story, highlighting him as a new breed of Dragon representing the digital industry. Previous Dragon Theo Paphitis has decided to step down, making room for Linney's entrance. Hilary Devey and Kelly Hoppen are other recent departures and additions to the show's lineup, respectively.

Several councils in Kent, including Ashford Borough Council and Canterbury City Council, are owed significant amounts in unpaid fines, with Brighton reporting a high rate of unpaid fines, especially among foreign drivers. The councils are facing challenges in recovering these fines from foreign-registered vehicles due to limitations in enforcement capabilities and lack of access to drivers' information. To address this issue, some councils have engaged a private company to help collect outstanding fines. The British Parking Association advocates for reciprocal arrangements between the UK and other European countries to better enforce fines against foreign drivers.

Former Wales striker Rush believes that despite being a low-seeded team, Wales will pose a challenge for bigger nations in the upcoming draw. He highlights the team's successful qualifying campaign and strong work ethic of the players. Rush acknowledges the need for more goal-scoring options but is confident in the team's abilities to perform well and gain confidence from friendly matches.

The Labour party criticized the government for changes to Personal Independence Payments (PIPs) that they said would impact 160,000 people. The disability minister defended the changes, which aim to clarify eligibility criteria to support those in greatest need. The modifications follow two court rulings on benefits claims scoring.
