Madsen contributed with 43 before being bowled by Thomas (2-68). Kent ended the day at 30-0. This marked the fifth time a Derbyshire batsman achieved three centuries in successive innings, with Godleman being the latest since 1990. Rain delays led to an early tea break, and Derbyshire declared after the delay but couldn't take a wicket, with Kent finishing at stumps with Bell-Drummond (18 not out) and Key (11) unbeaten.

A new educational facility in Iskandar, Johor has been completed in just over three years, accommodating 3,000 students. Comprising two buildings with an atrium named 'Heartspace' as a relaxation area for students, the campus aims to foster research and economic development in Malaysia. It is closely located to the University of Southampton campus which was established in 2013. The opening ceremony was attended by Sir Jon Madjeski, businessman and co-chairman of Reading F.C.

Faranza Kousar from Glasgow died in an incident on the motorway near Eaglesfield in December 2014. Stephen Clarke, aged 59 from Wednesbury, appeared before Sheriff Scott Pattison on a charge of dangerous driving related to the incident. Clarke did not enter a plea and was released on bail.

Sina reported a significant increase in net profit for the October-to-December period, reaching $44.5m. The company plans to list Weibo in the US, aiming to raise nearly $500m by selling shares. Weibo boasts over 500 million registered users, with advertising revenue rising to $56m in the fourth quarter. However, a decline in user numbers was reported in 2013 due to a government crackdown on online 'rumour mongers.' Despite challenges, Sina's CEO remains focused on growing Weibo's user base and engagement.

Sussex Police deputy chief constable Olivia Pinkney addressed a situation involving new officers making inappropriate comments at the site of the Shoreham Airshow crash where 11 people died. The officers sent a video with offensive messages, causing distress to the victims' families. Pinkney expressed disappointment, apologized to the families, and considered suspending the constables, but ultimately chose to keep them on duty. The officers have been reassigned away from public duties, and Pinkney emphasized the impact of their behavior on the professionalism of their colleagues and the families affected by the crash.

A 23-year-old player from an unnamed Pro12 club underwent surgery for a persistent shoulder issue, leaving him out of action for up to six months. The player, who had loan stints with Glasgow Warriors and London Irish, will be sidelined until summer 2016. His most recent game was as a substitute in a European Challenge Cup victory over Bordeaux-Begles on 23 January.

Daimler uses R-134a refrigerant in Mercedes car air-conditioning units. Germany is accused of not implementing the EU MAC directive, which mandates the use of refrigerants with lower global warming potential. Daimler argues against using the new chemical, R1234yf, due to safety concerns, which are not supported by other car manufacturers or regulatory bodies. If Germany loses the case at the European Court of Justice, it may face a significant fine. The MAC Directive prohibits the use of fluorinated greenhouse gases with a global warming potential above 150 in car air-conditioning systems since 2011.

In March, Gawker was ordered to pay wrestler Hulk Hogan $140m for publishing a sex tape, with the legal bill paid by tech billionaire Peter Thiel who aimed to curb Gawker's actions. Thiel clashed with Gawker in 2007 over being outed as gay. Gawker's founder Nick Denton believes Thiel should expect public scrutiny due to his position, advocating for a 'thicker skin' approach. He suggests that Thiel's disdain for the media may also stem from criticism of his political views. Denton defends critical journalism and Gawker's role in holding powerful individuals accountable, emphasizing the importance of free press and critical voices.

Kensington Palace issued a statement expressing concern about a photographer who was allegedly surveilling and monitoring Prince George in a park. The palace warned the photographer to stop, threatening legal action if assurances weren't made. The photographer denies any wrongdoing and believes taking photos in public places is within his rights. Prince William aims to protect his family's privacy amidst media scrutiny, contemplating potential legal actions. The photographer's lawyers contest the allegations, asserting their right to photograph in public spaces. The royal couple emphasizes the importance of allowing Prince George to have a normal childhood. The incident raises privacy concerns and follows previous conflicts with the media over the photography of the royal family.

In a joint article, UK Prime Minister David Cameron and former TUC general secretary Brendan Barber argue that leaving the EU would be harmful to working people due to potential job losses, wage decrease, and risk to workers' rights. They stress the benefits of staying in a reformed EU, highlighting protections such as equal pay for women, maternity rights, and more. Employment Minister Priti Patel, however, believes that leaving the EU would free businesses from burdensome EU regulations and allow for greater prosperity. The debate underscores key concerns and arguments surrounding the upcoming EU referendum on June 23.

Rocket enthusiasts have convened in Scotland for International Rocket Week 2016, commemorating 30 years of their shared passion. The event originated from the Scottish Rocket Weekend in 1986, and participants now gather near Paisley to launch rockets reaching heights of up to 16,000 ft from a farm near Largs.

A woman in her 30s was physically assaulted and sexually assaulted in Langdale Common, Witney. The offender, wearing a black jacket, fled possibly due to interruption by others. Police are seeking information from witnesses and are increasing patrols in the area. Det Insp Larry Johnson urges anyone with relevant information to come forward, particularly those near Witan Way and the entrance to Langdale Common.

President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan received a triumphant welcome upon his return to Khartoum, with supporters celebrating his defiance of the International Criminal Court (ICC) and portraying his return as a victory over international pressure. Sudanese media praised Bashir's "star" status and criticized the ICC's reputation, while South African newspapers highlighted AU Chairperson Robert Mugabe's alleged promise that Bashir would not be arrested. Critics expressed concern over South Africa's perceived abandonment of international justice obligations and the potential implications for accountability of leaders accused of war crimes. The New York Times condemned South Africa's role in facilitating Bashir's escape and warned of the negative impact on its leadership position in Africa. Overall, the incident underscores ongoing debates on the effectiveness of international justice mechanisms and the challenges of ensuring accountability for alleged perpetrators of atrocities.

Victims' group Wave and families affected are calling for police to quickly inform relatives about the retention of body parts and tissue samples for investigations related to suspicious deaths. The PSNI has apologized for causing distress to families and acknowledged the need to inform relatives. While police had legally retained the items until 2006 without notifying families, they are now taking steps to visit affected families and address their concerns. The State Pathologist explained that the retained material could help determine cause of death or serve as evidence in court cases. Prof Crane emphasized the importance of communication with families regarding the retention and handling of these items.

British open water swimmer Keri-Anne Payne, aiming for a top-10 finish to qualify for the Rio Olympics, placed outside the automatic qualification at the World Championships in Kazan. Aurelie Muller of France claimed gold, with Payne finishing behind in fourth. Payne will have another chance to qualify at an Olympic qualification event in Portugal next year. Teammate Danielle Huskisson also aims to secure a spot for Rio. Payne, a two-time world champion, expressed determination to continue improving despite the setback. Huskisson discussed the challenges of competition and emphasized the need to focus on giving their best effort.

A nun in Santiago became pregnant after being raped by a man doing repairs at the convent. Her fellow sisters blamed her for the assault and pressured her to leave. She refused to sign papers leaving the Church and eventually gave birth, putting the child up for adoption. The nun's rapist was jailed in 2015. The nun is now suing the Archbishopric of Santiago and the Order of St Clare, claiming they failed to protect her. Her lawyer argues that the nun, living in a convent, should not have been left vulnerable to such a situation. The nun feels abandoned by her Church and family. The Bishop stated that the Archbishopric only learned of the situation on 27 March.

The North Cumbria University Hospitals NHS Trust is considering removing consultant-led services from Whitehaven's West Cumberland Hospital due to concerns about infrastructure and the ability to maintain services. Midwives at the hospital have raised safety concerns, warning that mothers and babies could face risks if consultant-led maternity services are consolidated at Carlisle Cumberland Infirmary, requiring potentially risky transfers. Trust chief executive Stephen Eames stated that while there is a preference for consultant-led services at both locations, the reality is that resources may not support this. A public consultation will be launched to gather feedback on the future direction of services provided by the trust, which has been in special measures since 2014 for failing to provide a sufficient level of care in multiple areas.

Asisat Oshoala, an exceptional young striker from Africa, made waves by winning both the Golden Boot and Golden Ball at the Under-20 World Cup Finals. She became the first African player to compete in the Women's Super League and joined Liverpool Ladies under manager Beard's guidance. Despite interest from other top clubs, Oshoala chose Liverpool for the opportunity to develop her game and play in the Women's Champions League. With key signings and departures, Beard believes Liverpool has assembled its strongest squad yet to compete for another league title, facing tough competition from clubs like Manchester City and Notts County. Oshoala's arrival adds excitement and optimism to Liverpool's prospects for the upcoming season.

Exeter Chiefs, currently second in the Premiership, managed to secure a bonus-point victory over Sale despite a lackluster performance. Head coach Rob Baxter highlighted the team's busy schedule without a weekend off in 30 weeks, including league matches, European Champions Cup participation, and a spot in the Anglo-Welsh Cup final. Baxter emphasized the need for the players to take time to relax and celebrate their achievements before facing tougher challenges ahead. He stressed the importance of setting higher standards for future matches.

A recent report on HMP Dovegate highlighted concerns such as high levels of violence, insufficient staffing, unjustified segregation, and poor visiting arrangements. However, the prison was commended for good living conditions and resettlement efforts. The Category B jail, run by Serco, holds about 1,060 male prisoners. Chief Inspector of Prisons, Nick Hardwick, noted a decline in performance under new management since 2013, with challenges such as an increase in prisoners convicted of serious violent offenses and issues with the use of force by staff. The prison has been struggling to address the impact of psychoactive substances. Efforts are being made to address these challenges, including working with Ofsted to improve education outcomes.

A London businessman has assured the staff of Hereford United that all payments, wages, and debts to football creditors will be settled this week to maintain their Conference status. The Football Conference is demanding concrete assurances from the club, warning of potential expulsion if football creditors are not paid by Saturday's Annual General Meeting. Conference GM Dennis Strudwick emphasized the need for Hereford to demonstrate financial stability to avoid expulsion and ensure completing the upcoming season. Hereford's statement reflects a commitment to returning to the Football League, with ongoing negotiations and takeover talks amidst financial challenges including a pending winding-up petition and unpaid tax demands.

A 49-year-old man, identified as the former Wham! singer George Michael, suffered head injuries in a car accident in Hertfordshire on 16 May. He was not wearing a seatbelt and could have faced prosecution for this, but no further action was taken by the police. Michael was a rear seat passenger in a Range Rover, and no other vehicles were involved in the incident. This is not his first driving-related incident, as he has a history of driving offenses, including crashes and driving under the influence of drugs.

Security staff at 11 airports operated by Highlands and Islands Airports (Hial) staged a 48-hour walkout due to a pay dispute leading to flight cancellations at Dundee airport. Hial is owned by the Scottish government and operates airports in various regions. About 120 AMSL staff participated in the industrial action. Hial bosses plan to make a formal offer to address the issue, aiming for a swift resolution to avoid further disruptions during the busy summer season. The Prospect union welcomed this move and expressed readiness to engage in constructive dialogue if the offer meets the workers' objectives.

The government has introduced two new stalking offences, following concerns that existing harassment laws were insufficient. A parliamentary inquiry revealed that around 120,000 victims, mostly women, are stalked annually, with only a fraction of cases leading to offenders being jailed. The new laws aim to address this issue, with stalking carrying a maximum six-month sentence and stalking involving fear of violence carrying up to five years in prison. The reforms were prompted by cases of stalkers escalating to violence, highlighting the urgent need for stronger legislation to protect victims and bring perpetrators to justice.

Oliver Stone expressed admiration for Indian cinema, praising its vitality and influence on his 1994 film, Natural Born Killers. During a visit to Mumbai, he mentioned the possibility of making a movie in India if he finds a compelling story. Stone also discussed his interest in Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray's work and shared his positive experience filming parts of Alexander in Ladakh. Additionally, he mentioned his upcoming documentary mini-series, The Untold History of America, set to air next year.

Aston Martin reported a pre-tax profit of £5.9m for the three months to March, driven by strong sales of its new DB11 model. Revenues more than doubled to £188m in the quarter. Despite facing annual losses for the past six years, the company is aiming to boost sales by over 30% in 2017 with its latest models. Aston Martin plans to enter the electric car market and has formed a partnership with LeEco, the Chinese backer of Faraday Future.

Summary:
- 28-year-old American became only the second player in history to average a triple-double for a full NBA season, beating out James Harden and Kawhi Leonard for the award.
- Draymond Green of the Golden State Warriors was named the best defensive player after winning the NBA title.
- Westbrook had a record-breaking season, achieving a triple-double average and setting records for triple-doubles in a season and highest points in a triple-double game.
- Westbrook credited his teammates for his success and expressed gratitude towards them.
- A triple-double in basketball involves double-digit stats in three of five categories: points, rebounds, assists, steals, and blocks.
- Despite losing former MVP Kevin Durant, Westbrook-led Thunder had a successful season with 47 wins.
- Other NBA Awards recipients included Mike D'Antoni as Coach of the Year, Malcolm Brogdon as Rookie of the Year, and Eric Gordon as Sixth Man.

Former Rangers player Lovenkrands believes Rangers should aim to reach the Scottish Cup final in May rather than be the first team to beat Celtic this season. He emphasizes the importance of winning in Old Firm games and encourages a new Rangers hero to emerge in the upcoming match. Lovenkrands acknowledges Celtic's dominance but points out Rangers' recent improvements under new manager Caixinha. He highlights the unpredictability of Old Firm games and the potential for the outcome to change quickly.

Patricia Connors and her pet tragically died after running onto the carriageway near Cardiff Gate services. The incident occurred at around 18:20 BST, resulting in the closure of the westbound carriageway for five hours between junctions 29 and 32. Ms. Connors was pronounced dead at the scene. Her family expressed their devastation, describing her as a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, and are struggling to cope with the loss.

A group of five men in Wrexham, north Wales, were linked by a dark secret of operating a predatory paedophile ring targeting vulnerable children in the 1970s and 80s. Despite initially feeling confident they would not be held accountable, they were brought to trial and some were cleared of charges. The trial highlighted a shift towards taking abuse complaints seriously. Rumors of the paedophile ring had circulated for years, and investigations like the Waterhouse inquiry acknowledged its existence. Efforts to break the silence around abuse continue, with many victims still reluctant to come forward. The victims bravely shared their testimonies, as forensic evidence was unavailable, relying on witness accounts for the case. The ringleader and his accomplices used their positions and connections to prey on young boys, with the victims facing immense challenges in seeking justice.

England delivered a crushing 61-21 defeat to Scotland at Twickenham, showcasing powerful play and exploiting Scottish vulnerabilities early on. Despite Scotland's efforts and injuries, England's relentless attack and strong defense secured a dominant victory. The match was marked by key plays from Jonathan Joseph, Farrell's accurate kicking, and a relentless England team determined to secure a historic win.

In a recent political discussion in Wales, sentiments shifted from camaraderie to contention as Leanne Wood challenged the First Minister on various fronts, signaling the start of an election campaign. Economic development, particularly around job creation, emerged as a key focus for Labour's campaign. Differences arose over the proposed M4 relief road – with the expensive black route and cheaper blue route options being debated. Recent developments revealed a significant cost increase for the black route, prompting Leanne Wood to express opposition to any deal with Labour involving the billion-pound investment in the black route. The Conservatives, on the other hand, have committed to commencing construction within a year without specifying a preference for the blue or black route. This issue starkly contrasts with the widely supported metro rail scheme in Cardiff, highlighting the divisive nature of the M4 relief road proposal in Welsh politics.

A new drone prototype resembling a helicopter has been unveiled, designed to carry a passenger. Controlled via a tablet, the drone features 8 propellers, takes 2-4 hours to charge, and offers approximately 23 minutes of flying time. It allows the passenger to choose their destination through the tablet interface.

Paul Chichester, speaking to businesses in his home city, highlighted the increasing relevance of cyber security for personal data, online banking, and shopping. The NCSC in London, part of GCHQ, handles threats from nations to individuals concerned about online identities. Wales, geographically close to GCHQ, can leverage its technology base and digital skills for economic benefits in cyber security. A National Cyber Security Academy in Newport and the Welsh Government's push to make south east Wales a hub for the industry reflect efforts to train experts and establish centers of excellence. Mr. Chichester emphasized the need for early digital education and vigilance against cyber attacks targeting businesses and individuals, such as ransomware incidents.

A new music series, produced by James Corden's company Fulwell 73, is set to debut in autumn, featuring live music performances, sketches, and interviews. Unlike Top of the Pops, the show will focus on creating shareable moments with contemporary and relevant content. The series aims to showcase popular bands and artists, with an initial six-episode run commissioned by the BBC. Executive producers Gabe Turner and Suzi Aplin will be leading the project, with more details to be announced in the summer. The producers hope to engage a weekend audience with the show and create impactful moments that resonate with viewers.

Canadian singer Jon Vickers passed away after battling Alzheimer's disease. His distinguished opera career spanned three decades, highlighted by challenging roles and a unique voice described as having "100 colours and inflections." Known for his warmth and generosity, Vickers gained international acclaim for roles like Siegmund in Wagner's "Die Walkuere" and Peter Grimes. His deep religious convictions shaped his performances, leading him to refuse certain roles on moral grounds. Vickers received numerous accolades, including two Grammys and the Companion of the Order of Canada, before retiring in 1988. He is survived by his sister, five children, eleven grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

Singer Adele made a surprise visit to the Chelsea fire station, bringing cakes for the firemen and joining them for a minute's silence to honor the victims of the tower block fire. Adele had previously shown support for the community affected by the blaze. Other prominent figures such as Jamie Oliver, Lily Allen, and Tom Hardy have also offered help and started fundraising efforts. The fire crews have received support from various individuals and The Fire Fighters Charity.

Prior to International Women's Day, several women activists in China were detained by the police for planning public campaigns against sexual harassment. One of the detained activists was held longer than usual, sparking concerns among activists. The detainees were associated with women's and gay rights groups in different Chinese cities. Their planned activities included marches advocating safe sex and raising awareness of sexual harassment, coinciding with major political meetings in China. The police released some activists with warnings, while others remain in custody on vague public order charges. Despite China's focus on women's rights at the legislative session, authorities are increasingly cracking down on independent organizations promoting their own agendas.

The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) will close on 17 March from 16:00 to 21:00 GMT to ensure public safety after past disturbances during St Patrick's Day. Universities in Belfast have canceled classes on 15 and 16 March, designating them as "reading days," with closures on 17 March. Hospitality Ulster praised local off-licences for voluntarily closing on St Patrick's Day to address unruly behavior, urging supermarkets to do the same. The move was cautiously welcomed by the Holyland regeneration association, emphasizing the issue of alcohol consumption in the area.

About 3,000 young people aged 10-18 participated in debates to create clauses for a "Magna Carta for the digital age," with the current top clause addressing government and commercial control of the internet. The My Digital Rights project, coinciding with the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta and the 25th birthday of the world wide web, aims to promote a free and impartial internet. Safety and cyberbullying were key concerns for the young participants, while the public emphasized issues of privacy and freedom. The project, led by the British Library, encourages discussions about digital rights and responsibilities. Notable figures like Sir Tim Berners-Lee have shown support for the initiative, which involves various organizations and remains open for public voting.

The Scottish Sentencing Council, established a year ago to enhance public confidence in court sentences, will focus on crimes by young people, death by driving, environmental and wildlife offenses, and start research on sentencing for sexual offenses. Chaired by Lady Dorrian, the council will conduct thorough research and broad consultations to develop sentencing guidelines. It will also address theft, property offenses, and domestic abuse in its upcoming work plan from 2018 to 2021.

Dumbarton secured a 3-1 victory over Raith Rovers with goals from Christian Nade, Daniel Harvie, and Gregor Buchanan. The win ended a three-game losing streak for Dumbarton, while Raith Rovers extended their winless run to 12 matches in league and cup competitions. Raith boss Gary Locke expressed disappointment with his team's performance, highlighting the need for improved consistency. On the other hand, Dumbarton manager Stevie Aitken credited new assistant Ian Durrant for making a positive impact. Raith's struggles continued as they faced the prospect of being dragged towards the relegation zone, while Dumbarton looked forward to facing St Mirren with confidence.

Police were called to a house in Parkgrove Terrace in Clermiston after which an unexplained death was discovered. The incident is currently being investigated by Police Scotland and the death is being treated as unexplained. Further inquiries are ongoing and a report will be sent to the procurator fiscal.

In a raid on RGHQ Chilmark, a former Ministry of Defence bunker, police seized thousands of cannabis plants worth £1m. The nearly impenetrable bunker had been converted into a large-scale cannabis production operation across 20 rooms. After gaining access through nuclear blast doors, police arrested five men and a teenager on suspicion of cannabis production. Additionally, three men were arrested for cannabis production and human trafficking offenses. The discovery was described as one of the largest cannabis crops ever found in the county.

A potential exomoon resembling Neptune in size and mass was detected by NASA's Kepler Space Telescope, orbiting a Jupiter-sized planet with significant mass. This signal was observed during three transits and will be further investigated with the Hubble Telescope in October. The researchers assign a four sigma confidence level to the signal, indicating high probability but caution is urged until more data is obtained. The candidate moon, Kepler-1625b I, is named "Nept-moon" and is located around a star 4,000 light-years from Earth. The discovery challenges current theories of planetary formation, suggesting captured moons may be possible. This finding is considered the most promising exomoon candidate yet, but further observations are needed for confirmation.

Norwich City defeated Blackburn Rovers 4-1, with Jacob Murphy scoring a spectacular first goal for the club. Wes Hoolahan and Cameron Jerome added further goals, while Steven Naismith also found the net. Blackburn's Anthony Stokes scored a consolation goal. Norwich's clinical display handed them their first opening-day victory in 14 years. Norwich manager Alex Neil praised Murphy's performance and the team's attacking intent. Blackburn boss Owen Coyle acknowledged Norwich's quality and expressed disappointment in his team's defensive lapses.

A British official made remarks highlighting Britain's historical achievements and resilience in response to reported comments that "no-one pays any attention" to Britain. The relationship between Britain and Russia has been strained, particularly over differences regarding the war in Syria. Despite the controversy, British Prime Minister David Cameron emphasized Britain's pride in its history and contributions to the world in various fields. A Conservative MP criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin on Twitter, but Mr. Cameron clarified that insults have no place in foreign policy.

Swansea City has climbed to 12th in the Premier League table, now 13 points clear of relegation. Manager Guidolin believes reaching the 40-point mark ensures safety and allows the team to plan for next season. The recent win against Chelsea is seen as the best performance under Guidolin's tenure, with a strong first-half display and Gylfi Sigurdsson scoring a key goal. The manager is pleased with the team's progress and hints at discussing a new contract once Premier League survival is fully secured.

A woman died after suffering severe burns in a fire at a sheltered housing complex in Ardnaclowney House. The fire, deemed accidental and originating in the kitchen of her top-floor flat, prompted a response from police and fire services. Three other residents were treated for smoke inhalation, and the investigation is ongoing with the flat cordoned off.
